text: My husband and I always come here when we go to New Orleans. They have the best coffee (their vanilla lattes are always incredible!!) and the best donuts. You won't regret it. If you are in the mood for bagels instead, you'll love Steins bagels next door. Both places have an amazing vibe

Eh, this place is fine" is the thought that keeps coming up as I figure out how to write this review. In my stable of establishments to patron, this is filed under "Go to if you're looking to give the impression of a fancy restaurant and food doesn't matter.

None of the food is bad, per se, but I also cannot think of one dish that has knocked my socks off. The same can be said for the drinks. I ordered a apple cider mule last time I was here and I'm not sure what the problem was, but it wasn't good and that is something that is hard to mess up in my opinion. I also had the filet and the cream of tomato soup. The filet was very tender and good, bit the flavor wasn't great if that makes sense. Finally, the  soup was too thick and salty for my tastes and that is saying a lot considering I love salty food! I hate to give a restaurant an okay review, but okay has just been my opinion of the food here.

Prices seemed decent but close to the more than I would have liked to pay' end considering the service was spotty and the food was mostly average.

Other than that, the ambiance was great for getting dressed up and a romantic dinner. Low lighting, and polite wait staff makes this a great go to for dates if you're trying to impress someone early in your relationship.

I played Yelp Roulette for Castleton.  They were some other options I wanted to try like burgers and BBQ, but I had that recently. #40 on the list was Joella's.  As I looked at the menu, it claimed the winning spot for my supper.

Joella's is a little different from your standard fast food chicken places.  You get to choose your level of spice, more side options, and dipping sauces you do not get from other establishments. 

I went with the Jumbo tenders at the Ella's Fav level with red-skin mashed potatoes and green beans.  For checking in to Yelp, I also got a big wing, which I almost had to argue about receiving.  The tenders were big, juicy, and on the spicy side.  The green beans were ok but the mashed potatoes was very creamy and delicious. The wing had good flavor but has the flaws of most wings, not enough meat and some maneuvering.

One sauce comes with the meal and one sauce is just not good enough for this sauceaholic. So I chose 5 and paid an extra 50 cents for each one.  A description of the sauces I tried are: Jojo (Mustard BBQ), Bama white (a lot of horseradish), cheerwine BBQ (Cheerwine is a chery flavored soda), pimento ranchero (ranch with pimento cheese), and my favorite  - the spiked honey.  I am having a hard time thinking of a sauce similar to it.  Either way, that's the sauce I'm choosing next time then either the Jojo or Pimento Ranchero.

For dessert, they have pie in a jar.  I had the chocolate peanut butter one which was very fulfilling. I get to keep the jar too.

Sweet tea was Indiana level sweet tea which means barely sweet.  But it was fresh-brewed. 

I thought of Joella's as a better Southern Pop-eyes.  If you love fried chicken with some heat, come give it a try.

I really enjoyed this place. It was some of the best Korean I have had in the city and I would love to come back and try a salad. I was able to get my kids sandwiches which were really good as well. The pricing is about 5.99 a sandwich. Bimpap was 10.99 which is going rate I have noticed. Go there!

My daughter got a little confused and thought she was buying Imagine Dragon tickets for West Palm Beach but instead she purchased in Tampa. She managed to get us floor so we decided to keep them and take a road trip. Since we had floor and it's first come first serve we came very early to make sure we got to the front of the line. Unfortunately for us we stood in the wrong line for a really long time. By the time we figured out what was going on we were in the back of the line of people heading to the floor. They handed out wrist bands to signify who got to be on the floor. That part was great but better signs marking the respective lines would have been helpful. Security was pretty quick but I never bring anything in with me except one credit card, my phone, and a car key. 

Once inside things worked out better. We managed to find a spot along the rail and began what had to be the hottest night of my life. It was so hot that I felt dizzy at times. They sold expensive but necessary frozen lemonade on the floor which saved me. It was cash only which forced a necessary trip to the expensive cash machine. 

The show was amazing. We were so close to the band and they dropped balloons and shot out confetti several times during the show. This was the most civilized crowd I have ever been in. No one pushed or tried to cut in front of me. We all just danced and had the best time. In Broward it is a fight to keep your spot. I loved the show and it made all of the uncomfortable standing and heat worth it. 

After the show arena attendants were rude about patrons leaving. I sat down for a minute to catch my breath after standing for four hours in extreme heat and I was screamed at. Since we came early we were in the front of the parking lot. Leaving was another nightmare. No one moved around us for over an hour. We were completely stuck. Parking attendants to direct traffic would have been appreciated. The concert let out at 11 and we didn't get on the road until well after 12 AM. If I came back I would take Brett M.'s advice about parking at the exit and taking a long walk to the entrance in order to be able to leave. 

I think how much you enjoy your show at this arena depends on the weather. This arena has covered seating but it is open on the sides with lawn seating. If there is lightening in the area they will stop the show or cut it short. That is what happened to us the night before in Palm Beach. The finale was changed to acoustic because of bad weather as people were forced out of the arena. I am so happy we decided to keep the Tampa tickets where we saw the full ending of the concert. It seems easier to get good tickets here as opposed to more populated Broward County and my daughter lives in Orlando so I may be back.

When my friends and I asked the hostess about the origins of Capdeville, she told us that there are two things that the owners absolutely love: "Food and Rock n' Roll." Now take that idea and roll with it as you peruse the menu of eclectic entrees and appetizers ranging from Fried Red Beans and Rice to Fish Tacos. It proclaims itself to be an interpretation of a British social house that has been Americanized, and I think they have that spot on. The atmosphere gives a since of freedom that allows the patrons to be both elegant and relaxed, whichever one is more their style.

As far as food goes (and I think the other reviewers will back me up on this one), it is a complete necessity for someone at the table to order the Truffled Mac n' Cheese. Take about melt in your mouth deliciousness right there. It's incredibly rich, but by the time you've finished it, you'll still want more. The burgers are also pretty spectacular. I personally tried the Capdeville Burger, which was everything I wanted and more. The fries were delicious and perfectly seasoned (not too salty like at some places), and the price was absolutely acceptable. 

The only down-side of our trip was a not-exactly-delightful Pimm's Cup. You'd think it would be difficult to mess up a Pimm's Cup (my personal cocktail of choice), but whoever made it did a pretty good job of doing so. It seemed hastily made (perhaps because there was a pretty large crowd at the bar when we ordered) and wasn't worth the $9 they were going to charge. This problem, however, was immediately solved by our waiter who was super cool and took it back. We opted for Abita Strawberry instead, a great combination with the burger and fries. 

Which brings me to my favorite part: the staff. I suppose I'm not very familiar with the staff as a whole, but the waiter and the hostess that helped us were absolutely stellar. The waiter was very helpful and completely cool with us sending back the Pimm's cup (sometimes you get those stuffy types that don't hesitate to let you know how much of an inconvenience it is - not the case here). The hostess (Lauren) was also fantastic. She got us settled as soon as she could, and even paid us a few visits and answered the questions we had about the restaurant and the inspiration for it. And it was thanks to her that we got to have the most delicious dessert ever: King Cake Bread Pudding. I kid you not, friends. This bread pudding was made from a Haydel's King Cake that was brought in earlier that morning, and it was divine. 

So all-in-all, I think it's safe to say that Capdeville will be a place that I will frequent often for their delicious food and even more delicious prices.

I've been coming to this Taco Tote for a few years now, always bringing my kids who love it as much as I do. It's simple counter service tacos with a decent sized salsa/fixings bar and a 144-flavor coke machine at a good price. I tend to go with Chicken Adobodo (which I can never pronounce right and end up saying the "bodo" part about three times) while my kids enjoy the various "fajita" tacos (chicken or beef). They have limited kids meals (chicken nuggets or a taco) but I've never heard complaints (and often snag and extra nugget to dip in some salsa - part of a standard Dad's right to "taste test" the food. You know... for quality).

You can see the cooks preparing the food behind the cashier - chopping up the fresh meats and cooking them on the grill. It always comes out hot and the tortillas are some of the best I've ever had (you'd think a flour tortilla is a flour tortilla, but they know how to make a *good* tortilla at this place). I like to drizzle some dark, smokey "salsa" on my tacos with lettuce, lime juice (from little wedges), and a bit of guacamole salsa. I'll fill a few tubs of various "hot" salsas for dipping my chips as well - love to mix and match a few flavors. The beans and rice are pretty standard (part of the 4 stars) - part of a combo - but you can also get the "pack" which includes a baked potato instead. It's as delicious as a baked potato can be.

As for the coke machine - the kids *love* these new touch screen fountain soda machines with upwards of 144 flavors. Grape Mellow Yellow mixed with cherry fanta? You got it. Vanilla Barq's rootbear with a splash of peach coke and some diet lime sprite? Uhm... no. But you can have it if you want it!

Overall, tacos are a solid 5 in my book. The rice and beans are just regular, standard fare - 3 stars. The addition of the kid-favorite soda machine is always a nice bonus - a solid 5 there. Sometimes in the *back* section of the restaurant, in the booths by the windows you will get some annoying flies - definitely a 3 for that, but they stick to that back area, which is hot anyway from the large windows and so best to be avoided. Overall... 4 stars. Tada! I *can* do basic math. And Taco Tote can do good tacos (which is really what this review is about).

Sweet Tomatoes is a craving. It's also my post half marathon meal go to- buffet/all you can eat? Yes please.

I love eating here, even though it's not the best food I've ever had. The salad bar is always clean and fresh. My go-to's-  Chinese chicken won ton salad and the tuna tarragon. On the soup side, there are always the staple chicken noodle chunk and kettle house chili options as well as 1-2 vegetarian options(split pea or lentil seem to be the regulars). There are usually 1-2 others in rotation- French Onion and/or clam chowder. The seasonal soups are always the best in my opinion. The Albondigas Mexican soup is my favorite. The bakery section is the star of this location - offering 3-4 different biscuit/muffins including the seasonal one, dessert cobbler of the season, as well as a focasia, pizza bread, and sourdough/multigrain bread. Let me not forget to mention the frozen yogurt machine and toppings. Dessert sundae is always a must! I usually steer clear of the pastas and mac and cheese. They're bland and overall not so great.

Sometimes this location can be a little messy with people slopping soup and random food everywhere, but more times than not, it's clean and there is always someone ready to pick up my empty plates/bowls as soon as I'm done.

Sign up for the Club Veg emails and get coupons galore. I never come here without some kind of 20%off or other discount coupon! Makes it much more worth than the $12 dinner price tag.

My husband and I love craft beer, so Philly Beer Week is one of the best times of the year - when we have time to enjoy it. I actually had the weekend off for once, so we made sure to hit up as many of the events and bars as our livers could handle. BRU Craft & Wurst was celebrating their 1st birthday so we hit them up for a late lunch.

They had a live band performing (mostly covers), and although they were good performers, DEAR LORD was it loud inside! We asked to be seated as far from them as possible, and it was still incredibly difficult to hear one another. A place that primarily shills beer/alcohol should foster conversation, not lonely consumption. We like the concept of the 'self serve' drafts that charge you per ounce, but for this latest visit we stuck with the bar's draft list. They had some sandwich specials as part of their celebration - we shared the roasted pork and garlic pork sausage with sauerkraut, both of which had pickles and chips. The food was great with our cold brews, both meats super juicy and tender and instantly put us in a summer state of mind. If it wasn't for the loud music, we would've hung out longer and had another drink, but our ears were ringing and we left to enjoy the sunshine.

On a quick weekend trip to Nashville, I almost forgot to visit the Country Music Hall of Fame & Museum! I am so glad that I was able to get in a visit before heading to the airport!  

First - it is a gorgeous building, outside and inside the lobby.  It's very well designed, with soaring ceilings and windows in the front, and beautiful wood floors.  There is a sweeping staircase and elevators.  The walls are covered with awards and names of musicians.

No, wait - for real first off - everyone is really friendly here.  The ladies at the ticket counter, the folks at the coat check (complimentary!) and the young man at the beverage kiosk.  All super nice. 

The place is CLEAN.  The floors - whether stone, cement, wood or carpet - all clean.  Walls and windows - clean.  Sparkling.  They are paying attention to this - there was not a speck of litter anywhere.  The cases around the exhibits were crystal clean - and I didn't see people pushing their fingers up against them and getting them all dirty.

There are plenty of "hands on" kinds of exhibits for listening to music and getting information but so much of the visual part of the museum is composed of clothing.  The place is full of headless mannequins wearing the most amazing array of outfits I never did see in my life.  I have to confess - I love the costume exhibits at the local art museums in San Francisco - and this really made the museum compelling for me.  All the outfits are properly fitted on mannequins which stand at the size/height of the original wearer of the item -- so it gives you a sense of how big and tiny some of these folks were (Loretta Lynn was tinytinytiny!).  

There were so many great artifacts there, in addition to outfits there were instruments, automobiles and many other things.  I would definitely return and would love to attend a special event there.  My mom was very jealous.

Tang Bistro's been on my radar ever since it first opened. A lot of Northern Chinese spots seem to have opened up recently (South Silk Road, Blossom Northern China Cuisine and Chinese Crepe). TB specializes in Xi'an cuisine.

We came on a Tuesday evening and the place was half full. The inside is quite spacious and even has a patio facing out onto 109 Street (after all, it housed Urban Diner). The menu is beautifully done and more upscale than your normal Northern Chinese spot.

- Liang-pi (cold noodles) ($7.50) - crap, I didn't realize that you had the option of getting this non-spicy, mild, medium or intense! Would love to see how "intense" it really gets. The cold noodles had a chewy, slippery bite. Comes with the usual bean sprouts, julienne cucumbers and spongy gluten. Good but I prefer Noodle Feast's version.
- Cucumber salad with garlic sauce ($6.50) - the cucumbers had a satisfyingly crunchy bite. The vinegar/garlic sauce was bright and refreshing. Would get this again.
- Spicy pig ears ($9.50) - the spicy pig ears had a tasty chili oil sauce. Great texture but the portion was pretty small for the price. CC thought it came in a "ear shaped" bowl.
- Scramble egg & tomato ($10.50) with hand pulled noodles ($2.00) - the hand pulled noodles had a great chewy toothsome bite to them and the egg & tomato sauce worked well with the noodles. The combo felt like you were eating Italian with an Asian spin to it. The egg reminded me some sort of delicious cheese. I know that sounds weird but it was good.

The dishes are a bit on the oily side of things but everything was solid. Will be back to try more dishes. 3.5 stars.

I don't know where all the negative reviews come from but this place was awesome! We got the two hour unlimited game card for $23 each and it was probably the most fun I've ever had at any arcade in my life! I played Jurassic Park, Transformers, Werewolf and House of The Dead 4 and they were so awesome. My favorite was the Werewolf one because the seat moved along with the game so it wasn't a sit game the whole time. Also, the race car games move as you drive too. I have nothing but great things to say about this place and I am so glad I got to go and experience it! Loved it! Definitely plan to go back and bring friends and family!

Always good and cook fresh. I loved coming here for everything when I am in the area. The parking is a little crazy in the front but they have rear parking. I would say what to order, but I had mostly everything its all good.

I just want to add what I ate which was a grilled chicken po-boy with swiss cheese and grill onion and mushrooms ($ 9.25) large french fries ($3.95). My sandwich was good and stuff and my fries was hot and crisp. It was quiet at the time I went but it's usually large crowds.

Ok, I'm sold! The Piazza's new Pod Park opened today and it's such a wonderful use of old dead space. This lovely pastel colored, open air space is exactly what the area needed and where many will, and should be flocking to this summer. 

The tunes were bumping, thanks to a solid dj. The kids were playing in modern formations and on rocking horses. The doggies were wagging their tails, as they're welcome here, and folks were grabbing drinks from various shops shaped like cargo shipping boxes! Way cool! They included a Tiki bar, Craft Cocktail Concepts by Blume, Urban Village Brewing and more! Think anything from exclusive IPAs on draft to Frose' (frozen rose') and sangria. A lil something for everyone! 

All were enjoying the sunshine and good vibes.

There's a decent variety of food...Mama Maria's Italian Ice, Urban Empanada Box, Passyunk's own Essen Bakery, Tokai for vegan French Toast and bacon a la cart, Bru, Lil Sum Sum for dim sum and Spread Bagelry. 

There are some shadier areas and pretty textured white umbrellas. There are also really cool modern seating options. 

There are light strands, cut out iron lamp poles and marquee lights on the shops for at night. 

There's also a stage! I can't wait to see who performs! 

There's giant wooden Jenga and a neat viewing platform. 

There's even a toy store with bubbles and chalk to keep your kiddos busy. 

It's definitely a unique space I'm thrilled to see! It's so nice to have a reason to come back to this area again!!

Oh, and the friendly looking robot statue named Bebot, who was originally created for Burning Man at the entrance, is so fun! 

Dog park, large kids' space and nursing areas to come...

*As of Monday June 10th, the parking lot to the left of the entrance will have FREE parking with validation from any of the shops!

**Restroom are air-conditioned trailers in the rear of the park.

Willa Jean is awesome...what a special space with delicious comfort food. I loved the corn bread appetizer and the meatball sandwich that I had for lunch. The frose was also outstanding!

It was all so relaxing and made me feel less like a tourist in such a great city!

I like the decor, love the breakfast and the coffee is top notch.  When i'm feeling nostalgic about the 90's grunge days, this is my nashville go to spot and it gives me a little time to ponder what ever happened to that Afghan Whigs CD I let my roomie borrow.

Johns water ice is the best!!! I want for this to be open every what.
I absolutely love the chocolate and pineapple ice. Their ice is so smooth and perfect!
The ice cream is also great. I like doing a chocolate ice with strawberry ice cream mix. Or pineapple and vanilla ice cream mix.
Superb place! Friendly service.

Not impressed with the "bento" style lunch box. Presentation was sloppy, half bowl of rice, teriyaki vegetables were mostly cabbage and the crunch shrimp roll was tasteless.
The miso was good but the dressing on the salad was not appealing. (I normally love ginger dressing.) 
Part of me wants to try again but I also want good food that fills me up. 
Maybe your meal will be better?

Beautiful and Historic! I really love this place from the preshow music that vanishes into the stage to the stary skies that wish me sweet dreams as I leave after the show!

I heard they just went digital and the sound booms and no one has to carry film rolls of Gone with the Wind that weigh over 100 pounds (thanks NPR). 

Paid 10 bucks for a Sunday night show. Only one movie to choose from, makes the decision easy. But even considering the higher cost and limited selection, this place is AMAZING!

I really love the architecture and decor. I could come here with no movie playing and just wanted around. It is really old school and really cool. 

I did not try the food and the seats could be more comfortable, but this is a unique Nd authentic movie going experience, and I cannot complain about a thing. I plan to go out of my way to come back here. The Tampa Theatre is a true landmark.

Let's face it, Philly is severely lacking in the ramen department.  And by lacking, what I really mean is that it doesn't really exist.

Enter: Nom Nom Ramen.  For ramen lovers out there then, this restaurant should be somewhat of a nice surprise.  Except that it's really not all that.  It's not terrible, but i certainly wouldn't characterize this as good ramen.

The broth is mediocre and lacks depth of flavor.  The noodles are even worse - it's like they threw in spaghetti noodles and called it ramen.

The char sui is flavored fine but is a little tough.

Since there's really no other ramen joints, it might satisfy your ramen craving.  But don't expect something you'd get in LA or NYC.

Best Cuban in Tampa! I have found no one who beats La Bamba's pulled/roast pork. Also love the fresh chopped onion on top of the beans. Delicious! 

The place is nothing to speak of and I wish they were open for dinner and on UberEATS, but that's just for my convenience.

Food = 5 stars

Love this place. This is more pizza for say the "whole foods" type of crowd-think toppings like goat cheese, pesto, eggplant, and pine nuts.  If you're a traditionalist who likes pizza from Papa Joe's or Sal's, then yes you might find this pizza overpriced and not to your liking.  Personally I like this upscale pizza place-I've actually been on frst dates here.

Damn. This place rocked my world. If you know me, you know I'm obsessed with Chinese food. 

It was busy on a Saturday night, but we only waited 15 minutes for a table for 4. The table ordered: mala chicken, moo shu pork, shrimp with snow peas and mushrooms, and hunan tofu. I only tried the chicken and pork, but both of the other dishes looked amazing, got rave reviews, and the plates were all clean by the end. I could see that the shrimp was cooked to absolute perfection.

Next time I go back (oh, there WILL BE a next time, for sure) it will be really hard not to get the mala chicken again. Menu listed it as very spicy, and while it had a kick it definitely wasn't Han Dynasty spicy. The morsels of chicken were so tender and fried beautifully - there was a very light coating that provided just enough crispness. The sauce was surprisingly complex, with notes of sichuan peppercorn, black vinegar, honey, garlic, and chiles. The portion was quite large but I ended up eating it all. Well, F kept stealing pieces but I guess I did offer to share both dishes we ordered... Next time he's getting his own.

The moo shu pork was OK, but moo shu isn't really my thing. I will say it's by far the best moo shu I've had on a very short list. Loved the seaweed (?) and glass noodles; it was very fresh-tasting.

Housemade pickles to start and chocolate-dipped fortune cookies with orange wedges at the end. What could be better? Some reviewers have complained about the portion sizes but I thought they were a reasonable size. You're not getting two pounds of food like at a cheap Chinese takeout joint, but the food is infinitely better, fresher, and made with higher quality ingredients. Worth paying a few extra dollars for.

Dinner entrees are a bit pricey for typical Chinese food, but on par with what you might see at the local Thai places ($14-$17 per entree). Certainly still affordable by Main Line standards!

[766]

I really love the Container Store!  When I learned they were coming to our area I had to show up during the opening. 

Plenty of parking as this store is next to the King of Prussia mall (not in it)

The store is huge with tons of organization options. 

I always stop in to "look around" but always end up leaving with a few items 

I'll be back!

This is perhaps less to do with the general decor as with the premise of the place itself (pun intended). It looks a little bit rundown, but the staff are absolutely lovely, the people seem happy there, and you can get lost for hours (for a flat rate! yes! it's real!) in hard to find, unique board games. This place just makes me really really happy. Come here if you want to be happy.

The hand made tortillas were enough to make me love this place. The menu is a little disorienting at first but it breaks down into plain meat tacos, meat and cheese quesadilla, and tamales. The meat was wonderful. The steak was super tender and flavorful. The pork was a little fatty, bit worth I for the flavor. My favorite was the melted cheese. It was more sharp than a traditional queso fresco, an really made them stand out above the plain tacos. There are definitely no frills at this place. Old school, but being done right.

I love to start my day with a good breakfast! I've been following these guys on Instagram and they make me so hungry with their photos! My husband I am we're close to them so we decided to have a quick breakfast. 

The Place:
They are located in front of David's Bridal, in a cute little building. It looks really traditional and old school. Yet really adorable and you had the feeling of comfort food. 

The Food:
Food was traditional breakfast and lunches, with great selection of Mimosas, unfortunately it was a week day so no fun Brunch, just breakfast :(
I got some coffee and water while looking at the menu. 
I ordered some "Traditional pancakes" and a side of scramble eggs- they were really yummy and fluffy. The eggs were amazing! They had a great taste, like if they just pick them up from the farm earlier in the morning (seriously!)
My husband got the "Eggs Benedicts" with hash browns- i stole half of his hash browns and they were so yummy! 

The Service:
The service was great, the food came out fast and we had breakfast in like 30 minutes which was what we were looking for. 

Overall: 4 Stars (Salmita's Scale) I still want to come back and eat with more time, try more meals and their mimosas of course! ;-)

My home church in the heart of downtown Tampa.  I love Sacred Heart so much and yes, I'm biased because this is where my husband and I attend mass and where I had my confirmation and where we got married. So many memories here and hopefully many more in the future. 

I'll start by just how beautiful this church is which really goes without saying to anyone who's visited. I feel at peace and so welcome here by the staff and fellow parishioners. I could stare at the ambiance all day. The stained glass windows and the gold trimming details , the marble pillars, I feel like I'm in a huge cathedral. Oh and the musicians and choir are outstanding. 

I have to give a special shout out to my Fav Friar, Fr. Zachary Elliott, OFM. He is so wonderful! He worked with me during my confirmation and also with all of the steps I needed to take before getting married. He is extremely kind, caring, and he made the process fun! I received so many praises about him after my wedding ceremony and he even was so kind to attend our reception and deliver our prayer before dinner.

Due to my extensive travel history, I have built a very strong and picky tongue for authenticity. That being said, I can tell you Casablanca is the real damn deal. I'm about to tell you why. 

The entire menu at Casablanca is filled with what you'd find at a typical restaurant in Havana. I recognized many dishes that I've dined on and they were all delicious, so it was hard for me to make a decision. During my first visit I bellied up to the world-famous Sandwich Cubano (roasted pork, ham, pickles, Swiss cheese and mustard on a Cuban style bread). Man, I tell you, it was SPOT ON. Reminded me of my trip years ago when I had my first one. The meat was roasted to perfection, delivered a dynamite of flavor and was too damn good to stop eating! If you try one thing here, this is it!

On another occasion I was served the Ropa Vieja (shredded beef in Cuban Creole sauce with onions and peppers. Served with white rice, black beans and sweet ripe plantains (maduros)). This also happens to be Cuba's national dish! Again, each bite took me back to Havana. Sweet, delicate and tender beef paired with fresh cooked rice and beans. The taste was outstanding. Boise lacks so many authentic cuisine but Casablanca reminds me that true food is there if you seek it. 

On another note, I absolutely loved our waiter both times. He was very kindhearted and humorous, took time to inform us of what each dish consisted of, which was super helpful for my very Americanized husband (nothing wrong with that - he just doesn't have the palate for authentic food like I do!). 

In a heartbeat, I recommend this to anyone who is tired of over-sweetened, sodium packed eateries that boast but fail to deliver genuine cuisine. Also, if you've never had Cuban food you are missing out on so much!!! And it's here, in little Boise so HEAD OVER AND SUPPORT THIS LOCAL BUSINESS that I love so dearly!

Great little place to check out for noodles or dumplings! Place is on the smaller side. There are benches outside along the Main Street to sit as well. Dumplings are only sold in groups of 5 unless you head over on Wednesday when they have $1 dumplings. Typically you can not mix Sweet and savory but the counter guy was feeling friendly and allowed me to do so. My friend and I ordered a cheesesteak noodles and a 5 pack of dumplings. Taco, buffalo chicken, cheesesteak, apple pie and cheesecake. There are sauces on the table are great for dipping. As a condiment lover, enjoyed them greatly! The dumplings were packed with flavor. The cheesesteak was my favorite savory And the cheesecake my favorite sweet. Apparently cheese is the key to my happiness! I might have ordered another if they available individually.

The noodles were fresh. Ramen style but fancier. They were tossed in a white super gooey delicious cheese sauce with large pieces of cheesesteak and perfectly cut scallions. 

Looking forward to hearing back to try some more. Hopefully my next trip will be on a Wednesday where you can buy as many or as few as you would like!

I believe I have finally found my coffee shop! Cue the heavenly light and angels...AWWWWWWWWE!

Off the bat, it smells amazing. Not that coffee shops don't smell okay, the slight hint of tea leaves in the air is so refreshing here.

They still have everything I love from the other Mojos including the nifty chalkboard, local art, but more of it, including the postcards and flyers lining a step right under the bar. I called for a Milky Way and forgot to request it cold. Nonetheless, it was DELICIOUS and beautiful to boot. 

Though there are no couches for that homey sort of feel, I love all the tables because 1. They're big enough for all my shenanigans I bring to the coffee shop. 
2. There is no lack of plugs. 
3. They're spread out enough that everyone's biz is their own.
4. This is a weird one. I love seeing people I know, but sometimes it can be distracting when trying to knock something out. There are enough tables that you don't have to be by the front door where you'd constantly be looking up when someone comes in and possibly seeing someone you know with the obligation to chat. And there is a back door that you can escape out of. 

My only problem is the chairs are a little tough on my boney butt, but I think that's a personal problem. Next time I'll just bring one of those blow up cushions, and be the cool kid. Will definitely be returning!!!

I don't know how to review this place. Is it a restaurant? Is it fast food? Its a weird mix of both. I think they should pick one and stick with it. You order and pay as you walk in, then get your drinks and seat yourself. Your food is then served to you. We weren't halfway through our appetizers of lettuce wraps and two crab wontons when our food was served. We had the Honey Crispy Chicken with white rice and the Pei Wei Spicy Chicken. We loved the lettuce wraps. The rest was good but nothing special.

Don't let the word "diner" fool you. Good food but pricey. For $32 we could have gotten more bang for our buck at our local chinese restaurant.

I love this little place.

I started off with a frustrated taste in my mouth. It was no fault of their own, though. Google had listed them as being open during their transition from a coffee truck to a storefront and I arrived before actually having opened.

Several months later I finally got the chance to go back to an *open* Kaffeine Coffee. It quickly became my favorite spot downtown to work and caffeinate. 

The decor is a cool warehousey feel. The ambience is chill. The drinks I've had thus far--a Chemex with South American beans (Mexico, I think) and an Americano--were perfectly delicious. The staff are much more helpful than most baristas I've run into, particularly in the context of local, artisan type shops. 

If you're downtown and want some brew, don't miss the chance to get the best of the best here at Kaffeine.

I fell in love with this little tea place! They have an enormous variety of tea and the staff is extremely helpful and patient. The decor is super cute they have tea cups and tea sets on display and for sale as well. There isn't a lot of room inside to sit and study or hang out but they have outdoor seating. They also have fans outside so it isn't too bad to sit and catch up outside. I would not be able to study or get work done there though. The tea was really good. I was able to mix two different teas together. I hate when I go to tea places and they tell me they can't mix x  tea and y tea bcuz the steeping time is different .... duh obviously you won't be able to steep it the same way but you can steep it separately and then mix them together -_- .... this place was more than happy to mix teas so I loved them just for that.

I totally went to this........And I totally loved it.

So much food! And it's all relatively pretty well priced. For less than twenty dollars I got one of the best pulled pork sandwiches I have ever hard in my life... the tastiest, juciest roasted corn [omg]... some greasy,but frikkin' good Texas Style Potato Chips, and an oh-so-satisfying Funnel Cake smothered with Fresh Strawberries. Yum Yum Yum. There are vendors from all over the nation at this thing.

It's not year round - which sucks, but if you're ever in Reno around Labor Day - you must - YOU MUST check this food festival out. Admission is Free, food is not. - Don't forget to check out all the mullets!

I've worked maybe 2 shifts and watched a bunch of movies here while it was still the Ritz (I left way before the Landmark takeover). I love Joe and Maurice (2 workers, one is now a manager). The workers do their job and do them well. I haven't had serious issues with projection or sound (not that I can remember). The theater layout is strange and the floor in the lobby I have heard is uneven and makes you feel like you have vertigo.

The number one issue with this theater is how small the ladies room is. I haven't been into the men's room. The ladies room is really tight but I've heard rumors about expansion. I have never worked their concession but it's pretty small back there. I sucked at the cafe but as a customer, I've had no complaints. Oh, and in one of the theaters is a closet and at one point someone went in there which disturbed my movie watching experience (note: She doesn't work there anymore). This is rare that it happens, though. Also, I think the ushers do a good job of theater checks and cleaning up. Very consistent.

As for parking, go to the Olde City Garage, entrance on 2nd. Show your ticket to the person at the door or box office at the Ritz Five and they will give you a validation card. You now pay $6.50 for parking! Easy and convenient. Too bad they raised the rates, it used to be only $5 for parking.

Overall, a great theater. I love the Ritz movie theaters.

Ohhh Stella. You rock. 

I've been here so many times since they first opened, and every visit has been a pleasure. Family and friends are always happy here. First reason might be because the pizza crust here might be the best: so insanely flavorful, with a perfect leopard-spotted undercarriage indicating expertly tended char, plus the right amount of cornicicione. Secondly, the menu offers diners both the complex AND simple pizza options, and there is no 'bad' choice. The balance of flavors--in the simple Margarita or the epically delicious Tartufo--is always on point. 

It seemed appropriate, then, to celebrate true love over a love of pizza. For our rehearsal dinner, Starr Catering (the BEST!) helped us come up with a delightful menu that made all our guests happy in this fun event space. The antipasti course was loaded with so many options, and served family style, that everyone nearly forgot to save room for the main attraction-the pizza, obviously! We went with the margarita for those who like to keep is simple, the spinach because it's amazing, and the tartufo for those willing to be adventurous. Lastly, our servers began bringing out all the flavors of gelato for everyone to sample. In short, nobody left hungry or thirsty and plenty of pizza was packed up to go back with the boys to enjoy later!

There is something that I love about the elegance and old school regal nature of steakhouses. The irony is that although I love steakhouses, I am not a big fan of steak. I went here with a friend for restaurant week and found the ambiance to be ok. The staff was cordial.

The wait staff took a little too long for my taste to come take our order but was very pleasant upon arrival. I had the Morton salad which was good. I then had the salmon (which I often get when going to steakhouses). The salmon was was good but the portion size was small (even for restaurant week). The dessert served was chocolate mousse or creme brulee. The problem with dessert was, I eat neither dessert and substitutions were not optional. 

This place is a nice quaint place to eat with coworkers, friends or family. As far as steakhouses are concerned, there are other places in the city of Philadelphia that I would recommend over Morton's.

We drove into the city to try Sauce on the Side and when we arrived, we found out they closed and moved ad wouldn't be open for a few days. So, since we already paid for an hour of parking, we decided to try another restaurant close by. We found Baileys Range and decided to give it a shot!

The atmosphere is hipster/casual. The decor is cool and the building is brick which adds character. What really caught my eye was the "community" table. A big long table that you can sit at with strangers. Awesome idea, but we opted for a table upstairs for 2. 

We were seated and a waitress brought us a couple pitchers of water right away. We looked over the menu and I was impressed by the amount of variety in the burgers. I also loved the idea of the burger battle. Basically every week 2 burgers battle and whichever one has the most ratings stays for another week. Very cool. I ordered the California Bison Burger and fries with the house ketchup and house cheddar cheese sauce. 

The burger was incredible. Very juicy and just the right amount of gamey taste. The cole slaw was perfect on top as was the pork shoulder. The beer bun was delicious! The fries were crispy and seasoned which was great. The cheddar sauce was very good. The house ketchup was unique. It was very cinnamonny (Yes I made that word up). 

The water was room temperature which was strange and the waitress wasn't overly friendly or personable. She was just kind of there to do her job, which was fine. Also, for $12 I expected the burger to be a little bigger. But it was cooked perfectly so there's not much to complain about. 

Overall this place is awesome! Definitely worth the stop in and we will be back for sure. I want to try a bunch of the burgers from the menu!

Last time trying Kaiseki was in Kyoto Japan and I enjoyed it tremendously. I was glad to find out that Yoichi's offers Kaiseki and I don't have to fly across the Pacific. As a fan of authentic Japanese traditional cuisine, I could not pass up on this opportunity. It was a great find during my visit in the lovely city of Santa Barbara.

There is definitely a difference when using all five senses of touch, smell, taste, sight, and hearing. The presentation and simplicity says plenty. The main ingredient of each dish were never overpowered but accentuated. Each course is presented with an introduction. 

The staff is friendly just like the service you get in Japan. The experience was unforgettable. Thank you Yoichi's!

In the words of a fellow yelper "Let me start by saying I REALLY don't like writing one star reviews.   I hate to look like that guy that only has negative things to say." - because SOME people work hard and take pride in what they do. And "Cookie" the manager went out of her way to try to make it right, but there was so much out of her control, she actually helped me get into another hotel.

I got in at midnight and it was too late for me to be moved... and the Front Desk was tired and non-commital. Musty was the least of the problems. Filthy was the BIGGEST ISSUE. Dry food on the carpet, filthy carpet, filthy bed platform and blood stains on the white bed comforter.  Rusted bathtub fixtures, moldy wall paper, smelly room... GROSS, and the worst HGI I've stayed at - and I love. The restaurant breakfast staff was LOVELY, however as was Cookie at the front desk - people are their asset. But people don't give you a clean nights sleep without the carpet grabbing the sole of your feet...

I love the ambiance first off!  The inside of the Grand Ole Opry Resort is such a treat.   We sat next to a waterfall and just soaked it in.

The food was also really good.  I had the french toast and my husband had a traditional eggs/bacon breakfast.  The french toast is made with banana bread, which gave it an interesting flavor.  I love french toast and eat it everywhere I go just to compare.  I can't say this was my absolute favorite, but it also wasn't boring.  I'd eat it again for sure!   Just to have something different.

Their fruit cup was fabulous - really fresh fruit! 

The eggs and bacon were also delightful.  My husband said it was some of the best bacon he has ever had!   

And the service was stellar!   I highly recommend.

We stopped by quickly for some after-dinner drinks before leaving Philly, though wished we had room to sample from their food menu (which looked amazing!).

Drinks-wise this place is a great option.  Mr Beffrey enjoyed his Women In Love, which had a grassy, herbal note with celery juice and basil. Interesting touch of cracked pepper on top.

Ms Beffrey really appreciated the separate Mocktails section, and the Spicy Pineapple was delicious. Couldn't actually taste any of the cayenne pepper (so maybe more appropriately label it just "Pineapple"?), but that didn't detract from the drink at all.

We will certainly be coming back to eat -- our eyes are on the Cucumber Gazpacho and the Bao Buns!

This place may be a very commercialized taco spot but it is dang tasty! My go tos are the fish (fried), shrimp (grilled) and carnitas (there's black beans on it, SOLD!) 
Discovered this little gem on a trip to the new target in the area and because I love tacos decided to make a trip in. 
It's got beach, sunshine, and corona with a lime vibes that come at a decent price, depending on what you choose. I usually round out around $12. Presentation is great whether you dine in or take out. 
This maybe a weird note, but the water from pop machine is CRISP and delicious and they have some specialty brand of pops. 
I give this place two thumbs up in a Philly sea of just okay taco joints! Not super authentic but the flavor is there. And that definitely counts. If you're close to Fairmount/Spring Garden drop in!

Nutts has such awesome things on their menu that I want to try it all! I mean a crab omelet, a chorizo omelet, famous fried chicken, fried pickles, buffalo pizza, Mexican pizza.....the description on all these items make them sound great. 

I've been her twice and was really not impressed with breakfast....I will continue to come and find what I love though, because lunch seems more like appealing to me. My hubby-to-be loves the pancakes and omelets though (especially the chorizo one).

My recommendation if you love spicy food:

Buffalo chicken pizza. SUPER spicy food that is....the buffalo chicken pizza will make a grown man cry. I normally like spicy food, and buffalo sauce is one of those things that varies so much in heat depending on the place. Well, this place definitely PACKS the heat! It came out of the kitchen bubbling with red sauce and I needed a milkshake to get past the first slice. 

If you are sharing an appetizer: 

Baked Junkyard fries - gross name, but sooo good! They have cheese, chorizo, melted cheese, sour cream and all sorts of amazingness! I think if I ever end up pregnant, this is what my fetus and I would constantly crave. 

I would skip:
Denver scramble. which sounds delicious with Sauteed Potatoes, Mushrooms, Onions and Peppers, Topped with Cheddar Cheese and 2 Scrambled Eggs...but it's not. The potatoes were not seasoned with any pepper or salt, and everything is just thrown together like a bad batch of hash browns. Also, it's a small portion compared to the other breakfast platters, so plan accordingly. 

I will definitely be returning to try their famous chicken, and the service is always friendly and just overall there is something very inviting about the place...especially their outside area in a cool summer day.

This salon is fantastic. I was greeted at the door and offered wine, coffee, water, someone's first born child. I said, "nah, I'm okay. I'm just here to get my hair did".

Enter Anthony, my delightful, darling and dapper stylist. Anthony has been a stylist for four years and working at Mariposa for over a year. He asked what I wanted my hair to look like, and started mixing color and telling me what conditioning treatment I would need. 

He settled on a double process with a conditioning treatment. He was so excited the whole time. "Your hair is going to be bananas!"

As a stylist, Anthony really takes a good deal of pride in his work. While working on me he still had time to run around and assist some of the younger stylists with their clients. He seriously seems to love his job.

Mariposa has a cool monitor in front of the mirror streaming popular Tweets and celebrity news and trivia (sort of like the monitors in taxis). The monitors also had a system where you entered all of your personal info about your hair. Curly/straight/colored/conditioned/products used, etc. This then allows the system to match you with the ideal product that you should use on your hair. Pretty cool.

Anthony was so fun and my time in the chair flew by. By the time he was finished I had a whole new look and all of the other stylists were complimenting him on his work.

Definitely will be going back soon!

We were at International Tap House and got hungry, so we ordered takeout from here and walked right down the street!

Oh, we feasted, and I mean FEASTED with the Old Joe's Platter: Full slab of ribs any 3 sandwiches plus 4 sides (if your mouth doesn't feel envious.. well, it should!)

- Ribs: fantasticc! Not the most tender, but still easy to get off the bone
- Sandwiches: We got the pulled pork, prime rib and beef brisket; the best one was the brisket by far. The other two were about tied, hah.
- Beans: I love their beans!! Not too sweet, not too heavy. yUmms
- Pork skin: we got it because we wanted to try it. Verdict? We don't like pork skins. But you could tell they were fresh (came hot) and it was really good-looking... we just don't like pork skins, hah
- Slaw: really good too, went well with my meat!
- Sauces: I think there were about 3. My favorite was the sweet but that's because I love sweet things, hehe. The table's least favorite was the one with the V on it.

I also want to point out that they pack up take-out REALLY well!! Everything was nicely packaged and separate and was very easy to just unwrap the goodness (I felt like a kid on Christmas day) and feast! Also, it only took TWENTY minutes!!!

Overall: BBQ is BBQ, but Bogart's does a darn good job. Save the line-standing at Pappy's and just come here :) Oh and get beer at iTap while you're at it ;)

This was our home away from home for the Christmas holiday, and we enjoyed our stay immensely. We paid extra for the deluxe king room, so there was room for more than just a bed, and we didn't feel crowded. Plus - bonus - our room actually had a view of the Mississippi River, and it was strangely addicting to just stand there and watch the barges and tugs go by. I also loved that there was a Keurig coffee maker in the room.

The hotel was beautifully decorated for the Christmas holiday, so there were always people hanging out in the lobby and bar just enjoying the scenery or taking pictures. This is a crowded time of year for New Orleans, and the Carousel Bar in the hotel was always packed, but fortunately we were able to belly up to the bar next to the hotel restaurant, and sample their specialty holiday cocktails.  We had Christmas lunch at Criollo Restaurant in the hotel, and it was surprisingly good-with the desserts being exceptional.

I do NOT think the staff is as professional as it is at other NOLA hotels we've stayed at: friends we were traveling with had constant issues with the staff and a scooter they rented, plus the doormen seemed to be more interested in chatting with each other than opening doors, saying hello, etc. Also, I think noise is a problem in all of these old hotels, and this one is no exception.  However, since we travel with a small speaker so we can sleep with white noise, this wasn't really an issue for us.

The location of the hotel is hard to beat, the elevators were surprisingly fast, and as a whole, we had a very good time here.

I just ate ice cream at 10 in the morning, and Mike made me do it!  

This quaint and cute, old-fashioned ice cream parlor hails back to the days when quality service mattered.  Each of their twenty-something ice cream flavors is "handmade" (although I'm not...quite sure what that means), and their frozen cappuccino is freshly composed each day, in house.  Pastries and touristy-treats are also available, although those are provided by outside vendors.  Service does take a little while, since each drink is made to order-- I guess you could say, "with love."  The ice cream is worth the wait, though!

Perhaps Mike knew that I was a tourist, or, perhaps I am just that cute *wink*, because I was served a scoop of Tennessee Fudge so generous that Texas would be jealous!  It was smooth and creamy, but not gluey, like some other gourmet ice creams can be.   I also sampled the Pistachio, Red Velvet, and Moose Tracks, which were also delicious.  

Yes, it was still so early in the morning that people were just barely arriving at work.  Didn't matter.  I was on vacation, and on vacation, what girl doesn't enjoy a fun and indulgent treat?

I used to work at this location and while I do love the Applebee's drink and food specials I do not feel terribly engaged . The staff is disinterested and rude most of the time. 

Fact is it's a chain and I'm not really into chains. Never have been. Never will be. But for the most part I don't mind coming in, throwing down a few dollars and enjoying friend's company.

I have been to this marvelous local food-haven three times now.

Once with my wife who loved it & once with my 3yr old who loved it.
And they sure do have different tastes in food, if the Depot has both of them covered, then you'll find something to love, too.

The fish and chips are my favorite here in Reno, and I have even directed visitors from out of town (my father) here for the fish and chips. Their review is here : http://www.yelp.com/biz/the-depot-craft-brewery-distillery-reno-2?hrid=IeHMc0rfRgaFGG9ob9JWUg

-=-

I recently attended a Yelp Sponsored event at the Depot, where I had a chance to try the _amazing_ burgers and fries that this place offers, and I can now heartily recommend the Depot Burger to any omnivore or carnivore.

These guys are pretty new, but already I am seriously loving this place.  It is a real gem of a coffee shop, and has serious charm, not to mention dynamite beverages.

They have an entrance through their building on Arlington, but the main cafe is actually located on Roff Way, which is almost more of a back alley, to be honest.  Now, when I say they are located in a tiny storefront, I mean just that.  Like, my office is bigger than their whole shop.  Walk right in, there is the counter on one side, a few stools along the street-side window, and some nice, simple decorations on the wall.  Simple, compact, and no-nonsense.

They roast their own beans, which come in several varieties in many levels of darkness, caffeine, and flavor profiles.  What really impresses me is that they individually grind the beans for YOUR own beverage, and then do a pour-over method with a neat contraption built into the counter.  I was also impressed with how quickly they have this down, as until now I've been accustomed to pour-over taking quite a bit longer to get a cup o' joe.  Most of their menu is standard coffee, intended to show off the different characters of the beans.  However, you will also find a scant few mixed cafe drinks as well.  I tried the Bullet Proof, which I found phenomenal!  In addition to very nice coffee, it includes ghee, MCT oil, and brown sugar, all frothed in a blender to give a very rich, not overly sweet, and amazingly energizing brew.  Very unique and inventive concoction, to be sure.

To round things out, there are a few bottles of iced teas and mineral water available, but also be aware that it does not appear as if they serve any food or snacks here.  You can also buy bags of their coffee, whole bean or ground, and enjoy their product at home.  Price-wise you are looking at maybe $5 or so for the mixed drinks, and a buck or two less for regular coffee.  So a bit pricey for individual cups, but you get amazing quality.

Service here was exceptionally friendly and helpful, and as stated above, very prompt in how they make this style of coffee.  They are pretty easy to find, even for how they are sort of tucked out of the way.  There is plenty of street parking in the surrounding neighborhoods, and you could easily walk over from anywhere in the Riverwalk district.  And outside, they have a really lovely seating area that I look forward to enjoying during the warmer months.

All in all, Reno Coffee Company is a sort of place I wish more coffee shops were like.  They have their craft down, and want nothing to detract from that.  I think this chic, tiny space is really cool, and will certainly be stopping by again whenever I'm down by the river.  Cheers!

We had tried another of the coffee places in Santa Barbara the day before and it wasn't bad. But husband wanted to try the other place on my list (Handlebar - because yes, I made a list of coffee places ahead of time. We live in Seattle, after all, coffee is kind of a thing) we decided to try it and wound up liking Handlebar SO much more. 

Confession: When I first saw the name "handlebar" weeks before our trip, it wasn't until we walked into the place and I saw bikes hanging on the wall. I thought, "Why do they have bikes in here?" and then *face palm* Ooooooooh.... BIKE handlebars. Dork that I am, *I* somehow got it into my head that there was some sort of western theme and thought it was something to do with mustaches. Yeah. (Like, handlebar mustache? It could happen. Coffee places like to be clever.)  Husband was thrilled - he loves bicycling so this was right up his alley. 

(Another side note: this is where we realized how big the casual/commuter bicycling scene is in Santa Barbara. There were so many bikes parked outside, husband loved it. I am not a cyclist but I appreciated the laidback, fun vibe as opposed to all the competitive, holier-than-thou bike scene here in the Seattle area. BUT I DIGRESS.)

Handlebar Coffee! We liked it so much we went back a couple of times. The place had great atmosphere and was unassuming - it wasn't right smack in the middle of downtown so it was a little quieter though still busy. Nice, simple outdoor seating area. I dig the scene here. The staff was nice and the small selection of pastries they had was good. Husband got a drip and I got a latte, both excellent. We love SB and plan on going back as often as we can - Handlebar will be our go-to coffee place every time.

I was going to give this place 3 stars because it's kinda small/awkward crowded for a brewery, the tour is OK not amazing compared to other Brewery Tours I've been on, and I only like one of their beers.
But then I remembered one key point: I don't like beer. 

I've spent 10 years trying to like beer and have resigned to be a sexy cocktail femme fatale instead of the cool down to earth beer chick. Which sucks, because being sexy does not come as naturally as the dirt under my nails. Buuuut the reason why I love this place is because of the Yards Brawler. Before Yards Brawler I was doing shameful things like ordering Snakebite and Bloody Ho's (beers mixed with framboise) and getting MOCKED for it. Now, The Brawler is my go-to order. My friend and I got the sampler pack a couple of years ago when we were young and experimental and it's like finding your favorite pair of jeans that never stretch out. You feel comfortable ordering it and people don't mock you-- in fact they mistake you for liking beer and being the cool down to earth beer chick.

Also this review is for the COMPANY which rocks a solid A in my books. They do so many things for the Philadelphia community (and beyond) that I love them. I mean this is the site where I've been to the MOST fundraisers oddly enough. haha! Love it!

PNever in my life did I think I'd be eating at another fast food joint other than In N Out. 

My friend kept on raving about Chik fil A and now I understand why. It's just so fresh, delicious, and guilt free. 

One day I passed by and saw a loooong drive through line and decided to jump on the band wagon. 

I was surprised at how fast they were handling business. Pretty impressive being that they just opened. On top of that, every worker I've encountered has been nothing but nice and well informed. 

My favorite sandwich is the #2  spicy deluxe sandwich with Chick fil A sauce. It's so spicy, but in a good way. Eating the juicy spicy chicken patty along with the buns, cheese, tomato, lettuce and sauce is just the best. Everything is incredibly well balanced. 
I mistakenly ordered the regular spicy chicken sandwich without cheese, lettuce and tomato one day and it wasn't nearly as good. 

I was surprised at how fresh the chicken was. I could see the moisture after taking a bite out of it, just as when I cook chicken at home fresh from the market.

Chick fil A must have the healthiest, tastiest and smartest kid's meals on the planet. The nuggets are fresh and delicious just like their sandwiches. For sides they have great options- applesauce or a fresh fruit cup. Their fruit cup was legit. It had mandarin oranges, blueberries, strawberries and apples and everything was so fresh. I also love their drink options-milk or organic juice. To top things off, they include a fun educational toy such as I spy booklets or pop out assemble yourself animals. Doesn't get any better than that. Finally a fast food place this mom approves of. 

Did I mention that they have the best milk shakes ever? I never order milk shakes but they turned me around all right. Seems like they use real ice cream and fresh milk. Their Oreo and vanilla milk shakes are so delicious and refreshing. They use fresh crunchy cookies and  actual vanilla flavor. The thickness and cool mouth feel is just right too. They top them off with whipped cream and a maraschino cherry. 

Try all of their sauces!!!! Sooooooo good. The combinations are endless. I like the Chick fil A sauce the most but also like combining the ranch with the zesty buffalo.

I've been here more times than I can count because I'm truly addicted. I talked to many workers at every location I go to and all of them swear by Chick fil A, eating here while they're working and even when they're off the clock. That says a lot.

Oh Wawa, I love you after 12:00AM.  Anyway, I often frequent here after long nights of adult beverages and tales of yonder and the staff is always friendly to a accommodate my self needs and drunken self whether it is sizzlis at 2 in the morning or the weirdest hoagie you can think of.  Thank you Wawa.

LOVED THIS PLACE. 

Mushroom caps were phenomenal- the raspberry & goat cheese didn't really go well with the fried mushroom flavor, but the chocolate BBQ mushroom tasted awesome. Date & plum mushroom would be a great dessert option alone. The peach/mango was the best out of the 4.

Best friend had their chicken caesar salad (was kind of deconstructed) & had the best best pita slices I've ever had to go alongside.  

I had the ratatouille which surprised me when it was served on bread like a thincrust pizza, tasty though. My side was super fresh-tasting couscous with chunks of avocado (reminded me of summer & not the crappy weather we have now).

The cute waiter added to the great service we had. 

Will definitely try to come back once it's a little warmer out.

Tried it for the first time on a Saturday and was promptly back there two more times over the next five days. And I don't even live in the city!

I am so excited that there is an establishment in Philly that is a cross between In-N-Out and Bobby's Burger Palace for Vegans! But you really do not have to be Vegan to love the food.

Here's what I have tried so far:

Udon Noodle Salad: Classic tasty Asian salad with Vegan chicken. Really nice taste if a bit overdressed.

Curry Tofu Wrap: I had this for lunch the day after I bought it. Still was delicious. I'm surprised there was such a great Indian taste on this menu. 

Ziggy Burger: Get this! And order extra special sauce. My new favorite burger!

Crispy HipCity Ranch: Good Italian "chicken" sandwich. Not as awesome as the Ziggy.

Sweet Potato Fries with cilantro black bean dip: my new favorite Philly fries. Sorry European Republic! Still love you but this great dip is Vegan!

My wife and I have also had the chocolate chip cookies which are quite good.

One negative: they have no customer bathroom. According to the very friendly people at the counter it is because they are not zoned for one.

Philly's Veg/Vegan scene was struggling compared to New York's. Thank goodness HipCity Veg opened to help close the gap.

I was a bit bummed when Phat Bites moved to a new location, but I am pretty sure it's the same distance away from me, so no big loss! However, I drove past it the first time I visited, so keep your eyes peeled. It shares the same space as some nondescript business. 

I'm glad that the space is a lot bigger and they now have plenty of parking, even at peak times. The food, menu, and staff are the same. I came in for lunch a few times recently, and if you go early, you are golden. Anywhere between 11-12:00 you are fine. However, I stopped in around 12:30 and the line was long and order taking a bit annoying. I also waited about 15 minutes for my order, so it's not the quickest lunch option out there. When ordering take out, I like for it to be pretty quick, but expect to be at Phat Bites for at least 30 minutes at peak times. 

I still love the black bean burger that they offer. It's the best one I've had. I also have ordered a few sides. The kale salad is always great, and the hummus is out of this world! Phat Bites is amazing, so check them out!

On a bright and sunny Wednesday afternoon, I decided to visit Tuesday Morning. I have seen this sign so many times before in other places but have never really thought about what the store sells. Really, this store is all about everything and anything! I walked in and it was like an adventure. I would compare it to Home Goods but it is smaller and not stocked as well. They do have certain sections which were abundantly stocked today: towels/bath section and the pillows. There were stacks of different pillows and they have even categorized them according to size (standard, queen, etc). Unfortunately, they were all firm and extra firm. I have been thinking about getting a new pillow for my dog but I believe she prefers the soft kind. I bought her a firm one once and she didn't use it as much as the softer pillow.

Even though the pillow was a bust, I ended up finding 2 nice, soft bath towels on clearance! They have stickers on their clearanced items which denotes the percentage off of "Tuesday Morning's" already discounted price tag.  The towels had the purple sticker which was a 20% off the price tag. I was happy! They were already cheap to begin with. I also found a bottle of body wash for $5.99 with a pink sticker (60% off I believe but I could be wrong) so that was awesome! Can't ever have too many bath/shower things stocked up for rainy days or that dreaded zombie apocalypse.

The store is not the most organized but I guess I didn't expect it to be. I did read their website before coming in and so I sort of knew what to expect as far as the organization would go.  I could tell though, the staff try their best to keep things in order. 

The staff were very nice and very helpful.  While at the clearance area, I started looking at a pillow at the very top of the shelf and an associate offered to take it down for me. I saw the label on the side read "Firm" so I didn't bother and thanked her anyway.  The associate at the counter was very pleasant as well and asked how my new year is going. What a bunch of lovely people! I will be back.

I'd only been for pho twice in my life before checking out this Pho Hoa the other day. For some reason I was mega craving pho over the weekend, so my lovely friend Dianne took me out for some on Monday night. 

The place wasn't very busy around 6:30pm. The service was quick - tea came out right away and was refilled quickly when needed, and our food also came out very fast.

I didn't even look at the entire menu, but skipped right ahead to the pho page. It's cutely split into three categories: pho for beginners, just the regular, and the adventurers' choice. At this point I think the only two things I'm not ready to try are tripe and tendon, so I got the Ph Tái Nm off of the "regular" menu - round eye steak and well-done flank. You can get your pho in one of two sizes, regular or large. I got the regular (I think around $7.50) and it was still huge! I couldn't finish the whole thing. There was a ton of meat in there - too much for me, I had to leave some. The broth was so flavourful and kind of sweet and yum. I'm not a pho expert, so it's hard for me to describe the flavours, but I loved it. So good, hot and fresh. I've been craving pho ever since. 

Pho.

I decided to take an afternoon to explore Marathon Village and happened upon this lovely little coffee shop that looks exactly like the name would suggest: that you're having coffee in someone's garage while they change your oil, except the coffee here is incredible.  They have a particular treat served in a shot glass that combines espresso, caramel, and salt, and it will absolutely wake you up.  You can buy their signature blend, affectionately named Road Rage, while in the small shop.  They also serve up some snacks if you need a pick-me-up while shopping about the many adorable shops in Marathon.  It was without a doubt some of the best coffee I have ever had.  I would not recommend this as a coffee house for sitting and doing homework, as its too small, but I would recommend picking up a cup from here on your way to run errands.  You will have the most productive day ever hyped up on this incredibleness.

I really wouldn't recommend this place based on dining experience. First of all, I don't think there's an interior layout in this city, that I've seen, that I hate more than this place. It's seriously maze-like inside. Upon entrance, you'll see a typical large wrap-around bar. Behind that bar, there's a dining area, off to the right - there's a larger dining area split into two. It's just a hot mess of confusion and it doesn't matter anyway because it's not like this place is ever filled to capacity.

Now onto the food, honestly - for a person who really doesn't care too much for Mex or Tex-Mex - the food, from what I've had has been pretty good. But, all in all - this place is more or less a Tex-Mex Dive Bar. Take that how you will.

My majority of visits to this place has been for sports viewing, which has been great. There's plenty of TVs around.

Wing lovers take note: they do them well here. Their offerings are definitely not buffalo wings but what they call "Texas Ranchero" - which is basically a light BBQ sauce with a hint of spice, served with a side of ranch. The taste is a little sweet more than anything else. I find them quite delicious and they're often on special during sports games: 1lb (was 2lb) of wings and a pitcher of domestic beer for $12

This is pretty much just a chill, neighborhood bar with Tex-Mex offerings with drink specials. Don't go here for mind-melting dining experience.

I'd definitely say it's worth making a first-time trip, but I'm not sure I'd come again unless it was to try brunch or hang out on the outdoor portion of the restaurant. I love the concept of eating on a boat; eating is one of the most enjoyable and frequent activities that I engage in, and it's fun to switch up the atmosphere a little bit every once in awhile. 

That being said, the boat was hauntingly quiet, kind of dark, and just generally somber on the evening that my boyfriend and I dined here. I can't speak to whether or not this is the norm, as it was a frigid Tuesday night in the middle of winter. 

Drinks were good, the St. James Lemonade was bomb. 

Food was definitely a little above average, but expensive. I'd definitely recommend scooping a Living Social deal if you see one.

We shared:

-Crab mac n' cheese
-Philadelphia roll
-Brussels sprouts
-Braised short rib gnocchi

The portions weren't huge, but we ended up having to take home a small box of mac and a few pieces of sushi because we were full. Everything was good, but the mac and sprouts were my favorites.

It happened to be my birthday, and our (really friendly & helpful) waitress brought out a complimentary scoop of sorbet with a candle in it at the end of the meal. 

Overall, it was a nice, quiet evening with solid food, but you're definitely paying a premium to be eating on the river.

I've heard tons of good things about Prep & Pastry, so when my fiance and I drove by last Sunday morning, I suggested we stop for brunch.

When we walked in, the hostess said it would be about a 45 minute wait, but she wasn't sure since some people had left without telling her. Looking around the restaurant, there were quiet a few empty tables, and there didn't seem to be too many people waiting, so I was slightly confused. But since we weren't in a rush or grungry (the anger of being overly hungry), we decided to wait.

Luckily, we had only been sitting outside for about 15 minutes when our name was called. The interior is super cute! I really liked the high ceilings and how bright the restaurant was. It was definitely the perfect atmosphere for a lazy Sunday brunch.

After much deliberation, we finally made our decisions and ordered.  I ordered the breakfast poutine and my fiance had the chx + toast (fried chicken strips, rosemary brioche french toast, and a blueberry syrup). My poutine was just okay. It was a solid portion, but kind of bland, and I definitely didn't see any cheese curds. On the other hand, my fiance loved his dish! I thought the different components sounded weird on paper, but once I had a bite, I was sold! The chicken was flavorful, and the rosemary french toast was the perfect savory accompaniment, but I do wish it was a little less soggy. However, I did think the chicken was on the dry side.

Although we didn't have room to sample their pastries, they all looked amazing. I will definitely be trying one on my next visit.

I think overall, I would give Prep & Pastry 3.5 stars, but I'm rounding it up to 4 since I think I would be happier if I got a different dish next time. Also, I don't think the wait would be so bad on most weekends, but the Sunday we went was super windy, so I don't think many people wanted to sit outside.

Okay sushi. Very friendly service. The restaurant itself was well decorated and clean.  

Followed the yelp reviews here expecting the best sushi in the area, but was a little disappointed.  The price and portions are fair, but the execution was middling.  Went there twice this week just to be sure. On my first visit I ordered Miyazaki, Osaka and Green dragon.  Then on my 2nd visit Pink lady, Monster roll and Pacific Blue.  The issue is that they rely too much on cheap flavoring like spicy mayo and eel sauce which smothered my Monster and Pacific rolls. They also overuse frying and cream cheese.  Their sushi dishes seem to lack freshness and balance.

I still give them a 4 for having a great atmosphere and great customer service.  I think it's a great place to introduce sushi to someone, but veteran sushi lovers may be more cynical.

Nice employees, very helpful when asked about menu items through drive through. 

Very high quality chicken and they pride themselves on that. Their sauces are made in house, my favorite is the creamy garlic!

Sweet potato fries are also really good for a fast food restaurant, love that spiced marshmallow dip. It is "spiced" as in a warm, fall "spiced", not the taste of spicy.

Only complaint is my Pumpkin Spice Milkshake, which is amazing, had PLENTY of strawberry pulp in it. I'm not sure how the milkshakes are made but I'd assume the machine is not regular cleaned after the previous shake is made... I am glad I am not allergic and only simple dislike strawberry seeds/pulp (or pulp of any sort), but honestly wasted my money because I did not drink it all because of the pulp present. Which is the reason for four stars.

I wanted to update my review because I stopped in last night, and really had a great experience. The staff was really friendly, and allowed me to taste ALL of their beer (I guess they will do this as long as they aren't too busy). I'm glad I was able to sample all of them, because I found a few varieties that I loved.

They didn't have DFG (which is my one of my favorite beers available at Bier and also just overall in Indy), but they did have an IPA I hadn't tried before called Bubonic Chronic. It was pretty tasty and I drank a pint to kill some time before dinner. I also loved their Pumpkin Porter and Pumpkin Ale, and brought home a bullet of the Pumpkin Ale to go.

They had live music, and a chill vibe. Most of the people in the tap room were between 30 - 50 years old, which lends a different atmosphere to some of the other breweries in Indy.

I did breakfast here - I think it is the same Copelands that we had in Dallas where I fell in love with it.  The Breakfast biscuit was good, it was a knife and fork sort of thing, it wasn't a pick it up with your hands thing which caught me off guard, but I got into right away.    Service was friendly but slow but the food seemed to come out fast.  The Food was tasty :)

Dear Jed's, 
You are a sports bar. It says so in your name. So why did you have the CMA's on the big screen playing out loud when I wanted to watch the Predators game? You switched it to the hockey game once the awards were over, but until then I had to read closed captioned commentary on the smaller TV while listening to Taylor Swift make some sort of dying animal noises into a microphone.  
Your food was really good (great fries & sliders), beer selection was good, and I love that it's 2 for 1 on Wednesday night, but I'm still a little mad at you. 
I'll be back, but please don't pull that crap again.

Sincerely, 
Hockey Fan

These are incredibly smart business people. About a week before they opened, they dropped off generous samples of the original chicken salad to nearby businesses. And that's how you make friends, people! The chicken salad was delicious. 

I finally had a chance to try out lunch. I went with the Olivia on a croissant with pimento cheese. Cuz why not?? I love pimento cheese. I prefer mine a little creamier and pimento-ier, but that's just my preference. It's really good stuff. Lunch was a bargain-sandwich, a scoop, a pickle and a cookie for about $8.  I'm looking forward to making my way through the list of flavors! 

The staff was friendly and helpful. Download the app for rewards!

After researching authentic German restaurants, I chose Brauhaus Schmitz to take my step-mom to. She is from Germany and over the holidays I wanted to bring a little bit of home to her. First, we found amazing parking on South St, nothing to do with the review, but certainly a nice way to start the night. We decided to have a coupe drinks at the bar before dinner.
