I also love that they have a condiment caddy at the window stacked with 3 free kinds of peppers: sliced jalapeños, whole pepperoncinis, and tiny whole mexihots that are full of heat and make you sweat. Those little addictive add-ons are awesome!

The menu is a bit more expanded than a typical burger chain too since they have a Santa Barbara Burger (Sourdough plus avocado...really fantastic!) and also things like chicken sandwiches, Ahi tuna sandwich, Tri-tip sandwich, and a veggie burger(!) which almost seems blasphemous at a burger joint. No one around me ordered those things so I can't really vouch for any of them. And seriously, if you come to The Habit and order a veggie burger you probably deserve to be choked out and put in the back dumpster while waiting for your order. 

Don't miss this little gem of a burger stand if you are in the area. There is a small parking lot in the rear which is a pro tip recommendation as parking is tough to find on the street. And don't miss those hot peppers. Nothing completes the foodie look more than to have rivulets of sweat and burger juice running down your face while seated under the awning of a 1969 original.

Did a summer brew bus and this was on route. I love going to a family friendly joint that serves craft beer. I know what your thinking, why bring a kid to a bar?  Well, I don't know the answer to that, but I find that when I'm hanging with the kids and can enjoy a few libations. I have a much better time. Add a few games for the kids to enjoy as well and it's a win win for everyone.  

I don't think this is intended to be a family place. There is smokers , music, alcohol and old fashioned games. So don't you all go running over with your kids thinking this place is meant for that. But I did see a few parents in there enjoying some adulting with their kids hanging around.

Back in the Day Books is a store for readers. I found an interesting mix of new bestsellers and vintage books. A section for vintage pulp fiction and children's picture books. I love visiting this store. I can't wait to return.

Stopped in here with my mom for a quick dinner when we noticed it was sort of on the way towards I-95.  It was very clean inside, and you can see the food being cooked up fresh.  I went with a shrimp burrito and a fish taco.  I just wanted to try the fish taco because sometimes its super fried, but this one was lightly pan fried.  It was really good, next time I would definitely get more fish tacos.  The shrimp burrito was huge and also really good.  My mom got a variety of enchiladas, and we really loved the sauce.  We shared some chips and salsa and guacamole.  The salsa was only ok, and the guac had a lot of lime in it, but it was like $3 so I'm not really complaining.  

I'll definitely be going back when I'm up that way.

We spend a day in St. Louis and everyone had a recommendation of where to get barbecue.  Salt and Smoke was near our hotel so we went for dinner.  The space is really nice and the bar has a huge selection of bourbons.  Our server was really helpful and we both got plates.  Food comes out fast and we loved the burnt ends, pulled pork, and the ribs.  The ribs were my favorite and they absolutely fall off 

Earlier in the day, our Lyft driver said that the mac and cheese here is so good he is prepared to start a religion around it.  Needless to say, we each got an order and it delivered!  So creamy and the Ritz topping is so buttery.  My only disappointment is that that the potatoes in the potato salad were undercooked and hard.  Otherwise a fantastic experience!

I am a sucker for Middle-eastern and Mediterranean food! The combo of grilled meats, flavorful rice, and fresh herbs and salads pretty much always knocks my appetite out cold! Well...consider me KO'd cuz Taziki's hit the SPOT! 

My go-to is the grilled chicken feast. Perfectly grilled chicken, savory basmati rice, and a crisp and fresh Greek salad! I also love their Taziki sauce so much I usually ask for an extra! I liked it so much that I hired them to cater my next office lunch and they where fantastic to work with! The only downside was there weren't any leftovers!

It's historic, it's lovely.  Sound is pretty good... well, it's improved over the years.  My only gripe is the women's restroom down all those steps... in heels, boy oh boy you gotta be careful.  Otherwise, I've always enjoyed the fox.  The cocktails at $8.50 are a pretty good deal.

Back again on a later visit, this time for lunch. The Wilted Green Salad sounded kind of ambitious but I was totally pleased with it. I love this place! Such interesting combos of flavors and I appreciate that it's locally sourced and super fresh. I always want to sit on that delightful patio but I think as a visiting Midwesterner I need to go in December so I don't fry in that intense sun. Inside is lovely but a bit loud. So what. I adore that food and I'm glad that I can go back to a place a year later and it's still as good as ever.

Love this place! 
Meschiya Lake & Tom McDermott on a Wednesday night is a must see gig!
The pizza is top notch too.
Say hi to Dale the owner, & be prepared to chat & hear some stories........!

Stopped in for lunch on a Friday and loved it. It wasn't very crowded, but we sat at the bar. I ordered a house margarita, and it was huge and tasty. We also loved their chips and salsa fresca. For lunch, we ordered the Tlayuda de Chorizo and the grilled shrimp tacos. The tacos were amazing. I wasn't sure what to expect of the tlayuda, but it was wonderful. It was almost like a thin crust pizza, but the "crust" was actually a really crisp fried flour tortilla, and chorizo and other toppings play well together. Delicious!

Nice breakfast place. Good value, but It is far from exceptional (5 stars) or amazing (4 stars) !! 
I liked my omelette, my friend liked his eggs over easy, we both really enjoyed the hash browns, crispy on top and quite tasty!! 
The disappointment were "the pancakes"! 
They were fluffy and just too much like cake! If that's how you enjoy your pancakes ... great! I like my pancakes w/a crispy edge ( like at Gilchrist's !! ) ALSO although our very lovely waitstaff said the maple syrup was "real" maple syrup... my tastebuds beg to differ! 
All in all it was a good experience! All servers were attentive and people here are happy enjoying their morning meals!

Stopped here when I was shopping over the weekend for a yummy hot chocolate and a latte. Expensive, the same price as Starbucks - maybe more because the sizes are smaller here. Nothing to write home about. I'm sure some people love it but it wasn't what we were looking for. It was a nice little storefront to sit in.

Crown and Bull has the ambience, the deals, and the quality food! It's super lively at night and a great setting for drinks with fire pits and live music. The brunch is really where it's at though, there's always a table even though it's a crowd favorite in Dunedin. 

Top recommendations for brunch:
Man-mosa $5
Mimosa $3
Bloody Mary Bar $7
Love the eggs Benedict with grits!

I want to preface this review that I lived here for two years, from 2010-2012. I only know of how Lenox was up until May 2012 & that things may have changed for the better, or for the worse. 

I lived in a two bedroom, two bath, patio unit that listed for "$1,400" but the new move-in special was $1,035. A great deal for a brand new unit. The unit itself had a stack washer & dryer, large kitchen appliances & huge closets. When I mean, huge, I mean HUGE. I'd almost wished the closets were a little smaller & the bedrooms themselves were larger. The master bath had a large, oval tub/shower. The laminate hard wood floor in the kitchen was nice but it showed foot prints very easily. Overall, I enjoyed the unit, even if the patio overlooked the parking garage. 

To enter the residential part of the building, you must use a RFID card or use the phone directory to look up the resident & then call their number & they can buzz you in. I enjoyed this system & I always felt safe. Each entrance door had a camera on it. 

A few things I did not like about Lenox Village was the people with pets, mainly dogs. I love animals, I've got two cats myself. However, I don't like when people take their dog to the stairwell & let the animal pee all over the place. My last year at Lenox, there was an issue with people bring their dogs to the stairwell and letting them do their business. Management knew about it & put up signs that pretty much said whoever snitched on the culprit would get a gift card or something. 

I wanted to put a camera up in the stairwell but that would cost a lot & would require some effort, so instead, I would just bitch about it every time I'd use the stairs. Why not use the elevator, you ask? Well it usually was on the opposite floor & I was only going up or down two flights of stairs, "Keep Moving" as the First Lady says. 

The trash room with the trash chute always was a mess & smelled. I don't know if people just carried their trash in their hands & threw it on the floor for a reason or what. I put my trash in a bag, tie the top & put it down the chute. 

Each apartment gets one (1) numbered, reserved parking spot. One (1), not two (2). This usually wasn't an issue, as there was two levels of "two hour parking" that was never monitored. I saw one car parked in the same "two hour parking" spot for months & nothing happened. 

As you're probably aware, the apartments are over different businesses. Our unit was over top of a sports bar. The patrons of the bar weren't loud, it was the employees that, like clockwork, every night at 1am would LOUDLY dump glass beer bottles into a metal trash can. I think they did it one at a time. At least I knew when I woke up from a sound sleep that it was 1am. 

Lastly, the reason we moved from Lenox was that every year the price would go up. Not by a few bucks but by a hundred. The first year was $1,035. The next year it raised to $1,125. The third year they wanted to raise it to $1,250. I understand that Lenox Village & RAM Partners (the company that owns Lenox) needs to make money, but I kind of feel that it's a slap in the face to keep charging more & more each year to people who are living in the unit, making you money. 

They ask for 2 months notice of you're going to renew or not, we told them no & they didn't seem to care. I would think it would matter to them however, because in the months leading up to us moving out, they were running promotions that if you got someone to move in you would get a referral. I was in the area around 4 months after we moved & noticed the unit was empty through the windows visible from the parking garage. 

Overall, I give the Lenox Village town center apartments 4 stars. That 4 star rating is at the $1,035 price. I would give it a 3 if it was the $1,250 price & I probably wouldn't live there for $1,400 a month.

We had lunch on Fat Tuesday at Baileys' Range and were totally surprised. I have drug my feet coming here due to the mixed reviews and now regret that I didn't come sooner.  Not only did BR amaze us with burgers, but their wings, chili and fries were equally as good. 

Our feast at Bailey's begun with Smoked Pablano Chicken Wings and a Cup of Chili. We enjoyed the wings, they provided a different twist to the traditional "hot" wings and the chili was kick ass. The chili had a spice that provided a good kick that we could not name, but loved it just the same. It was topped with melted cheese and croutons. Croutons are a nice upgrade from oyster crackers and add an additional flavor. 

To test a new burger restaurant, we figured it was best to try the "basic" burger. If they can not do a basic burger, how will they be able to do the "specialty" burgers. They nailed it! Our burgers were juicy, cooked to our specifications and served with all the toppings. Bailey's doesn't stop at a good burger, they put it on a house made bun, that can rival some bakery buns. 

We shared a small order of fries and I can tell you a small is enough to satisfy two. Their fries are house cut, no frozen pre-cut fries at BR. As our sauce we choose "crazy catsup", which I wish could be bought to take home. I love the way they serve their catsup, in the small mason jars. I recently have become a big fan of places that provide catsup in small cups instead of nasty bottles. 

A visit to Bailey's Range would not be complete without having a shake. Again, we went with the a traditional shake instead of one their now famous "boozy shakes". 
I had my favorite flavor, strawberry and Brad got creative and mixed vanilla ice cream with blueberry sorbet. They said, they have not had anyone mix ice cream and sorbet before. His creation was fantastic, he joked that he is glad we do not live in a loft downtown, because he would have one everyday. The shakes were better then a specialty parlor down on Locust. 

Our waitress was friendly and provided great service. I will be honest, the reason they did not get a five is fault of the kitchen. All the food was excellent, but we had just received our wings and chili when another server approached with our burgers. Next time, we will hold back and not order burgers until we are finished enjoying our appetizers. However, they took ownership of the error and without complaining they made it right by treating us to our shakes and removing them from our bill. 

Bailey's Range, I'll be back. You gave me good service, good food and I like that your carryout vessels are eco-friendly.

Five Guys is the chain that started my quest for the best burger in St. Louis.  It's not really a quest so much as a compulsive need to order burgers wherever I go to find one that could potentially beat the Five Guys burger experience.  

My first encounter with Five Guys was at their Town and Country location.  I fell in love and couldn't have been happier to find new locations in St. Charles and Florissant, which seem to be my stomping grounds between work and home.  

Just a few tips for folks new to the Five Guys Experience:

The fries are cooked in peanut oil, so take your Epipen if you have allergies.  Note, I did not say avoid at all costs, just take the damn Epipen!  (it's worth it, I promise!)  

The menu isn't clear enough for some people.  If you order a regular burger, expect to get a huge burger with 2 patties and all your toppings.  If you are a light weight, order the Little Burger.  You will get one patty instead of two.

Last but not least, order the regular fries.  A large fry here is ridiculous, and is more than enough for two or even three people.  The regular order will get you a cup of fries in your bag, and then another cup dumped on top of your order.  It's not a joke.  They dump them right in the bag once everything else is in there.

The last tip is to eat slowly.  Those fries will be hot!

SO GOOD!  Is it all about the buffet and menu?  No!  It's all about the Mongolian BBQ.  You walk in, see the chef in his glass case of emotion.  Surrounding his case are delicious goodies, or gifts, for us to make om nomz out of.  You may need to try a few different concoctions before you score a winner and fall in love for yourself.  My bad boy: noodles, beef, broccoli, sprouts, and of course 2 scoops of garlic, 1 scoop of Mongolian BBQ sauce, 1 scoop of chili oil, and 1-2 scoops of chili sauce.  I like my goodies spicy!  

So I have my goods in a bowl, put it on the counter near the window so Mr. Chef can throw the ingredients onto his holy canvas.  He works his magic and voila!  I'm ready to go to town.  

Never have I been disappointed with Mongolian BBQ.  I've tried their buffet items and they are disgusting.  Don't waste your time filling your plate with food that has been sitting under a heat lamp, find true love over on the Mongolian BBQ side.

This Japanese ramen house is probably the best I've had in Philly. Not quite as good as LA's Japanese ramen, but pretty damn close. My wife and I went here last weekend for lunch. We started with the seaweed salad and octopus balls. Both dishes were fantastic! For the mains, I had the pork broth ramen (tonkotsu) and loved it. My wife had one of the curry and rice dishes and thought that it was okay (I tried it and really liked it though). Overall, great food and atmosphere, and not too pricy. Definitely going to come back to try some of the other stuff!

Absolutely the best ice around! It's as soft as snow! I like the idea of their souvenir cups as a great reminder to go back!
I tried the cream of chocolate with cream of ice cream. This decadent combo did not disappoint.  For my man, I got cream of coconut which was recommended by patrons in line.  Even my pup got her own.....just the ice! We all loved it and will be back
The selection of flavors is not as huge as some other places I like, but they all sounded amazing!
Go for the "cream of" flavors! 
I'm told that there is always a line, so get ready to wait a bit!

This hotel is awesome! I have loved staying here because your room comes with wifi, breakfast, and dinner. The rooms are really clean, with a microwave and a refrigerator. It is close enough to the French Quarter so you can participate in the festivities that New Orleans have to offer. I really wish the food was a little bit better, but I can't complain since it comes with the room. Also, if you forget something like a razor or a toothbrush, they offer those things in the lobby free of charge. I would definitely stay in this hotel again.

I will definitely be back for a coffee or date or study session. 

I ordered the potted cap green tea. Although the tea wasn't as hot as I would like it, the flavor was sooo good. Also ordered a Tomi Toast, which was a little too sweet for my liking but still worth trying! 

This place reminds me of the Alice in wonderland restaurant in Japan, from the decor to the menu; loved it!

Boucherie is amazing.  It's a little place where parking is questionable but don't let that deter you from coming here.  I met up with a small group of friends for lunch here.

We sat down, got our drinks and food ordered and we're chatting away and our nice waiter gives us each a shot of basil tomato soup to try!  They were so cute!  The soup was very good and we appreciated the taste.

Let me tell you, the garlic, Parmesan french fries are simply perfect!  I love cheese fries in general but Boucherie takes these fries to another level.  I couldn't stop eating them.  We had ordered a small plate of them as an appetizer and I was ecstatic to know that my husband got the beef brisket which came with more fries as a side!

I got the potato pierogies with greens and caramelized onions and they were really tasty.  Very nicely cooked and pierogies went really well with the onions.  

I couldn't help but steal my husband's fries.  I traded him a pierogi for a piece of brisket and that was very nicely cooked as well!  Very tender and the sauce was brilliant.

So to be honest, I would come back here for the garlic, Parmesan fries and I would be perfectly happy.  OH!  I almost forgot to mention for dessert we got the bacon brownie!  That was also amazing.  Moist and soft chocolate brownie with a hint of bacon which also came a scoop of vanilla ice cream.  

I highly recommend this place.

I came here with my family to celebrate my birthday. (They provided a dessert which was delicious). We all had burgers, and loved them. They have interesting toppings on the burgers which you won't find everywhere. Pricing is fair, especially for the location. Would definitely come back!

I should review Funky 544 in the context of Bourbon Street shit-bars (in which case about 4 stars), but I'm not going to do that. This place embodies all I hate about Bourbon Street. Shot girls, over-priced drinks, bands combing the crowd for more tips and getting in your face when you refuse, shitty bartenders, and a sea of douchebags - if you love these things, this is your spot! I went here the other night for what was supposed to be a closing party for a comedy festival. We were supposed to get the upstairs blocked off for VIPs and we had assumed some drink specials had been worked out for us. Miscommunication..blah, blah, blah...this didn't happen. I don't really hold that against them. I hold $10 small well drinks against you. I hold $15 huge cups of well drinks where you pour booze on top so that your customers will smell it and think that there drink is not just a plastic cup of Coke against you. I hold the fact that your bartender refused to give me my change in the hopes that I would get frustrated and leave all of it as tip against you. But that's cool; if the kids from Sheboygan are willing to put up with that kind of nonsense, play on player. I'll be around the corner paying $5 for a real drink with no attitude or weird syringe things in my peripheral.  Oh but 2 for 1 beers (total=$7.00), except Bud Light, cuz that shit is like Cristal!

Dinner Nov 16
  Would like to give 4.5 stars!
  Hidden Gem!  No idea this place existed.  Living in Tampa, I will make the drive to get this freshly made and truly authentic German food.  The Red Cabbage was the best I had ever had.  Loved the garlic butter spread with the bread.  The freshly breaded and beaten schnitzel was phenomenal!  Can't wait to come back and try more dishes!  Oh yeah and sides are all you can eat!!
  Small restaurant, so if you're making the drive, make a reservation.

If I give 3 smackeroos to a fast food place, I'm impressed. My daughter has been after to me to check this place out. She ate at Chipotle's a lot during her college days in S.C. where fast food is so much "better" than in NOLA. See Five Guys. So we met for lunch on a 90 degree day on that lovely stretch of Clearview Pkwy that was so much more scenic when it was a cow pasture, ie, Elmwood, the Concrete Jungle. She walked me through the Felipeesque process of making my "bowl."  I was impressed by the fresh ingredients which is apparently the Chipotle food mission. You can make fast food that is healthy and tasty. And tasty it was. Not knock your socks off tasty, but tasty nonetheless. My "bowl" (which is a burrito with no tortilla) had something like brown rice (flavored with lime and cilantro), black beans, pulled pork, cheese and some sort of salsa. It was a pretty good and healthy dish and beats a double whopper with cheese on both the disgust and bloat factor. 

As for the decor, I can't say I'm a fan. They are trying not to look fast food so basically have designed an interior with stainless steel bar seating which is somewhat communal, very trendy. See Mariza. It is an improvement over the orange and yellow formica at most FF places, but, frankly, I thought the tables would have been perfect for a morgue, easy to clean etc. 

But regardless of the morbid decor, I will go back....and maybe get it to go.

PS I'm not checking off "Romantic" on the additional tips section.

Love this place!  The pretzels are so good.  Genuine philly pretzel style.  Thick and shaped like an 8.  I usually get the buy 3 get 3 free after 3PM and you may think eh after 3,they must be stale but they produce the pretzels consistently through the day so you always get a good batch.  

The store is pretty small and there is no seating and the service is quick.  It'll be cool if it had other things besides pretzels and cheese like pretzel sandwiches but hey, it's cheap+fast+tasty.

I feel a little guilty giving this place 3 stars when everyone seems to love it so much, but oh well!

So, to begin, we managed to find parking quite easily in the underground parking garage. We actually found a spot right next to the elevator that took us up to the entrance of the museum, so that was a good start to our visit! Parking would have been quite expensive for the garage, but the museum validated our ticket so that we could leave the garage for free - another plus :) On the negative side, I thought the admission tickets for the museum were kind of pricy: $15 for an adult ticket? Not outrageous, but a bit more than I expected for a pretty small museum.

Anyway, we paid for our tickets and began our visit with the "Reel West" special exhibit. This could be a generational thing (I'm in my early 30s), but I thought this exhibit was super boring. It seems like this exhibit, which includes various mementos and outfits from old Westerns, would be interesting to older people that grew up watching the relevant TV shows and movies, but it was not interesting to me at all. Maybe just an issue of personal taste, though.

Our next room contained some really nice paintings of Western landscapes and Native Americans as well as a few interesting sculptures, so that improved my mood quite a bit. Unfortunately, the neighboring room was under construction or something, so we likely missed out on some other good pieces.

We then went down to the lower level of the museum, but it didn't seem to contain anything interesting, so we journeyed up to the top (and final) floor of the museum. There was definitely a lot of content up there, so I'm glad we checked it out! First, there were at least a couple of rooms dedicated to one particular Native American artist - unfortunately, I was not a huge fan of his work. Some of it was pretty good (the abstract paintings, for example), but a lot of his work consisted of poorly drawn coyotes. I'm not trying to be a jerk, and it's possible that the true meaning of his work just flew right over my head, but that was my interpretation of what I saw :) So many pictures of coyotes!

The remaining part of the museum contained a lot of artifacts and objects created by different Native American tribes. That part was pretty interesting as well, although I tend to prefer paintings over artifacts/objects, so I wasn't super captivated. After finishing up with the actual exhibits, we checked out the gift shop, and while we didn't buy anything, it had a pretty good selection of stuff to purchase.

Overall, I can't imagine I'd ever come back here. I am interested in Native American and old Western culture, but only as much as I'm interested in most other things, and there are lots of other museums to check out in the world. That being said, if you're particularly fascinated by the themes explored by the work in this museum, then I definitely recommend you go, as there's a good amount of content and some of it is pretty cool!

I'm an Oilers fan through and through, partially as I lived in the Edmonton area during the glory years in the 1980s... sure I was pretty young (okay I was very wee), but I grew up in a family of hockey and specifically Oilers fans.

I've enjoyed their playoff runs (when they've had them) and no matter how they're playing, I really love going to a live game. I don't go too often (maybe once or twice a season tops) but I do watching them play. They do a lot for our city and I enjoy seeing the hockey players out in the community as well.

Gotta love the Ol' Iguodala. The beer selection here is pretty large and stocked with ones I've never heard of, but I like that (don't bother looking for a Bud Light). The food at O.E. is also well above par for a local bar. Many a Phillies' game I have stopped by on the way home, and they didn't even get angry with my repeat attempts to steal their one-ton (must be the wieght if I can't lift it) cigar Indian statue; for some reason their beer always makes me feel powerful enough to throw it onto my shoulder and walk home up the hill. If I'm not feeling particullarly strong, they always have a real cork dartboard, a pool table, and a shuffle board bowling game to get into. Everyone's friendly there, bar dog included, even when I occasionally return to pay tabs I forgot the night before (and especially when I return to pay tabs I thought I forgot, but actually did not). Great bar to go chill in any night of the week, or at least to jump start your night on Main st.

***they do 6 packs to go!***

I don't know what it is about Grille 39 but I think it is one of Carmel's best kept secrets.  Since discovering it when I was pregnant nearly 6 years ago, the consistency alone in it's above average food at good prices continues to bring me back!  

My girlfriends and I used to partake in martini Mondays here...since, we go back for a glass of wine and a salad or just for dessert (the apple crisp - don't miss it).  It's always very good and the service is also excellent.  It's NEVER busy it seems, even on weekends when the Renaissance is full!

Most recently, however, we ended up here again b/c my sister was turning 30 and 17 of her closest friends came into town to share a meal with her.  Unfortunately Kona and Cooper's Hawk could not accommodate us (at all or if they could, there was a room fee - silly).  Grille 39 not only had no issue accommodating in a semi-private area, they offered us a VERY affordable menu to choose from.  For $25/pp we were able to choose a three course meal off a pre-set menu.  The choices were extremely appetizing and they assured us service would be smooth and stressfree.

They were 100% correct.  Everyone seemed to devour their meals and I especially LOVED my salmon. The portions were perfect, the food was cooked well and the service ran extremely smooth.  We had two wonderful servers who filled drinks, cleaned up one of my messes (spilled water glass) and were always around to clean up plates.  It went very well!  Then dessert came out and other than the brownie, which was hard and ....tasteless, everyone seemed very happy.  I was disappointed in the brownie that I tasted off someone else's plate, but honestly that is the ONLY complaint.

Overall, I highly recommend this place if you have a larger group and need space, want something more private and intimate for a date night and/or a quiet place to grab a drink and have a real conversation.  It never seems crowded and there is always good food/drinks to be had. For a restaurant in a hotel, it really could not be any better!

Iavarone's restaurant has a family feel to it, I've been coming here for years. Every time I come the staff is friendly and the experience is great. I've never had a dish I didn't love, from the appetizer to the dessert everything is filled with such authentic favors. This Italian restaurant is a must try, if you visit Tampa.

Another great meal at a Cunningham Restaurant. My husband and I went tonight for our 40th anniversary. After we were seated Ronda the manager came and explained the menu and suggested a few cocktails. I had the Mezcal with the ginger beer, it had a bit of a smoky  taste to it, loved it, hubby had Modelo beer. Next we  had the grilled artichokes it was so flavorful and tender.
Hubby had the Red Drum fish and he loved it. I had the corn empanadas which were good but next time I would get them as an appetizer and try the pork tamales.
For dessert we ordered the churros and Crystal also brought us a plate of dessert with "Happy Anniversary " on it, very nice presentation and delicious. 
It was our waitress Crystal first day off training and you would never have known.
She did a fantastic job friendly, personable and a great smile.
After we left the restaurant I found out one of my daughters that lives out of town wanted to pay for the dessert plate,  whoever she talked to said, "absolutely not". It was on the house....great experience and look forward in going back. Yes, the parking is $8 but worth it since parking is at a premium and my husband can't walk very far. Valet was so sweet and personable as well....

Man oh man tropical isle you were so fun but I won't miss going back. I had my fair share of grenades and I am feeling it still. What are in them?!! No one knows- but the added bonus of a plastic grenade to use to launch at a basket (or other people) kept the night entertaining. 

I also somewhat fell in love with bartender Matt from Milwaukee. Hi Matt.

I had found a cat I was interested on the website for the Camden County Animal Shelter. Some of the local rescue groups and shelters smartly partner with pet stores to accommodate adoptions. While I got to meet and fall in love with Oscar at his foster home, the actual adoption took place here, where his foster mom volunteers on weekends.

The actual process took only a few minutes as we went through his paperwork. As we were doing that, Oliver was playing with buddies and looking quite adorable - other folks stopped by and expressed interest in him and I was happy to let them know he was going home with me.

Petco provides new adopters some great coupons for immediate needs such as kitty litter, carriers, pet food and collars. Use them!

I've been torn on how many starts to give this restaurant. The food is a stand out 5 stars, absolutely outstanding- but our service was 2 star! 
We had a reservation and arrived early so we planned to have a drink at the bar. They don't have bar to sit at other than one that overlooks the pizza oven. The staff at the pizza oven was so friendly. I was really disappointed they only serve beer and wine. They offer no liquor and no ciders, and their rosè or champagne is only sold by the bottle, which was really a bummer. A few of us only had cokes because there wasn't something we liked on the menu.
Our server wasn't friendly at all. She cut off people asking questions, and repeatedly said she'd discuss the specials when the whole group arrived but she never did. Later, we realized that someone in the party would have ordered something from the specials menu. It was difficult to get her attention when people wanted to order another beer, or bottle of wine. She walked away from the table after two people put in appetizer orders, not giving others the chance to order. She also seemed outwardly annoyed if someone asked a question she already answered.
I had the Pollo Valentino and it was absolutely amazing. I had called ahead and they confirmed that they can make any of the pasta dishes gluten free. I ordered this as gluten free and it was better than I could've imagined. The pasta was cooked to perfection and the sauce was a perfect balance of flavor and creaminess. The chicken was well seasoned and grilled perfectly. My husband tried this and agreed that it was absolutely amazing. He was jealous he hadn't ordered this.
My husband had the pizze formaggi, made fresh in the pizza oven. It was made to perfection and he loved every bite!
-the salad that comes with the meals was very average.-
Our party ordered a couple of desserts and the only one that I didn't care for was the crème brûlée because it was more like a pudding and the tip wasn't fired to be crispy.
I will give it another try because as I said, the food was outstanding.

If you want to know if Ale Emporium is good, try going in there on any given evening, weekend, or during a sporting event of any significance and try to find a table. My husband loves this place for their wings and pizza. Both are excellent. The deep dish pizza is fantastic and incredibly filling, so order less than you think you'll need. Great beer selection, pretty good service. The only thing that keeps us from going here more often is the lack of a host. The whole place is open seating like a bar usually would be, but this place is huge so it seems to me there should be some kind of organization. When we drive by, if the lot is full and we're really hungry, we usually go elsewhere. But if you have time to stare down fellow diners to steal their table when they're done, it's worth it.

I love macarons! I heard of this place from my cousin's bf. He ordered macarons from Sucré and had them shipped to New Jersey. When I went to New Orleans in April, I knew I had to visit this sweet spot!

It's located on Magazine Street in the Garden District, alongside the other shops and cafes. Sucré has a lovely sign outside that reads, "Life is uncertain. Eat dessert first." How true, how true?!

So many sweets, so little time. It's like being a kid in a candy shop... literally! The sweets are arranged in glass displays and they have a large menu with pricing. There's plenty of seating in the shop so you can enjoy a hot beverage with your dessert.

I bought a box of macarons to bring back home and they were carefully wrapped to survive the walk, bus, and air plane ride home. Macarons are fragile, but these made it mostly intact to NJ.

Sucré is one of my favorite sweet spots in NOLA and when I'm back, I'll be heading there!

I don't know why I have trouble remembering this place exists. I think because it blends in with so much on 4th Ave that it just sort of becomes a wash.

Today, however, TTS was a standout success. I ventured out this morning for one thing and one thing only, a really ugly holiday sweater for Yelp Tucson's first Elite Event at the Abbey. http://www.yelp.com/biz/the-abbey-eat-drink-tucson. I struck out at a few places, and then knocked it out of the park here. There were two ginormous racks of holiday sweaters, literally jumping off hangers and into my arms! It was hard to choose, but I wound up with a delightful zip-up cardigan with snowmen and snowflakes that I would actually consider wearing in more normal circumstances. 

Even better than my sweater was the accessory I scored. I'd love to talk about it, but I'm afraid some Elites might read this review and I'll have spoiled my Ho Ho Ho surprise. I'll get a photo up of the ensemble so you can truly appreciate the joy I have for rediscovering a Tucson mainstay. Oh and the staff there is super friendly and really informative. When I was going back and forth between two picks, the cashier was helpful in leading me to a festive decision!

Good side: Everyone was very polite and helpful. I asked someone about the price on some tea and he didn't know but went and found out and then found me again to tell me. I could tell some people were still being trained but even they were polite and speedy. This restaurant is adorable. The artwork on the back wall is cheery and very pretty. I love the gold chairs. I love the benches. It's a great look. You walk in, order and then find a seat which seems to keep things speedy. I ordered the hand pie and it was absolutely delicious. I devoured it. In about 2 minutes. I even wanted to finish the gravy with a spoon. Which leads me to the bad side . . . 

Bad side: The portion was so small. They were so good but I finished lunch super quickly and was still hungry. For the price, I expected a little more food. I ended up getting a croissant on my way out because I was still so hungry. The croissant was flakey and delicious but that plus my lunch was kind of pricey. It was good but this is going to be more of a "special occasion" lunch spot rather than a quick everyday lunch spot.

Oh, the Longwood Gardens.

I've been coming here every few years since I was a little girl, and I love it more and more every time, because I come to appreciate it more and more whenever I have the opportunity to visit.

Of course, it's gorgeous. So much work was put into the design of the Gardens, and so much work is put into maintaining it every day. This year, they seemed to be kind of promoting that behind-the-scenes work in their introduction video when you first enter. The children's garden is so cute and fun, the water lilies are absolutely beautiful. I loved the entire room dedicated to the Victoria lily, which is an amazing flower. (It's also a great place to escape to find some air conditioning ;) )

The fountain shows are great. I think some people felt underwhelmed but honestly, I think that they have really high expectations as far as how in-sync the fountains go with the John Philip Sousa playing. The EVENING fountain show was seriously spectacular, though. It's a 30-minute show that starts at... 9:15 PM? The fountains are lit underneath, there are some amazing beautiful colors, and it's a really nice way to end a day at the Gardens. (Or you can come back if you arrived early in the day.)

I also really liked visiting Pierre du Pont's house. I'm the kind of nerd who really loves learning about history, so getting to see his home, his vision, and what he physically did to even the house was really great. He had such a great vision for what he wanted the Gardens to be like, and he poured so much of himself into making that vision a reality that people still enjoy today.

I wholeheartedly 100% recommend the Gardens to anyone who likes flowers, plants, horticulture, biology, the outdoors, people-watching, fountains, John Philip Sousa, topiary, and more.

I feel like I stumbled on a neighborhood secret walking into Sunday brunch here. The vibe at Pro Tap is laid back cool. A tad hipsta but what great brunch place isn't nowadays?

We needed 3 things: carb items for my daughter, eggs and sausage for my son, area proximity due to party proceeding...ok maybe four...bloody marys...always a requirement.

We were greeted with smiles and the wait was nothing (5 mins) compared to other brunch places. Albeit this is a bar but the brunch game is strong my friends.

I definitely recommend getting the Bloody Mary. It's spicy and garnished with homemade pickled veggies. Your choice of vodka.

We ordered a chocolate, caramel donut for the table to try because it was $2 and it was ridiculous. Hot out of the fryer made it crunchy on the outside with a cakey inside and whatever goodness they garnished with was off the plate and devoured within seconds.

Kiddos ordered the chocolate chip pancakes  as well as eggs and sausage. The portions are enormous. The toasted sourdough that comes with egg dishes is superb and you can order as a side. The pile of seasoned fries are a crispy nice addition instead of home fries.

The stunner is the chicken french toast with sunny eggs, kale and cabbage slaw, and peppered maple syrup. The combination of the crunchy kale and cabbage slaw and the saltiness of the fried chicken coupled with the gooey sunnies and peppery sweet maple syrup was insane. I will go back for that lovely dish.

Overall I was really impressed and would recommend!!

This place is phenomenal!! I came here for brunch this morning with a few friends and we loved it. Started with a blackberry marga and I would recommend it, I liked that it wasn't too sweet. We then got an order of nachos for the table, with the as advertised, "very expensive cheese" (lol) and they were cheesy and crunchy and acidic from the pickled onions and jalapenos--honestly a culinary masterpiece! Best nachos I've had around this area, and I am a frequent flyer. Then I had the ceviche mixto, which was a 12 out of 10, dude. I've never had ceviche that had salmon in it (think like sushi-grade, very fresh) and it was a pleasant surprise. It comes with a huge bowl of tortilla chips which I couldn't finish--thanks to the nacho app--but I also paired it with a side of sweet plantains, which made my meal entirely too much. But the plantains were cooked to perfection, topped with crema and this delicious honey and chipotle-y sauce? phewwww man. I could've drank it, lemme tell ya. I will be back!

For a buffet, that is top knotch! We celebrated my son-in-law's 35th birthday weekend with a trip to this faboulus foodie spot. I'm sure he had his fill of crab legs and sampled everything at the seafood station. We all did! I loved the variety of the different stations and there is something for everyone's tastes, from salad bar, (including a made-to-order caesar salad station), mongolian grill, chinese food, all kinds of meats and veggies. Desserts were fresh and dished up by staff on request. Loved the cheese cake and the pastries. Everything was very fresh.

Came to see A-trak Saturday night. He put on an amazing show, but the rock music he switched to (which I completely LOVED!) almost started a brawl between my group (mix of guys & girls) & another behind us(guys & 1 or 2girls) who ALL night kept pushing into us even after asking politely to stop. I have to really thank security for being on them and getting them out of there. They weren't just annoying us, but everyone around them.
5 stars for entertainment and security being on top of their game!

Drinks on the other hand.. Pricey as hell for receiving our drinks with 1% liquor to none.
Drinks from the front bar:
-My crown & coke was just coke. No lie! I literally watched the bartender walk ALL the way to the other side of the bar to make my drink & not once did he pick up a crown bottle or ANY liquor bottle to mix into my drink. Just soda! He came back and said "that'll be $14." When I told him that I watched his ass the entire time of making my drink, he got mad & walked off. Lol thanks for the free soda! 
-1 of my brothers ordered a AMF & received a mixture of syrup.. 
Negative 10 stars lol

Bar next to stage:
They made better drinks... With liquor.
3 stars.. They were OK drinks but better than the 1st round we had.

All in all a great place to check out! The space is very nice & looking forward to seeing other great acts perform here!

I am a fan because I see potential.  Yes they are going through major renovations.  You will hear large drill sounds at 10:30 AM, You will not go through a beautiful lobby and there is no hotel bar...However, once the renovations are complete all you complainers will take back all those negative things you said.  I loved the décor in the rooms and the beds were rather comfortable.

Best Mexican food in all of Reno! 
I've come here to celebrate every special occasion for as long as I can remember..... the food is great, the service is amazing... you really can't beat Bertha Miranda's! 
I always get the classic shredded beef enchilada... never fails to impress!!! My fiancé got the fajitas this time and wowowowowow! The even make their tortillas from scratch! So yummy!
We love Bertha's, and I always recommend it to anyone looking for good food in Reno!

I know its a chain but so what!? They make great pizza here. I love the meatball supremo and the 'turbo' crust is a nice touch (basically butter and romano cheese is spread over the edges). Each time I've been here the staff is really friendly and to me that's surprising since the majority of people there are young high school or just out of high school kids who typically juat aren't the friendliest. The salads are fresh and huge for the price. I appreciate the easy online ordering.

Went to 3500 Winehaus for a friends birthday this past weekend and REALLY enjoyed myself. They have an amazing and knowledgeable staff and a large selection of wines. The ambiance is warm, rustic and welcoming. They have a very cute outdoor patio where they had a fire pit burning outside. I also purchased some of their homemade turtles ($4 for 2 large turtles) which were beyond AMAZING!! I don't think they serve a full menu of meals, but they did have appetizers like pita/hummus, cheese and crackers and little sandwiches that my friend bought as a part of her party reservation. The prices were reasonable considering what type of place it was and wine available by the glass or bottle. I will definitely be going back to this place, I loved it!

Everytime I walk by Boyd's, I dream of the day when I can walk inside to get suited and booted.

No matter how old school, rich, White, and Republican the image their store projects, I love everything in the window, and I envy anybody coming in or out. I miss department stores like these, it gives us something to hope for.

They have an INCREDIBLE tweed suit collection, and great shoes. I like to walk inside, when I look presentable. Even my old man was struck with it. Boyd's, the minute I get it, you're coming with me.

When a friend suggested celebrating her birthday at this restaurant, we all jumped on board. First off, I must say, this is a case of a fine restaurant being located in a rather tired-looking strip mall.  Don't let the outside turn you away. It's a lovely little restaurant with a comfortable and relaxing atmosphere with friendly service.

If I may, I'd like to quote some of my friends on their first meal here for we ordered a nice variety of dishes. I might add the menu was very extensive and offered good vegetarian choices as well.
"The food was delicious and I found the service to be efficient and very friendly.  I also liked the tasteful decor and ambiance.  We tasted many items and I found them all to be very good."
"The restaurant was clean and pleasant, not crowded but well frequented. The food was plentiful and interesting.  My dish was more spicy than expected but had large pieces of chicken and rice that was aromatic and flavorful, although spicy."
Chefs Special Combination Mixed Grill: "The service was excellent and very attentive. Though the dish had great flavor it was overcooked. The lamb was way over done and dry. I loved that they had real ice tea, and lots of lemon! The naan flat breads: we had onion, garlic and plain. They were tender, flavorful, and melt-in-the-mouth delicious. All the appetizers we tried were fantastic."
I had the Vegetable Biryani with flavored basmati rice with veggies, nuts, and cashews. It was pretty bland as I ordered it. Should have spiced it up a bit more.

Here's a link to their website with all the food they serve: http://sher-e-punjabtucson.com

Several of us remarked upon leaving that it would wonderful to return for their famous lunch buffet. I look forward to that.

I guess the point of Groupon is to encourage you to try new places you haven't heard of before. And to make money, I guess. But that's how I discovered Judge's. I was skeptical at first, but according to the interwebs, it had won tons of BBQ awards. Due to its incredibly limited hours (how are they not open on the weekend?!), I could only make it there for the Friday buffet. But I was pleasantly surprised!

It's in a nondescript building on a nondescript street, but the inside is very nice! Comfortable and traditional. The buffet confused me at first - it looked like I was walking in on a church group's potluck. But maybe that's the charm of Judge's. My boyfriend and I tried everything. It all was amazing, but I went back for seconds (and maybe thirds....) of the rib tips - they were so tender and meaty. There were a few different desserts, but I loved the chocolate cake. I think it was just made from a box of cake mix, but it was so good! It seemed like someone at the restaurant had lovingly made it, like my mom would for my birthday.

And wouldn't you know it, the Judge himself stopped by. Or at least, a guy who looked just like the logo. I'm kidding, it was him, and honestly, it felt pretty special to meet the Judge after we had enjoyed the awesome BBQ at his restaurant.

I shared three starters with my date. We had the pot roast cheese fries which was very good. The pot roast was very tender and the flavor gave the fries an extra kick. The cheese wasn't too heavy and that made my day. The buffalo chicken rolls were also very good and the blue cheese sauce was unexpectedly good, since I'm not a fan of dipping sauces very often. It tasted fresh and not like something you get out of a packaged container. Last were the stacked chicken quesadillas. They were really good and had a nice balance of chicken cheese and veggies. 

For a meal I had the shrimp scampi which I grade a B. It was good but I wasn't too keen on taking the left overs home. The sauce was on the bottom, so I had to move the noodles around a lot to get to it. 

I had a Proseco which was nicely chilled and good on the palette. My date had a Grand Mimosa which was made with sparkling wine rather than champagne which she didn't like. She thought it would have been better with champagne because mimosas are typically done with champagne. I enjoyed the flavor because I love Grand Marnier, but I thought the drink could have been colder. It was somewhere in between cool and warm. 

Service was professional and the waitress wasn't bothersome. Our food came out promptly and our orders were correct. The layout of the location was nice, good for a romantic evening or for a quick stop in and have a drink and go. All in all I had a great time and would recommend this Grand Lux. Will definitely go again for the bread pudding that we had for dessert.

Holt Renfrew is Edmonton's only high end department store. Since I don't identify as upper-class, I frequently forget to venture in even though they have some great sales and many of my favorite brands. it's easy to go elsewhere for Citizens of Humanity jeans, but no one else has quite the selection of Gucci bags (I own neither of these things, I'm just trying to appeal to a wider audience, you know?). I stop in here because they have a Tiffany & Co. store inside which is where I go to get my pieces repaired or polished. They also have a Louis Vuitton if you're into that sort of thing. My most recent tour in here I fell in love with one-thousand things I can't afford, and walked out empty handed. Maybe someday when I am a rich lady, Holt & I will become better acquainted.

I've always enjoyed the Nashville Farmer's Market, even as all the old interior businesses were torn down, and new ones (and some of the same, yet renovated ones) appeared.  I thought by moving from north of Nashville into town I'd do most of my regular shopping at the Farmer's Market.  Ehh, not so...

So I don't make it here too often, but it's great when I do.  Mostly because I LOVE the Indian (and general Asian) market.  Huge bags of lentils, other grains and spices, for so little $.  I can dig.  I'd like to adopt an entirely Indian diet just so I can shop here.  

The actual farmer's "row" is pretty good, too.  Sure, the bananas aren't Nashville grown... But the peaches are Georgia of South Carolina grown.  I've had great, very fresh experiences with the produce purchased here. (And a bad experience with the frozen goat meat purchased here.  Moving on...)

Jamaica Way inside is an awesome eating experience every time.  The Indian place is good too, if I recall.  I haven't had experience with any of the BBQ or southern cookin' places, because it's hard to drag me away from the previously mentioned...

I'd save a lot of money and improve my health by a landslide if I shopped exclusively at the Nashville Farmer's Market, and purchased produce that was ONLY in season.

After a long day of driving, we wanted to find a place for dinner within walking distance of our hotel. I love Mediterranean food so this place was a no brainer. We received a friendly greeting upon entering. Order at the counter and food is delivered. I ordered the falafel salad and asked for some Kalamata olives to be added. The falafel was good but far from the best I've had but I was disappointed that the lettuce was iceberg; I had anticipated romaine as I would expect on a Greek salad. The pita bread was warm but again, I have had better. Husband, however, enjoyed his lamb bowl. It sounded like there was a bit of a commotion in the kitchen; perhaps that is why there is a help wanted sign.

A great spot to grab lunch - it's one of the frequent restaurants we stop at when out and about on the weekends. The portions are definitely generous, the ingredients are fresh, and the menu is extensive (from salads to wraps to rice bowls to flatbreads). I love that when you purchase an entree you also receive a small dish of frozen yogurt - score!

I'll admit it. We saw The Avengers movie, and Robert Downey Junior's quip and the post-credit scene gave us a craving for shawarma. So we searched high and low for pita-wrapped meaty goodness (specific rules: it had to specifically be called "shawarma" on the menu; no gyros nor kebabs here!)... and found the best shawarma of our lives.

Seriously.

The only menu item specifically called shawarma is chicken shawarma... and it's beautifully flavored. The meat roasts on a spit in plain view, and is super juicy and tender. They give you the WHOLE pita here (as opposed to the half-pita sandwich you might find at other places), so it's super filling The distribution of layers of vegetables, sauce, and meat is perfectly arranged so you get a bit of each in each individual bite.

Oh man, we could rave about the self-serve sauce bar, but I'll try not to gush. It includes a variety of pickles, harissa, some kind of sweet tamarind sauce, a green somewhat spicy cilantro sauce, and a variety of olives. I can't believe all that is free! Make sure to give it a look, at least.

I'd love to come back to Desert Rose to try their other offerings. The prices are decent, the portions are huge, and they also have a little shelf of Mediterranean groceries for purchase (check out their interesting salts!). It's obvious that the head chef and employees care deeply about this new business, and I hope that the rest of the community will, too.

This shop specializes in fudge, old time candies, and ice cream. It was so much fun wandering around and picking out candy from our childhood. We were on vacation and ended up leaving the shop with lots of treats and gifts for those back home. The chocolate dipped apricots were my favorite and my husband loved the rocky road clusters. I also like that they make their candy on site in the back. We could see the machines through the window. A must to stop in every time we are in Carp!

My first attempt at St. Louis BBQ was more than two years ago when I went to Pappy's as an eager freshman and waited 1.5 hours for a pretty average pulled pork sandwich. Granted, maybe I did not order the best bbq item on the menu, but it pretty much deterred me from trying other St. Louis bbq since Pappy's is considered the "best in STL".

A couple months ago I was introduced to Sugarfire when i went with a group of interns - it was a life-changing experience. The line was about 10x faster than Pappy's, and everyone serving me was friendly and helpful. I ordered the beef brisket sandwich with a side of veggies the first time, and it was so damn good. The beef brisket is so tender, and I enjoyed trying the different bbq sauces, but STL bbq sauce is my favorite by far. 

I have tried basically all the meats at Sugarfire after 2 visits to this location and 2 to the O'Fallon location. The beef brisket and smoked turkey are my favorite. They are both very tender, flavorful, and not too heavy. I am not a huge fan of pork, but I think the ribs and pulled pork are average. The sides tend to be on the salty side, especially if they are veggies, but they are pretty flavorful. I have also tried the salmon and its pretty good if you're looking for an alternative to meat! 

However, if you want a ton of meat, go for the meat daddy, which has generous portions of ribs, pulled pork, beef brisket, smoked turkey, and a sausage with two sides and a drink. I had the meat daddy the last time with baked beans and green beans and split it with my girlfriend. It was literally so much food, we definitely shouldn't have tried to finish it all. It's good though if you want to sample the meats and it's a lot of food for $23!

I love Sugarfire, and I just keep coming back for that delicious STL BBQ.

Who doesn't love an interactive dessert experience? Sub Zero starts with a choice between different bases like ice cream, custard, fro yo and more. There's even non-dairy and vegan options. Then you can pick from a full menu of flavor syrups and add-ins. Then the fun starts as they blast your bowl with liquid nitrogen to freeze it all into a custom dessert as you watch. It's so very tasty and the combinations are endless!

When I walked in, I was convinced that vampires inhabited the house. I was excited to eat here! It was lunchtime on a Saturday around 1pm and it wasn't too busy on this quiet street. We just sat wherever we wanted.

There is a long staircase right by the entrance and I was very tempted to use it. It's also very dimly lit pass the dining room and the bar. I was almost reluctant to use the bathroom in the back. I love that feeling.

The waitress/bartender recommended these new drinks she was mixing up so four of us each had one. The other two were staying away from alcohol. Let me tell you something, their corn bread with syrup (probably family recipe) was the best thing I've ever had. We devoured it in 2 minutes. I love sweets before the meal.

We proceed to order our entrees. Everything was fried, it seems like; except the salads. The pork chop was pretty. Two of ordered the jambalaya with deep fried catfish strips. The rice was a bowl's worth but it was surrounded by fish. It was battered pretty thickly so it was a lot to eat. We stripped the fried crunchy stuff and ate most of the fish. 

Disappointed that this wasn't a vampire house, I left happy and full stomached.

I wanted to wait to try a few different nail salons around Zionsville before writing a review of any of them. Ya know, to compare them all.

So far, of the three I've tried, I've liked Mia's the best

Why, you ask? Easy - 3 reasons.

First and foremost, cleanliness. While I've only been there once, it was clear to see that Mia's sanitizes their tools regularly. In fact, I saw at least 4 sterilizers behind the manicure stations, and I saw my manicurist take the tools she'd be using straight out of her sterilizer and open the sealed package. 

Second, their color selection for gel polish was excellent, and the manicurist was very patient as I struggled worth indecision! So many choices! Eek!

Third, my manicurist, May, was so patient and gentle while also being very thorough. Unlike some manicurists at other salons I've visited, May did not attack my nails with a vengeance, stabbing and cutting like a mad lady. Rather, she worked efficiently and gently, paying close attention to detail. When I clumsily bumped my nails when putting them under the lights to cure the gel...not once but TWICE...she patiently and kindly fixed them without losing her patience or complaining. 

Suprise! I thought of a fourth reason I really liked Mia's - they did not rush their work on me to get to the next client.  It was lovely. 

In short, I'll be back!

Wow, I must say- the Stillery is an impressive restaurant and I am glad I found this place while in Nashville.

First off, you will need reservations to go here. I went on a Wednesday night and the place was completely full and not accepting walk-in tables. They don't have a ton of seating, so definitely plan ahead if you want to check this place out!

It is in a very convenient location in comparison to the main stretch on Broadway. This is a place that will allow you to have a nice dinner without all of the noise of its neighbors around the corner.

Service was friendly and efficient. We got seated for our reservation on time as well. My fiancée and I ordered the rangoons to start. For our main dishes, I went with the Mac and cheese topped with hot chicken (they had two options- their house which was a medium Buffalo or Nashville hot) & he went with the mushroom blue burger. I absolutely loved the Mac and the chicken; however my fiancée said the burger was overcooked. The offer great cocktail options as well.

Overall, we had a great time here. I definitely recommend checking this place out!!

Finally made it here for lunch, and i thought it was pretty solid. i love a restaurant that commits to using local, fresh ingredients.

I also love a magically delicious sandwich. I have heard  good things about the Fried Egg BSRP which is what i ordered...minus the B (B is for bacon). I feel that you always take a gamble when ordering a dish sans ingredients because they were usually put there for a reason. But, that sandwich just seemed too good to pass up, so i threw caution to the wind and went with it! So glad i did, because it was SUPER. I got a side salad with it, which i didn't really eat. It was not bad, but i eat salad all the time and i was really just regretting not getting chips. Note to self - get chips fool!

Okay, so now for the best part of my lunch. COCKTAILS! Nosh makes a mean one. Seriously, one of the best i have ever had. I had a cucumber martini and it was PERFECT. Refreshing, slightly sweet but not overly so. This would be the most amazing summer drink ever. My friend had a hard lemonade and it was equally delicious. 

I can't wait to go back and try Nosh again but first impression is good. Good indeed.

A bunch of us came here after dinner on a Wednesday. There was a long line out the door.  We heard it was amazing though so we got in line.  They had a large selection of ice cream,  old fashioned soda fountain drinks,  shakes,  malts,  and sundaes.  I love hot fudge sundaes so I had to get that.  I thought it was pretty pricey though,  mine ended up being $14! It was the mt. Vesuvius.  It came with chocolate and vanilla ive cream but you could switch it out, I should have because i thought it was bland.  I just wasn't impressed for the price it was.  I wished there was more hot fudge too. I did eat most of it because I love ice cream but all in all not that impressive.

I have a bunch of friends who swear by this place, and while it didn't quite live up to the hype in my opinion, it was on its own really good. It has been fairly busy whenever I've gone. The burger was an average size patty, plain with cheese and pickles. Do you have to ask for condiments? I'm not sure. The amount of fries (they were good spicy) was decent, and I was definitely full when I left. With a can of pop, my bill was about $20. 

This place has delicious meat! It's a bit of a hipster vibe, but cute. I love Holland Plaza. Not a huge place, but adequate seating and a long bar in front of the grill. The prices were as expected for quality food of average portions. The server (Simone?) was really friendly and fun to chat with. They sell some retail meat. 

I would say it's more accurately 3.5 stars. 3 definitely feels like too few, but 4 seems a little high.

We stopped by on one hot summer afternoon. With the abundance of green live plants throughout and natural light, it felt like an oasis. The unusual building structure seemed perfect for a public library. I would love to sit at one of the small tables and just get lost in a book. The whole place makes me feel very nostalgic, as if I've been here before. I love that feeling. 

Now, some negatives. The books are not easy to find. it seemed the selection was rather small, but it could well be because of their huge shelf areas. I also learned just now that they close two days a week (Fri/Sat? Really?) and close early in eve. I know I am spoiled locally in Marin, where the public libraries are just amazing, but that's a bit sad. 
Also, no parking. We were able to just park on the street, but this would be inconvenient for families with little kids, disabled users, and in bad weathers. I hope this place, and the public libraries as a whole, gets more love!

This would have been a four star review if their chefs were consistent.  The first time I went I had the sea scallops.  They were seared perfectly and had a rich caramel color developed on them.  The risotto was creamy and the pork belly tender and flavorful while the baby zucchini still had a crunch.  I was so in love with the dish that I ordered it a second time.  That was a mistake.  It had to have been a different cheft that night.  There was wayyyyyy to much goat cheese in the risotto to the point that it had a grainy texture and caused you to pull strings of cheese.  The poor pork belly was so over cooked it was hard to cut with a knife and barely had flavor and the sea scallops while okay didn't have that great color developed.  This place can be great.  Depending on what night you go.

Yes its that good. My grandma worked here for like 25 years, nothing like getting fresh danishes. The owner is super friendly, he even attended my bros wedding. The blackforest cake is hoe blackforest cake is suppose to be,not that crud from safeway. I even work for a restaurant and we buy our buns from here. I am european and this is my pastry headquarters. LOVE IT

This place has great pizza! It's definitely a popular spot, so be prepared to wait. We came at an odd time - around 3pm on a Saturday and it was still packed. I loved how much basil they put on the margherita pizza too. The service wasn't spectacular - my bf and I ordered a pizza and a calzone and they didn't come out at the same time. Our server told us they mistakenly gave the calzone to a different table and he'd give us a dessert on the house to make up for it. It wasn't a big deal but we never got the dessert. Our server just seemed busy and not the friendliest. Overall a solid pizza spot though.
I loved this place.  It's a great change of pace to the rest of the college/frat bars along 4th.  Great beers and great people.  Check it out.

This place is very cool. The idea of "pour your own beer" is awesome. I could come here every night so I can have a couple sips of beer and be on my way. It led me to trying a bunch of different beers that I normally wouldn't try to do because I wouldn't want to try a normal sized pint.  The prices are by the ounce and are pretty decently priced. The manager was very nice and asked us what we liked me didn't like. They are really open to suggestions. 

Plus.. they had Abita on draft and the Nola girl in me fell in love with an Indy bar with Abita

Best ice cream in Nashville! Chocolate dipped vanilla is a classic. My wife loves the chocolate soft serve. This is a great place to end a night after a spicy, hot chicken feast at Hattie Bs. I've not partaken of the food here, but it always looks and smells good. If you're going the cone route, the medium is not for the faint of heart or the lactose intolerant. Grab ya some ice cream!

Another wonderful trip to Tay's this morning. Fast, friendly service that keeps us coming back. A great place to interact with your local neighborhood citizens. Worker even made my wife a drink that wasn't on the menu and she loved it. Keep up the great work, always enjoy stopping by in the morning.
Huuuge supermarket (compared to NYC supermarkets) clean and well maintained. Reasonable prices. And they have an ample selection of wines. Would love to see them have a bigger organic selection.

This is my main Ulta, and my favorite. It's definitely the biggest of the ones I frequent, and the cleanest. I love the huge selection of Butter London that they carry, as well as the essential drugstore items I need but always forget! I have never gone to the salon here, and I highly doubt I ever will as I'm pretty dedicated to my salon now. This really is my go-to place besides MAC and the Sephora in the Cherry Hill Mall. There usually is very little staff here - at least when I go, which is typically 7pm or later - but that's fine by me as I don't ever need help.

After walking in, we soon discovered that this place is the perfect date spot for a cold winter evening! It has a great cozy upscale feel with wonderful food. 

We both started with some tasty bubbly cocktails. If you love some bubbly than this is the place for you. They have plenty of options. We then split the grilled quail with wilted arugala and a sherry au jus and it was lovely. Yes, quail is always tough to eat because it's just so tiny but the flavors were really tasty. It was a very fall dish. My only wish was that the quail came with more of a grilled texture but all and all, great start. I should also mention that the bread and butter was awesome. I loooove a french baguette and they serve a great one!

For our entrees we went with the seared duck breast and the butter poached salmon. The duck was perfect. I love a seared duck breast and this dish had every component I love in a duck dish. Perfectly medium rare, sweet and savory with a creamy puree to pair. Great. Very rich but well worth the richness! The salmon was also a winner. It was more on the rare side which is fine by me with the perfect buttery flavor. The other components all paired well with the dish and didn't take anything away from the salmon. 

With the cold winter months upon us, absolutely check this place out!

I have many memories of Plaza Bowl from my childhood - birthdays, school trips. I think my mom was even in a league there for a while. I've always thought of it fondly but hadn't been back in many, many years. The one time I did attempt to go recently, they were closed! I went for dinner nearby last night and actually parked right outside. After our meal, hoping there weren't leagues in there, we decided to head down and see if we could knock some pins over. 

I felt like I stepped through a time machine and came out in 1993. Absolutely nothing has changed and I love it. There are 12 lanes, but they're not all in a row like other bowling alleys. There are six on each side of the room. The wooden benches remind me of old church pews. The bowling alley is in a basement, yet there are curtains all along the walls. I swear the lady working at the front is the same one from way back when, too. 

The price for a game is cheaper than other alleys - $4.50/game. Shoe rentals are $2.00. You can get a few snacks - chips and beer. The lady told me they usually close between 9:30-10pm.

There are leagues every night except Thursday night. We went on Wednesday shortly before 7pm and the teams started playing right around 7pm, although they were only using six of the lanes. Call ahead if you want to be sure. 

They don't make 'em like this anymore.

"How the Scott Loved Snake and Jake's"

Every Whodat
Down in Whodat-ville
Liked the Christmas Club den...

But the Scott,
Who lived just Uptown of Whodat-ville,
Had NEVER been!

Now, please don't ask why. No one quite knows the reason.
It could be that he plum ran out of thick condoms.
It could be, perhaps, a fear of no windows.
But I think that the most likely reason of all
May have been that his wallet was two sizes too small.

But,
Whatever the reason,
With coat and two hats,
He stood there on Christmas Eve, surrounded by Whodats.

See, he had an idea!
An awesome idea!
THE SCOTT
GOT A WONDERFUL, AWESOME IDEA!

"I know just what to do!" The Scott laughed in his throat.
And he grabbed his Santy Claus hat and leather coat.
And he smiled, and hooted, "What a great Scotty plan!
"With this coat and this hat, I'll look just like a man!"

"All I need is a friend..."
The Scott looked around.
But since friends were away, there were none to be found.
Did that stop the lone Scott...?
No! The Scott simply said,
"If I can't find a friend, I'll bring Storms instead!"
So he called his dog Stormy. Then he found his red sweater
And he dressed him all Christmasy like a go-getter.

Inside the bar, all divey and dark,
There were two other dogs and none of them barked.
Storms wandered on in, sniffing ass after ass,
And soon got picked up by lass after lass.

Scott grabbed a seat and bourbon he drank,
And even eventually new friends did he make.
And friends from Twitter, and friends who have Yelped,
Friends one and all, it just couldn't be helped.

"It's midnight," grinned the Scott,
"Merry Christmas I hear!"
Then he paused. And the Scott saw in the rear,
A giant balloon hat wouldn't you know?
It started so small. Then it started to grow...

And what happened then...?
Well...in Whodat-ville they say
That the balloon hat universe
Grew three hundred sizes that day!

And the minute Scott's stomach didn't feel quite right,
He spewed up his yak through the bright morning light
And he brought back the bourbon! And the food from Eve feast!
And he...

...HE HIMSELF...!
The Scott flushed Porcelain Beast!

I love this place. I've been here many times because they have good drinks, open late, and have some BOMB mac & cheese. 

I recently just tried the Kale Salad and it was the same caliber as the mac & cheese. I know thats a heavy statement, but it's so true. The fried chicken of course is good. Oh and those biscuits with honey butter. Come. on. It's all just too good! 

The drinks are all great. Great beer selection. The mule and eagle tea are great too. Oh and they have a pretty good whiskey selection as well. 

One of my favorite places to go to on Mass Ave.

I LOVE this pizza! Seriously don't understand the low reviews! 

Slices are huge and packed full of flavor.  The base is thin and crispy, perfect ratio of sauce to cheese to topping, lots of variety, cheap, cheerful and the staff were friendly too.  

I also need to mention that the mix in their pop-dispenser was excellent.  Really tasty coke zero (this is important!!) 

What I gave an extra star to (and would have given it 10 more) is their limoncello cake - sweet baby Jesus it's one of the nicest cakes I've ever tried in my life (and I'm a fussy home-baker!) so much so that I went back two days in a row, for cake, for pizza and for a cheap feed on the way back to my hotel from the Children's hospital!

So to start out on a positive note...my fiance got my engagement ring from here and it is absolutely gorgeous... He ordered online and it shipped very quickly. I couldn't be happier with it. However , when it came time to look for wedding bands we decided it just made sense to go back to Shane Co. Unfortunately the experience was not a good one... The gentleman that offered to help us when we walked in the door seemed almost annoyed that he had to help someone.. but I tried to give him the benefit of the doubt. Maybe he was nearing the end of his shift and just tired. However , we told him we were there to look for wedding bands and I was very excited. He didn't share the excitement ... Didn't ask when the big day was, no interest in us personally . I told him I wanted something Rose gold to match my ring and he started pulling some rings. I noticed the ones he was pulling were much more than we were hoping to spend, so I politely asked him if maybe we could look at something more in the $500-$600 range. I didn't think that was unreasonable based on some styles I had seen online during my research. He immediately said, "well I can tell you that you aren't going to get a ring with any sort of stone in it in that price range..."... Okay... So I ended up finding something at the top of that price range that had some small diamonds in it and felt like that was really my only option if I didn't want a plain metal band. He made it obvious he was tired of showing me rings and I felt like I needed to make a decision so next thing I knew I had purchased this ring that I probably wouldn't have originally even picked out. So fast forward a month or so and it was still bothering me that I wasn't completely happy with my ring and felt liked I had been rushed into a decision. So I decided to look elsewhere.  I ended up going to Jared Galleria of Jewelry, and what a stark difference from my experience at Shane. I was greeted immediately by a very bubbly kind woman who was more than happy to show me several options of rings in my price range that were gorgeous. She took her time with me and I felt like she would have spent however long I needed to find the perfect ring . I found a ring I really loved there and was set to buy it but I wanted to give Shane co. one last chance. I went in as soon as they opened today and was greeted by a young woman. I explained to her that I wanted to return a ring I had purchased because I really wasn't sure I liked it but that I was interested in looking at a couple of rings I had seen online. She asked me why I didn't like my ring and I just was honest and explained the prior situation and how I felt rushed into buying something that I wasn't crazy about. She didn't give an apology but jumped at the chance to show me more rings. She looked at my receipt from the original ring and said "okay I see what your budget is based on this".
