Once we reached the window we noticed she had on a mask but it was below her nose and no gloves. She gave us our drinks and asked us to pull forward. A few minutes later a lady brings out a bag and tells us to have a good day. We were missing the flounder sandwich my husband wanted to try, sauce for the shrimp he ordered and received 3 beignets instead of the 6 ordered. My husband puts his mask on and grabs the receipt. He was back out in minutes being told the order wasn't done so they were going to bring it out....but, the lady who brought it out said have a nice night?! Ok no big deal, we get on the road and I check the bag they gave him, no flounder sandwich but instead two plain chicken sandwiches. I took the bag of beignets out and there was a hole in the bag and powdered sugar went everywhere! All in all like I said the food we did get was decent but I wouldn't visit this location again anytime soon. I imagine we got someone's plain chicken sandwiches and they got his fish so that'll be interesting.

Pro's: Excellent quality and selection, hip and trendy vibe in the decor. Loved the fried egg rolls! 

Cons: For me, location, but it's close to work so that's good for lunch. No other cons I experienced.

Go back? Definitely 

A coworker and I ordered AYCE for lunch. I enjoyed everything I had: Sumunomo salad...sweet and tart; Fried egg roll fresh and delicious...not too greasy; Gyoza rolls, maguro and San Francisco roll. 

Service was excellent. Decor was hip with passion-red drapes and lovely Asian lady art work where their smoldering red lipstick was a nod to the draperies...kinda sexy! Sushi aphrodisiac? Give it a try!!!

Charming atmosphere and DELICIOUS food. They have great pastry options to start and a full selection of tea, coffee, and lattes. The breakfast items are delicious - we ordered the quiche and the breakfast sandwich and were not disappointed. Loved that during weekend brunch we also had lunch options. Outside patio and bar are first come first serve but the main seating takes reservations. Would definitely go again!

I love Dominican food and was excited to discover this affordable Dominican restaurant on 12th and Callowhill.  Friendly staff made for a good start but the lack of air conditioning made for a stifling and uncomfortable meal.  There were a variety of dishes to choose from.  I had the tres gulpes and was underwhelmed.  The fried cheese and salami were good but the base of the meal was mushy and not flavorful.  My friend had the Tilapia which came out black.  I did;t ask her how it tasted but it looked severely If I were to go back again I would order the chicken lunch special - half a chicken with rice and beans for $7.50.  Also getting it to go would prevent from having to eat in an un-airconditioned room.  This place has potential unfortunately I didn't feel like it was quite met.

The cheese curds are amazingly good! I visited them for the past 2 years at taste of three cities food truck rally. The cheese has flavor and is fried to perfection every time. The cheese never comes out before you bite it, and it is alway nicely melted and hot. They had a line each time I went, but it was worth the wait! Sorry mozzarella sticks - I found a new love.

One of my favorite places in Seminole Heights!   The inside of this place is just so cute.  There are plenty of tables inside and a couple benches outside if you want to eat here.  

As far as the food goes, I am seriously addicted to their acai bowls.  I think I probably stop in once a week for a bowl.  I loved all three of their bowl options.  I usually gravitate towards the Whatever bowl which has light and fruity base, although sometimes I will get the cacao bowl which has a hint of chocolate in the base.  They have a lot of different toppings which are all are spot on - fruit is fresh, granola is crunchy and the honey is local!      

I will also come in here for some gelato or a pop.  My favorite pop is the earl grey lavender lemonade.  So yummy!  Whatever pops is a great place a sweet treat or a light breakfast/lunch acai bowl!

Visit date: 7/30/19 2pm
This is a really nice option in the Indy airport, my third time there. Prices are comparable to any airport establishment. I love that they have so many fresh salad and sandwich options... and pizza. 

I always sit at the bar, there are outlets and bag hooks near each seat. The barkeeps are friendly and funny. No one rushes you, but they provide excellent service, unlike most airport bar/restaurants.

On this visit I did a 20oz tap IPA (ice cold) and their famous shrimp cocktail. It might seem pricey... 4 jumbo shrimp in house-made cocktail sauce for $16... but it was the perfect treat when I wasn't looking for a full meal. It is served in the sauce, on ice, and it will knock your socks off. Horseradish at its best!

I heard that they are expanding the establishment within the year, even better!

To say I love this place might just be an understatement. Whenever I come to town, this place is one of my go to's and a place I always take someone unfamiliar with St. Louis. So, yea, it's good! It looks unassuming from the outside, but man do you get delicious drinks and mouth watering plates here

I can't live without the prime rib. Part of me actually thinks I need it to maintain breathing, or is it the rich risotto that keeps blood pumping through my veins? The risotto is rich, nicely seasoned and just begs you to eat more and more. And, when risotto asks nicely, who am I to argue?

Ok, so minor note, on my last visit, the prime rib wasn't fantastic. It was cooked to perfection, but the cut was just not as tender and succulent as it normally is. We came close to closing, so I think maybe this was just the one they had left? Or, more to say, I hope this is the case.  

Ask about the drink specials. They change, and you might find some random deliciousness. On my last visit, I got a bacon bloody mary that knocked my socks off. Our servers have always been incredible too. 

All in all, do I recommend this place? No surprise here: OF COURSE! I'd say to make this a must see on a trip to St. Louis.

I got a chance to kick off last Remembrance "long" weekend with a late night dinner at the new North 53. I say new, because although I had been there a few times before, this past Friday was their official reopening launch, showcasing a new look, new chef, and new dishes.

The tasting menu and plates are now gone and instead replaced with snacks, plates, and plates to share. The new concept focuses on smaller tapas style plates, encouraging its patrons to share more menu items. The most noticeable difference on the menu? The price. Diners, I'm sure, will be happy at the lower price point of the meal. 

I really enjoyed the mousse, the chicken liver sourced from Four Whistle Farm. Blended with duck fat, it was smooth and rich. Delicious! Could have used a couple more bites, perhaps larger individual portions would have been more satisfying, although the petite bites gain points for being adorable.

Chicharron seems like a trend now on a lot of menus and North 53 has jumped aboard. Scallops and mussels are dried in house and ground, with kelp and salmon katsubushi, giving a strong umami flavour to the fried pork skins. So good, crunchy, and super addicting!

The Marinated and Griddled Mushrooms came out next, a drool-inducing looking plate. A mixture of crimini, shitake, beech, and oyster mushrooms are first brined with Maggi sauce and griddled on the flat top before serving. 

The Popcorn Chicken literally took on its name: pureed popcorn grits mixed in with a tempura beer batter made a crisp coating to bites of Four Whistle Farms chicken and finished with powdered popcorn. Yum!

The Shrimp Chorizo was one of my favourite dishes for the night! The shrimp was mixed in with a blend of garlic, chill, fennel seeds, smoked paprika and hot paprika, giving the "sausage" slices that classic chorizo flavour. Loved the fact that not all the shrimp was ground so that you could still taste and see chunks of shrimp. 

The Carrot Salad was the most elegantly plated of the night, and was nice and refreshing after the heavier dishes we had earlier. Loved the colours and the varieties of techniques used to treat the carrots (steeped and pickled), with a light vinaigrette of olive oil and Saskatoon berry vinegar. To add back some sweetness, a carrot caramel, made from freshly juiced carrots, was drizzled around the plate. Quenelles of goat cheese topped it all off, with hints of green cardamom. Most of the bites I got were on the sweeter side, while some of the others got a hit of the vinaigrette. Wish I had the dish all to myself to get the best of both worlds!

The Rutabega & Oxtail Tart was a table favourite. John Schneider's Gold Forest Grains lends his Park wheat flour to make the tart shell, which was filled with a rutabaga puree. The oxtail was from Sangudo Farms, braised and shredded, then cooked with red wine, espolet peppers, and a red wine vinegar sourced from Spain. A micro salad from their urban cultivator topped off the dish with a honey and lemon oil.

The clam and scallop fettuccine gave the Shrimp Chorizo a run for its money for me. Utilizing their pasta extruder, the house made egg-free (whaa?) pasta was amazing and perfectly cooked. West Coast clams and Nova Scotia scallops were tossed in alongside a white wine sauce, my favourite! Absolutely loved this dish and bound to be a favourite for many.

Last main for the night was the Short Rib Glazed in Beer. The short rib was sous vide for 24 hours before being finished with a beef stock and beer glaze. The navy beans were nice and tender, but not overcooked, and mixed with parsnips, carrots, onions, and celery. I was confused as to where the bone marrow was, expecting a whole bone to be plated, but was notified that the dish was finished with raw bone marrow for added flavour.

The Blue d'Elizabeth was a conversation stopper, a combination of the named blue cheese from Quebec, roasted Bosc pear, and a side of salad with olive oil from Turkey and dressed with a burnt caramel mixture, deglazed with a sweet sherry. The components were all separate but combined created an amazing dish, well balanced, and truly unique. I'm not the biggest fan of blue cheese either but this was so yummy!

The Cognac ice cream. TO DIE FOR. Smooth, creamy, the ice cream's texture was perfect. Calvados and maple syrup were incorporated into the mix itself, and finished with Cognac-rehydrated sultana raisins. Even the simple toasted brown flour sugar cookies were delicious! We also got to try the blueberry sorbet (unpictured), light and refreshing, not overly sweet. A great way to end our meal.

Fried chicken is only available as the  perfect late night snack: three pieces of dark meat, brined and fried with a simple batter. A powdered green Tabasco and jalapeño mixture gave the chicken an added kick, although I didn't seem to get any of that in my bites! Will have to try it again on my next visit for that, but the chicken was moist and tender, the batter crispy.

Spring is right around the corner when the Indiana Flower & Patio show starts. This show is one we go to every year. I love seeing all of the flowers and displays. This year it was not as "pretty" I feel there is not as many flowers as past years. Now if you need to be hassled to buy windows or change your internet provider they have you covered!! 
I was glad to see they were selling more potted plants. There were quite a few booths selling succulents. They are the hot plant this year! 

It was great that Yelp had the Yelp's Backyard Lounge built by Scott and Jessica with New Palestine Lawn Care. They did a great job. Cozy little area to play some games or just have a seat.

Tickets are $14 at the door but if you buy them online you can get buy one get one free deals. Plus Groupon normally sells discount tickets about a month before the show. So look for the deals so you don't have to pay full price.

Tacconelli's is hands down the BEST pie you can get in America - I might be willing to fight over this fact.  I lived in Italy for a year of my life so I have some footing to stand on here.  You might be puzzled by the 4 star review so let me elaborate...

First off, planning a pizza dinner a few days in advanced seems a little obnoxious.
The wait was long and the restaurant was small we decided to wait outside no big deal, only problem was that all of the smokers would come outside and light up (downwind).  I think I second hand smoked a pack of ciggs before dinner. Not so nice aperitif.

The decor hasn't been changed since forever, but I like that!  Our waitress was a little short with us, I understand she was busy, but no need to be kinda rude to your customers.

It's a BYOB and we knew this in advance however, we did not know that we needed to also BYOG (Glasses).  Red wine isn't quite the same out of a plastic cup ha ha.

Now to the pizza... My God, THE PIZZA... Thin crust, nice and crisp on the bottom  Pillowy and soft interior just above that.  Slightly smoky flavor throughout the dough, sauce and cheese.  The red sauce is like sun dried tomatoes had an illegitimate child with fire roasted tomatoes.  The flavors are so concentrated and complex, be sure to sip wine with the meal as most of the flavors in tomatoes are alcohol soluble. In plain English... you wont be able to truly taste the sauce unless there is a little alcohol present to allow your plate to experience them. (Sorry I know weird food stuff, but trust me here, you want the full effect!)  Cheese was sparse on the pie.. the way it should be, because it's about the sauce!  However the cheese was of amazing quality, no grease here.  

14 bones for a medium sized pizza seems a bit high but, as we have already established, the place was packed, you need to reserve your dough, wait outside before you are even seated, and it is the best pizza you can get without a passport so I guess I should be happy they aren't charging $40 (because I knew a few pizza junkies that would still pay that)

All of that being said... it's an AMAZING pizza experience.  Order your dough, wait outside, bring wine and a couple of glasses, ignore the unhappy waitress, and order yourself a pizza like none other.  I would love to go 5 stars... I just can't do it with all of it's flaws.  
-This pizza should be on your bucket list.

You'd think I was on a quest to find the best deli in STL--- maybe I am! 
Anywho, darling honey and I decided to eat for lunch a couple weeks ago after I suggested we try it out. 
We had a coupon from the entertainment book-which helps.
The place wasnt crowded- in fact, we were the only people in there untill another table showed up-
I will say, dont blink! or you'll miss it! 
Such a cute, quaint little place. So for that, it gets a star.
I LOVE delis--- and I am certainly not a picky one, at all---
But I must say, I was a tad disappointed in my sandwich, and the lack of flavor.
I ordered the For Petes Sake- which on the board, sounded amazing! 
In my mouth---- not so much. While it was okay, it just didnt blow me away. 
With flavors like bacon, applesauce, brie, caramelized onions, and applewood smoked pork loin you'd think that it would be bursting with flavor---it wasnt.
It really had no taste.
Now, darling honey ordered the hangover club, and he seemed to really enjoy it.
However he said he would get it without the spicy mustard next time.
I will definitely return to Noras for a chance for redemption- but I'm hoping next time 
my sandwich is more of a party in my mouth, and not a dud.

My husband and I took advantage of the lovely cool weather last weekend and took the ferry from St. Pete to Tampa. What a fun, stress-free ride! It beats driving over the Howard Frankland any day. 

We were meeting some friends at Sparkman Wharf so this was the perfect time to try out the ferry, since it drops off at the aquarium just around the corner. We parked in my husband's space downtown, but they do validate parking in the Sun Dial garage which is nice. The ship was easy enough to find right in front of the Vinoy. 

We bought our tickets ($8/each way plus .80 convenience charge added to the entire order) on the mobile app the day before and are glad we did. When we bought them, it said there were 88 seats left on the boat, so when we got in line to board we were surprised to hear them say it was sold out! It was also sold out for our 3:15 trip back to St. Pete. 

The boarding process was quick and easy and we got some nice seats outside. It was windy but not too windy to be out there. There was a snack bar serving beer/wine/mimosas but I wasn't able to see the prices. 

My only complaint is that I wish 1) it wasn't ending in April and 2) they had more frequent times available. I'm meeting a friend for happy hour in Sparkman Wharf in a few weeks and don't want to wait until 10:45 to come home. It would also be nice to have a round trip discount - even if just a dollar or two. 

However, it's a great way to get to Tampa without driving and a cheap way to be out on the water. We will be utilizing the ferry to get to the next Lightning game we are attending in March!

I have heard and seen nothing but great things about this place.
Yesterday I stopped in to see Gilbert. Even though it was super super busy, I patiently waited and browsed around their great selection of bikes; Triumph and Ducati's mostly. 
Once I was helped, I had the chance to test ride some bikes that I was really really interested in.
I first tested the Ducati Streetfighter 848 and Triumph Street Triple R and loved both bikes. 

It was super easy to test ride these bikes, other than signing a waiver, and the staff were super helpful.

Also,
If you're honestly complaining about prices of your bike getting serviced, GTFO. They're European. 
If you want to save money, learn to do your own maintenance yourself!

The food was good. We went at 5:30pm today (Wednesday) bc some of the reviews cautioned about wait times. Today was Wine down Wednesday - wine was 1/2 price bottles. We had the margarita flatbread for $6 during happy hour, and it was really good. I got the scallop dinner, and it was pretty good. The service was a touch slow, but the waitress was very nice. The restaurant space itself is lovely. It was a very nice experience. 4 stars!

Got a chance to check out Church and Union last week. Love the decor and vibe of the spot--similar to a speakeasy. The service was great and our server was very helpful in helping us navigate the menu. The food was great, but my filet was a little bit tough. Great flavor, though! The corn and carrots were wonderful as well. After dinner we bellied up to the bar for a drink and was happy they had some TVs showing the college football games that day. I have two things that prevented this from being a 5 star review: 1) there was no sign we could see, so we weren't entirely sure we were in the right place. 2) there is no valet and if you know downtown Nashville traffic, that automatically increases stress and anxiety! All in all, great experience.

Oh my gosh. As a book lover, this place gives me all kinds of nostalgic feels. This little gem is along Mass Ave but is tucked away in its own little corner. It's warm, friendly and a great little place to hide away for an afternoon. I attended a book discussion here one summer afternoon and enjoyed looking at the large children's selection that was available. They accept donations and have all sorts of genres. The gently used books were reasonably priced. 

I'll definitely return to look around more and to enjoy being in the presence of other folks who still enjoy books in print like myself.

Don't let the other reviews turn you away from this place! Honestly I was hesitant to go there to buy a birthday cake but I am SO glad and thankful that I did! I got a 8" single round birthday cake-chocolate chip pound cake was the flavor because that was one of the gluten free options they had! 

The cake was BEAUTIFUL! I was blown away when I saw it. And it was only $25! It was beautifully decorated and DELICIOUS!!!! 

Also, I tried their pumpkin spice cupcake, chocolate chip cookie, and mini red velvet cupcake. Everything was amazing. The pumpkin spice cupcake was basically a spice cake cupcake with this amazing spiced cream cheese frosting. I'm not sure exactly what was in it but was not your ordinary plain cream cheese frosting. I loved all of them. 

PLUS- they had samples at the bakery when I visited! They had their nut bar (so good) and their crumb cake (I took 2 samples because it was so good). I will definitely be going back!

Finally had a chance to try this place after walking by for a year. 
Since I came on sat at noon I wasn't surprised to see a line at the door. It was about a 35 min wait but considering how small the place is, they are able to squeeze in a fair amount of people. There is also an outdoor space in the back that appeared covered so that's promising.
The service was decent here but very busy so it was hard to get the waiters attention.
Now onto food.
First of all, their coffee and beverages were lovely. My friend got the aussie iced coffee which had espresso,vanilla ice cream and whipped cream. This was divine. I ordered a classic cappuccino which was perfect.
For our entrees I got the brie scramble which was yummy but I would prefer the chili sauce on the side for future reference - it's very sweet. The brie was delicious though. Also my friend and I were obsessed with the chip fries.
My friend ordered their daily special which was the maple bacon walnut French toast. He loved everything about it but didnt like how the walnuts were salty. Probably too much of a contrast for his preference. Overall a cozy spot that I would come back just to get some aussie drinks!

I have been exploring 118th Avenue a lot lately and am absolutely loving some of the  discoveries I've made there!

Swiss 2 GO is a very clean and bright restaurant that serves pasta, sandwiches, soup and desserts. The place is small, and holds about 3-4 tables.

As soon as my friend and I walked in, we were greeted warmly by the lady behind the counter, who waited patiently as we went over the menu selections. I was starving, and couldn't wait to try the Thanksgiving sandwich (Turkey, brie, cranberries, red peppers, lettuce, etc.). 

It arrived on a gorgeous pretzel bun (perfectly crisp/chewy exterior, with a soft tender mouthfeel on the inside) and LOOKED incredibly fresh; I knew it was going to be a delicious sandwich. 

The ingredients were vibrant, fresh, and clean-tasting. The simplicity of the ingredients made it all the better. Served alongside potato salad that contained fresh dill, apples and pickles, it was an ultra-satisfying, yet light and clean-tasting meal.

For dessert, I ordered a selection of pastries to share with friends at a picnic. I wasn't impressed with their layered cakes (we tried banana and chocolate) but their puff pastry shells filled with vanilla custard and topped with blackberries were delectable! Go for the cream-filled pastries for sure!

The prices here were reasonable at about $6-10 per lunch (small sandwich and potato salad) and the service was extremely warm and friendly. I loved Swiss 2 GO and can't wait to go back for a sandwich and salad!

We stopped here for lunch this past weekend when it was sunny and high 60s out! What a delicious little spot with simple, wholesome food choices. We both ordered noodle bowls (he the pork belly and me the chicken) and the basil lemonade drink. For the portion size it's generously priced! And we love that it's made with simple, healthy ingredients...no frills yay! Great little outdoor seating area for those warm, sunny spring days! We will both be back!

If you haven't,  you need to roll on over here! 
My first time having rolled ice cream, and what a fun experience! Ice cream is fun already but to have it rolled in, what looks like roses to me, made it so cute looking! 

I asked the gentleman behind the counter what a fan favorite was and he said the Strawberry Sweet Cream. And strawberry anything is my favorite, so I had to try! 
It reminded me of cheese cake! I loved it! 
While I waited for my ice cream to be rolled into perfection, my mouth was watering for some chocolate! So I rolled over to the chocolate case and picked out some goodies! 
I got the fan favorite Sea Salt Carmel and Lemon Raspberry.

Keke's is a great breakfast place. They have a good selection of food. I used to go there since I was a student at USF and it is still one of my favorite breakfast places. During the weekend this place is crowded. They have pretty big portions. Their food tastes great! My favorite is the Buffalo chicken omelet. And I love their french toasts.

I haven't tried the food here yet, but I can already tell this will be a neighborhood favorite for me. Stopped by for a date and got a Naples butter pecan latte. I was pleasantly surprised by the live music in the back- this kind of thing is why I moved to Nashville! 
It has the cozy ambience of a friendly local diner with coffee beverages that are a little more fancy. 
The touchscreen jukebox was another nice touch that added to the atmosphere. 
If you want a place to go that isn't a bar that's open after 8, this is a really lovely choice.

First visit to this Jamaican themed resturant for lunch. I had a quick grilled Shrimp Salad. The spices on the Shrimp were excellent! The greens were fresh and an assortment of arugula and other dark greens. It also had a generous amount of sliced avocado. The other offers are very authentic Island cuisine such as Oxtail soup, Jerk chicken and some American twists like Jerk Chicken Quesadilla and Jerk wings. The take away from this small, quaint restaurant is it is a friendly, casual place with really cool people that work there. While I was there the server and order taker as well as the cooks were definitely from the Islands and super friendly. You will feel very welcomed and they are happy to have you in their restaurant!! I love and appreciate this gratitude and hospitality in any place I spend my money!! Go and check it out order a few dishes to get a taste of Jamaica have some extra time because they do run on Island time and Cheers! Bonus - really cool Regge was playing!

I think it's the adorable sign that brings in the customers. Pretty small but cozy restaurant. We never have to wait but there's a strict no outside food or drink policy. The rest room is one and gender neutral. Always have to wait to wash your hands and it's usually dirty. 
But the restaurant has some good food. I come here for the soup dumplings and scallion pancakes. I love scallion pancakes! The dumplings are fine. Nothing to die for but tasty. They are a bit too doughy for my liking. My friend said they were too oily. But they come at a good price and you still leave with a warm feeling in your tummy.

Wow. Simply wow. The cafe serves great light bites especially on 1st and 3rd Sunday when they do specialty "pop ups".

I had a sausage veggie quiche which was excellent. Another of our crew had the Mediterranean quiche (which was to die for) and our member had a housemade cranberry muffin. 

I found this cafe from the ABSOLUTELY incredible catering they did for my daughter. The staff, the precision, and THE FOOD - omg  the food was SO succulent and incredible. 

They went over top for vegan dishes for our guests AND still satisfied the carnivores! 

Their herbed shrimp and the fish (2 HARD dishes to cater well) were fresh and spoke to Florida flavors and seemed like Fresh Connection plucked them from the sea and roasted them with love.

I have worked with catering companies many times - NO ONE does it like these guys. It's just that Good. Call 'em - use 'em - enjoy some of the best catered food anywhere.

'Nuff said. Foodie Ninja Clan Approved!

My Wife and I stopped in Aqimero located in The Ritz Carlton in Philadelphia. We were blown away immediately. The atmosphere is just absolutely gorgeous. It was just a fantastic, cozy little spot that creates the most Amazing Latin inspired dishes. 
The hostess seated us immediately and the Waiter Bobby came to our table promptly. He was one of the most professional and courteous Waiters we have ever come across. 
The dishes we ordered were absolutely unbelievable. Everything we had was top notch. 
We ordered the Picanha as our main dish. It came out exactly as we ordered it and was Melt in your mouth delicious. The sides were just as good. We ordered the potatoes and asparagus, they were absolutely perfect. 
We also got Grilled Spanish Octopus which was so good. I have never had it before and I am now regretting what I have been missing all of these years. I had a Stuffed Poblano pepper stuffed with chorizo, rice and Monterey cheese. I wish I ordered two. The prices were pretty reasonable considering the quality of the dinner. I would definitely recommend giving them a try. My Wife also had a few different cocktails and she enjoyed all of them. I would love to go back and try their breakfast. If it is as good as the dinner I think we would enjoy it very much.

We had just finished up at The Wilson County Bank in Gladeville having pictures with Santa along with all the cousins. I have an idea! Let's go to Providence in Mount Juliet and eat burgers! Yeah, let's just hop on over there and have dinner real quick...

It is about 5-ish, so we head that way from the Gladeville community. We zip along on Stewarts Ferry Pike to South Mount Juliet Road. Cool! But THEN we hit rush hour traffic along a lonely two lane highway - well not THAT lonely as traffic was backed up almost from Stewarts Ferry Pike to Central Pike. I'll wait until you pull up Google Earth before typing any more...

Done yet? It's a long way isn't it? It takes about thirty minutes until we crest the hill after Central Pike and see the lights of civilization. We get to the restaurant around 5:45 - again - ish. I put in our name, give my phone number and await the anticipated text message which I was told would be 20 minutes. They appear short on servers at this burger place as several tables become vacant. Eventually others are sat - people that appear to have come in after us. I approach the host - "I'm sorry, I entered your phone number wrong - we have been trying to get in touch!" Someone in the 615 area code just asked his wife, "Did you order a table? It's ready!"

This turned out to be a blessing in disguise. Our daughter notices the man behind the bar as someone she knows - one of the managers. She knows his wife and knows that just yesterday he was suffering from an extreme stomach bug.  So I'm trying to get us a decent table and my wife says, "We are leaving!" Wait? What?! I'm about to score us some free food!" We get outside and they explain why we are leaving. 

What now? Mexican, Chinese? Me, "What about Cori's Dog House?" Silence. Again, "What about Cori's" No response. "I said what about...." "We heard you - just hoping you would get the hint."  Someone mentions Indian. "Cori's has an Indiana Hot Dog!" My lip stopped bleeding in a few minutes, good luck getting that blood stain off her coat sleeve, though. 

This was our first visit as well as our daughter to Persis Biryani Indian Grill - you probably forgot by now which restaurant I was reviewing. My son-in-law had been along with our one year old grandson about two years ago - just seeing if you were paying attention. Were it not for the food and obvious ethnicity of the staff, you would not know you were in an Indian restaurant. The inside is sleek and modern with lots of stone, modern chairs and white laminate - bright, but pleasing. We were sat immediately. Indian food has flavors that appeal to a certain palette. Or if you are like my wife you had some really bad Indian food a few decades ago and never gave it another shot.

This time she goes WAY out on a limb and orders the Saag - just kidding - she gets this every time - she also locks her car when it is in the garage - so go ahead and analyze her. They have butter chicken AND chicken tiki masala which I had thought were the same, but were different here. Here they use ghee instead of just run of the mill butter. It imparts a nutty flavor - slick, huh? I read it on their wall. Our daughter orders the butter chicken - now it is her favorite to date - and Indian food is now her favorite. If you follow my reviews - and who doesn't - you know that she or my wife thought they wouldn't like it. There is the aforementioned reason in regards my wife and then there is her negative influence on her daughter all these many years. I am surprised DHS didn't pull her from our home, but she is almost 30. Daughter's husband orders the avocado curry, medium spice. He loved it! Now me - I tried to explore and decided to order the restaurant namesake dish - biryani. I get it with chicken and find that they don't have degrees of heat when preparing this dish. A slight language barrier with the server and he was finally able to explain that to me - I was asking what spice level - he was saying no spice eleven. He assured me it was spicy. It comes with riata yogurt and pepper gravy on the side. It is a large portion of basmati rice and lightly breaded chicken.  Good, but I would probably not order it again. I find I prefer the dishes that are sauce heavy. Good, but different. We ordered garlic and bullet naan. Bullet naan is very spicy! The garlic was delicious as well. Our daughter loved dipping the garlic naan in the sauce of her butter chicken. I did too, until my wife told me to leave her (our daughter) some...

Kid's meal is basically boneless tandoori chicken served with either white of fried rice or noodles. Lots of green onion so you might tell them to lighten up on that - otherwise the one year old ordered that - spicy level 3 - kidding. We said we might get the kid's meal next time. Our daughter had to tell her husband to leave him (their son) some...you women! It was that good. They leave a carafe of water at your table which is good and our server was great, but MORE WATER!

I know a couple local magazines have been calling Reeds American Table best restaurant of 2015 and I've been itching to try it out. I went to Reeds with two coworkers using a Seat Me reservation. We went on a Wednesday night and the place was packed! We had to wait about 5-10 but they quickly got us a table ready upstairs. 

The main floor is pretty packed. They don't do the communal table thing, thank god, but you might be dining close to other guests. The upstairs is AMAZING. It feels like you're dining in a fancy living room. It's a tasteful space that sets the mood for any occasion. 

For starters, we shared the breaded cauliflower, fried green beans, and Barbacoa. For my main meal I had their cheeseburger. Don't judge me, I love fancy burgers. The fried green beans and cauliflower were my favorite out of the starters. My main meal was amazing. The meat was juicy/tender and it was served on a nice fresh bun. The fries were served with a decadent aioli that calmed my inner fat kid. 

And don't worry, they serve craft cocktails. Right now they have a hot toddy drink served with honey and ginger. It's sooooo goood. I hope to recreate it at home soon with some Marker's Mark bourbon. If you're looking for something else, you'll find it. Their drink menu is expansive to say the least. Seriously, it's massive. 

The staff was extremely friendly. There was a bit of delay getting our drinks out because the bar was so backed up but that was the only bump in the entire experience. Reeds is already my new place to impress friends looking for a quality meal.

A visit to St. Louis is not complete without a concrete from the famous Ted Drewes. Today the temp was 98 and it was definitely a day to get something cool. We drove in and as expected the lines were long but, were moving. We checked the menu on the side of the building and I decided on the "Cardinal Sin" concrete. Chocolate and cherries. My wife loves a "Hot Fudge Sundae". So we walked over to the walk up window and ordered. Within a minute we had a delicious treats and we were on our way. We are only visitors and it is too bad we don't have one of these locations where we live. I would visit a couple of times a week. If you are visiting the city make sure you try one of their 3 locations.

I really like the atmosphere in here. Nice decor and music. Loved the coffee ceremony set up at the enterance.  Service was nice but really slow and I am not sure why. We were one of two tables there. 

Food was good and the general usual for Ethiopian cuisine. We ordered the vegatarian combo and Special Kitfo.  We also ordered the peanut soup.

We found the peanut soup was  too sweet and I didn't finish mine. The rest of the food was really good though. I especially loved the Yesimir wot which is spicy red lentils. My husband loved the special kitfo. 

It  was great, but I am not sure based on price whether it was either it was better of worse than the other Ethiopian places we went.

Oh and give the spiced tea a try. Although it came almost after half our meal was done.

This was our first dinner on our trip to New Orleans.  We were tired and very hungry from our travels and the staff was incredibly welcoming and quick.   I really appreciated that they asked for our vaccination card as soon as we stated we wanted to eat here.  They sat us a table in the courtyard which was quiet and peaceful.  The service was fast which we appreciated being so hungry.  I loved the selection of wines and we ordered one from France to share and it was delicious.   We started with the baked brie with roasted garlic cream sauce & coulis & balsamic reduction and it was delicious.  We could have used a bit more bread though so some of our brie did go uneaten but that's ok.  My sister ordered the Mushroom De Vin with chicken, I got the angus medallions and my friend ordered the Boudin Sausage link.  It was all tasty but I think the angus medallions were a favorite.  The courtyard here is such a nice of breath of fresh air near the wilds of Bourbon St. and with little places to find good wine, this is a must-go to spot!

On one hand, I love this location because they always do my returns quickly once I get to the till (I often purchase items from BR, ON, and Gap online because its SO MUCH CHEAPER and then return to stores), but it often takes super long to get to the till because there only ever seems to be one girl on cash. 

I've looked around a few times, and have actively had to get somebody to help me find a size or open a change room for me. I don't love being coddled and followed around in stores, but I would like a little bit of service. 

I think it's a by-product of being in WEM, but I also find their stock really picked over. They're typically out of items in my size or don't even have certain items that they do online.
Although I love their calamari salad and boozy milkshakes everything else I have tried here isn't thrilling. Yes, it is comfort food but I don't think it's good enough for what they charge.

This market is excellent! I fell in love with it from the moment I walked in. My shopping list included: kaffir lime leaves, Thai basil, jasmine rice, Thai chilies, rice noodles (cooked or not), garlic/chili sauce, bean sprouts, and maybe a few other things.

I got all of this and some more for less than $16.00. 

The only thing I couldn't find was green papaya, which apparently doesn't exist in this city? Oh wellz, I'll get over it. =]

Crazy to say and some may be baffled but this is my favorite Dollar Tree in Nashville!  It is the smallest and the junkiest BUT this store has a great bread selection, if you can get in early!  I love Spoleti bread and when you get it for $1, that's a steal!  The staff are friendly enough but very laid back, hence the clutter.  Since this is the smallest of all the stores, there isn't much selection and there is no freezer/cold food section.  I don't spend much time browsing here, just come for the bread!  I only hit this store once every two weeks so I often miss my chance for Spoleti.  It's just not as convenient of a location for me anymore.

These food stores tend to be big but pricey compared to other supermarkets in the area.  Just my perception?

My favorite thing about THIS location is the beer garden!  Beer beer beer!
They have a large selection of craft beers and I love it! I even found my favorite beer here (Rogue Hazelnut) which I have had trouble finding on the west coast!

I also find that when I come here I am drawn to the sushi section, fo no particular reason at all.  I mean pre-packaged sushi is never as good as the freshly prepared stuff.   In any event, I got suckered in (again) to getting a sushi roll (see pic).  It was decent considering it was prepackaged and all and it sure was pretty to look at.

I will obviously continue to frequent this venue.

So, my friends are wanting to go to Peru, so I brought my travel photos and asked them to meet me at Azucar. Now inside is interesting, big dance floor, odd decorations and lights, and booths set out. I will have a disclaimer....if you want Columbian or Peruvian food eat here. For tacos or any other Latin American food...you probably would do just as well as somewhere else. This night we only ordered Peruvian food. We ordered Ceviche - which I loved but everyone else was squeamish  for.  It was fresh fish that is marinated in peppers and that is how it is cooked. Not great if you don't like raw fish..but this is exactly how I remembered it in Peru. I don't think anyone else does this in the city.   We also had Papa A La Huancaina -Steamed potatoes served with huancaina sauce (feta cheese, garlic, spices, and a hint of aji amarillo), garnished with boiled egg and black olives). This, everyone loved, and I suggest if you are new to Peruvian food give this one a try. We also tried  Azucar Jalea which was assortment of fried seafood which everyone seemed to enjoy as well. Another surprising win was the antichuchos - marinated beef heart.  I love this dish,and actually everyone also hesitantly enjoyed it too. Our server was attentive and lovely.  If you want to try some authentic Peruvian food try this!

Thortons is my current preferred gas station out of this 3 gas station (soon to be 4) section of Ulmerton. They have a pretty large drink and food selection which makes them the logical choice for my work breaks (I work overnight and I am mostly limited to gas stations and McDonald's). 

The inside of Thortons is rather large and they have a wide variety of snacks. I have adopted an addiction to the Herr's Jalapeno Popper cheese doodles that I find here. Their wraps, salads and sandwiches are decent. While they are not the best thing to eat for lunch, I like them better than the other 2 gas station choices. I love that they have a large tea and soda selection and that they have syrups you can add to them. They even have soft serve and Shushies!

My first review of Bailey's Range was 3 stars and last night's experience was definitely worse so I'll go with 2 stars on this.  When 1. we're seated by an emo hostess who ignored my first query about where to find the loo, when 2. it takes 45 min to be served dinner, when 3. the compensation for the wait is a plate of stale fries after we've already ordered onion rings, when 4. the bill includes an extra drink charge, and when 5. the manager has to apologize for a 15 min delay for paying the bill because their bank has a limit on the number of credit card transactions/day, I draw the conclusion that I don't want to visit again.
Sure, I love the hipster decor and vibe but I wouldn't ever pay for that experience again.
All that aside, if you still decide to go, here's a rundown of what we ate:
1. smoked onion rings -- good with a more tempura fry, not salty enough for my taste but a nice, new take on an old item
2. small salted caramel shake with choc sauce -- VERY good though the small was PRETTY small and, therefore imho, overpriced
3. PB&J on gluten-free bun ordered medium -- the bison burger was cooked nicely medium, the goat cheese and jam toppings were sparse, and the bun was decent but pretty bulky and difficult to fit in my mouth
4. Dave's Smoked Burger on gluten-free bun -- again, decent but the burger was too small for the bun
5. small peanut butter ice cream shake -- again, PRETTY small though tasty although I wish the peanut butter had been blended in better and wasn't left in chunks
6. comped fries -- I had these on my first visit and found them stale; they were stale this second time around, as well

I have only been here once but I loved everything about it.  There is plenty of seating and the service was great.  The food was amazing. My boyfriend and I split a rice bowl.  I loved the falafel and the garlic sauce.  One bowl was the perfect amount for us to share.  They have a lot of great things to add to the bowl like hummus.  I definitely plan to go back.

Calling all dessert lovers!!! ALERT: Delicious things ahead!!! 

I have visited KRĒM twice now. During the week for lunch it was a little quieter, however Sunday night they were poppin! 

I absolutely love the unique Asian inspired flavors. I have sampled every combo and flavor, all good. The matcha ube swirl is my favorite. The ice cream is the perfect texture and consistency. Yum!

The shop has a very fun laid back vibe. Clean, sleek, insta-famous and social media worthy decor ;) 

The owners Casey and Alyssa are so friendly and genuinely passionate about their business. Casey is very engaging and has great convos with the KREM patrons. We'll be back!

So I'm giving this place 3 stars because while it's so much fun, the service is really lacking. 

I've been twice now and both times were so much fun, until the last one wasn't. First off, the cover is high and fluctuates $15? $20? depends on the night. I get it, this is one of the only legit after hours spots, but it's still Philly. The drinks are also kind of high in price. 

I love that there are 3 floors with different music- depending on your mood you can choose a room and still have fun. 

Now the trouble. The last time I was there, it was Friday and not crazy busy, but a decent sized crowd. I had a bit to drink, but I wasn't very drunk. I could still walk, function and all just fine. My friends and I went down to the bottom floor to use the bathroom and while going down, one of the bouncers took my arm and escorted me out. I didn't understand what was going on until we got outside and he said I had to leave. What?! He said I was stumbling on the stairs and too drunk to stay. Like dude, I have on 4 inch heels, your stairs are uneven, it's dark and I'm not 100% sober, of course I'm going to teeter. But, he didn't care. I told him my friends and my stuff were still inside and he told me to call them and tell them to meet me outside. Their signal in there isn't the greatest and my calls kept going to voicemail and my messages were waiting to send. It's winter, the middle of the night, and while there are people around- including a few bouncers- I'm still a young woman alone. I'm crying when my friends come out and a manager walks up asking what happened. I told him and he kindly apologized for the situation and told us we could go back in if we wanted. This is after I stood outside for about 20 minutes. Ugh. 

This was a real turn off. I had a lot of fun the first time and the second before this whole ordeal, but I don't know if I'll be back.

Stopped in with a friend and had drinks.  It's a pub, not much more I can say. it was loud...really loud. It was a saturday night and crowded. Our server was nice, but not too friendly. She brought our drinks timely and checked on us. 

My friend orders the same thing every time...the wings. She loves them.  Since I had never been before, I didnt know what to expect. I ordered a salad and fried mushroom sticks?!?!  The mushrooms were really good. The sauce that came with it was a little spicy, and really good.  My salad on the other hand was my own fault. Who orders salad at a pub. This chick right here. The balsamic dressing tasted like straight vinegar....ruined the entire salad. The salad probably would have been good with a different dressing. Oh well!  Lesson learned for when I return.

First time at this location and noticed other reviewers Say they offered a half order of the chicken and waffles. I ordered to share with my two-year-old but she devoured half of my half order lol. Needless to say it was very good I'm not surprised as the Castleton location is delicious as well. Love the strawberry butter will be back very convenient location and parking is free as well.

Great little stop just off The Fairway in Jenkintown! A menu filled with an array of salads (both prepared i.e. chicken, tuna, egg, shrimp and veggie fresh), sammies, soups, burgers, quesadillas, melts, wraps and comfort food staples. There's something for those indulging as well as veg-heads and the calorie conscious alike. The menu is especially adorable as many of the items are named after local neighborhoods and towns. Very cute touch! 

I used to stop on for lunch with my mom all of the time when I frequented the area more often and the Boca Raton salad was my go-to. It's grilled romaine with a big portobello atop drizzled with the sweetest, thick balsamic glaze. I loved the warm and cold ingredients together! So good! 

Most recently I stopped in for the prepared foods for din. While it all looked enticing and prepared with care, I wound up choosing grilled salmon which came with creamy tangy honey mustard and a big 'ol hunk of baked mac n cheese for hubs. He loved both but raved about the mac which he said was sweet, contained many different cheeses and topped with buttery breadcrumbs! I got the broccoli salad and it was THE best I've ever had! And it's dairy-free!!

 Davida the sweet owner was behind the counter helping me decide what to take home and giving me all ingredients in each dish as my family is made up of a bunch of P.I.T.A. Eaters. (Pain in the A**). She also told me exactly how to cook each item I purchased. Great customer service!

They have a delightful bakery with schneken, cookies, cakes and fresh breads too! Grab and go items like cheese and crackers, crostini and hummus too. 

I say it's a really great lunch option when in the area and a perfect spot for delicious prepared foods for din in a pinch!

We've had a couple of emergencies with our pets and this is the only place we'd trust with their lives. The staff actually loves animals and they know how to talk to their human parents. This will be our vet while we live in NOLA.

Sigh... I'm bummed because I know after writing this I'm going to be hungry. Seriously, nothing gets me hungry like the thought of dinner (or lunch... or brunch...) at Tony's.

I love to swing by during lunch and get the lunch buffet... you're in and out really fast, and the food does not disappoint. The buffet includes a signature chicken item, two homemade soups, a variety of pizza and pasta, as well as one specialty item each day (boneless hot wings, BBQ burgers, or toasted ravioli)... AND IT'S $8.99.

Dinner is a whole other story! If you're a steak lover, this is where you need to be. The steaks are always perfectly done and topped with a steak butter only the gods of steak themselves know how to create. I was at a business dinner at Tony's once and took a bite of the steak, saying afterwards, "that was the best thing I've ever had in my mouth!" I enjoyed the entire rest of my steak, that is after the sting of the accidental and embarrassing innuendo wore off. I swear, you can't take me anywhere.

My usual way to go is the Hannah's Combo. It comes with a 4 oz. cut of house tenderloin as well as the Chicken Anthony, which is grilled chicken topped with provel cheese and a fresh lemon cream sauce. I also always have to get the white chicken nachos... Tony's is famous for them. I learned how to make them at home, but it's not the same.

As I predicted, I'm now hungry and it's 11pm. Anyone up for Tony's lunch buffet tomorrow?

It's always a great time here. On this occasion I did not eat, I just went for a few drinks and a lovely chat with a girlfriend. 

She order an iced cappuccino that she said was lovely, and I had a lemon granita. The granita was quite sweet for my buds, but after squeezing actual lemon into it...it was perfect.

The staff is always friendly and attentive. They have a great selection of food, drinks, and Italian gelato! 

From prior visits the salads are very good, I also had the gnocchi once with mushrooms! Truffle fries are yuk as well. This is definitely a great date night or just a good time with friends. Enjoy!!

Mmmmm, Lolita.  Light of my life, fire of my loins...

Okay, maybe that was an exaggeration, but I firmly believe the first paragraph of Lolita is one of the most magical things ever written and just wanted to share that.  Anyway, on with the review!

I went to Lolita for the second time last weekend with my boyfriend to meet his parents.  This is the sort of event that normally sends me into a nervous fit, but I kept my cool most of the day because I was so freaking excited to eat here!  Whether you want to call it Mexican or neo Mexican or Mexican influenced American, I don't care.  The food is seriously yummy.  We split some guacamole and fundido for an appetizer.  I would have eaten the guac with a spoon, but I was trying to make a good impression.  They all loved the fundido.  We also got a pitcher of blood orange margarita.  Boyfriend had the waitress bring me a glass with sugar and poured me some before adding tequila.  He said it would go really well with my meal.  At first I though a virgin margarita was kind of silly, but he was right.  Delicious.  It was such a good compliment to the spiciness of my salmon.  Everybody loved their meals.  The bittersweet chocolate pecan bread pudding I had for dessert was astoundingly good.  The flourless chocolate cake Boyfriend got was irrationally dry (seriously, there's no flour, how is it dry?). 

I would eat hear all the time if I could afford it, but I can't afford it.  At all.  Minus a star for price, Lolita.  My sin, my soul...

I recently had dinner here with one of my friends. Parking is located behind the building or across the street in the parking lot during the bank's off hours. The bar is cozy and it is one of those places that makes you want to get with a group of friends, order food, and stay awhile. We were able to snag a table in the back against the exposed brick wall. It was the perfect environment for us to catch up! My friend ordered the margarita and enjoyed it. We also ordered the fries and the poutine. I liked that the fries came with multiple dipping sauces. Neither of us have had poutine before -- and my husband loves to get poutine when we visit his family in Canada -- so we thought we would try it. While I don't think I would order it again, it was definitely tasty and a recommendation for people who do like poutine. The food comes from the Revery so it was all delicious. Bonus - you get complimentary popcorn. We will definitely be coming back with our husbands especially since the patio opened this past weekend!

La Patisserie is the the quintessential French bakery. The ambiance is so bright and lively it really highlights how beautiful the pastries and cakes are. It really makes you crave a hot cup of tea with other bourgeoisie.

I was stopping in after lunch at Union Loafers with a friend and was already stuffed but couldn't pass up on the opportunity to get something for later. Since the thought of food was a little much, I decided to try something I wouldn't normally get that looks pretty. Great logic, I know. 

I went with something that i'm 90% sure they called a  "Choquette", although I didn't know that was an actual thing. Maybe it's a signature item of theirs? Not sure. Regardless, it was amazing. I'm more of a chocolate lover but this decadent creamy baked good was legit. It had raspberry cream on top, filled with a really light custard like substance inside, all wrapped in a golden baked bowl. 

It was legit. I highly recommend checking this place out if you're a sweets lover or even looking for a gift for a special friend.

Amazing restaurant for birthday dinners! A dinner with a view? Absolutely. Flames in your face? Yup, you've got that right. The food was phenomenal and very filling! They even have sushi rolls, my favorite! 

The restaurant is clean and pretty big. They service was great and Mr. An even came to our table to say hi. He took a picture with our table and we got to take a printed picture home as a memory. I loved that!

We will be returning for more friend's birthdays!

What I have always loved about Sushi Garden is their unique lunch buffet. Where else in town can you get all-you-can-eat teriyaki salmon, seaweed salad, tempura, and various maki rolls? When I am really hungry for salmon and seaweed salad, I load up here. I'm usually not too crazy about Asian buffets, but because of how busy Sushi Garden gets, the food revolves fast. Usually the salmon is not sitting in the heaters very long before I eat it. The restaurant is centrally located in a nice area of town with plenty of parking in back.  Be careful, there are busy times and you may experience a short wait. I do not come here for their regular menu items and sushi because there are better options in town.

Loves:  

Breakfast...seriously good...the second day we even had eggs florentine...really nice selection. Sausage, waffles,  yogurt, cereal, breads, pastries, fruit... if you can't find something good to eat, you're not looking!

Friendly!  

  We always tip housekeeping everywhere we go.  This is only the second time that housekeeping has ever left a note thanking us for our tip.  Try it, and see!

  Also, how cool is it that they will even deliver groceries to your room if you want?  (see pic)

Likes:

Fitness Center was okay.  

Location very good for our needs.

Temperature control good.


Dislikes:

Small bed!  Ours could not have even been a queen. Pillows were so fluffy as to almost disappear when you put your head on them.

Fan comes on automatically when you turn the light on in the bathroom.  While it is nice to have a fan, it's LOUD, and in the middle of the night when you have to go, well, it could wake up everyone nearby!

So pitch black that I would suggest bringing a nightlight, and I've never suggested that before anywhere.

Pretty good dolphin watching experience, but not as good as The Little Toot at Clearwater Beach!  The shape of the pontoon, cannot and does not intrigue the dolphins the same way that the tug boat of the Little Toot can.  They love to jump, play and frolick in the waves, and this boat type doesn't get it as epic as the other boat.

My mom & I went out on their dolphin watching tour & I won the Dolphin Spotting Contest! (First-to-spot-one!) For the contest, I won my choice of any snack or beverage (they have pop, beer, chips, candy, lots of snacks) as my prize!
The real prize is being able to be out watching these majestic creatures on a boat in the sunshine with my momma! We LOVED Captain Jack & first mate (Florence?) The crew was awesome! Learned about the Dolphins, the area, history lessons, very educational and fun!
They play fun boat music in between teaching us factoids about the area, houses, people, lifestyle, water creatures, everything! Well worth every penny of the only Twenty Dollar 90 minute cruise! 
Fun crew, great atmosphere, we passengers were singing along, and having a great time on this fun adventure!

Definitely glad we went!!
Go for it!

Love!! This place is adorable. All of the tips go to a charity. I can't remember exactly what they said but either a portion or all of their proceeds go to a charity. Each of the owners children chose a charity and yhe money gets split between the charities. We ordered a flight and sat outside. The back patio was so cute. The wine was quite tasty.

I recommend trying this school if you're on a budget and have some extra time to spend getting your hair done. The school is easy to find, clean, modern, and comfortable. Caitlin Baird did my highlights and I love them! She listened to what I wanted and did a great job. The only complaint I have about this school is the way they do appointments on Saturdays. In fact, they don't take appointments on Saturdays. It's walk-in, first come/first serve. Saturday's are the only time some people have to get their hair done and it's very inconvenient to not be able to make an appointment since there's no guarantee of getting your hair done if you're a walk-in. The student's don't have to be there on Saturday, it's optional. So one Saturday they may have 10 students there, the next, only 2. The other 2 schools I've been to in the area take appointments on Saturday and that may be the only thing that makes me go to them instead in the future.

How we came to be looking for pasta is a long story... suffice to say...we considered many places and of course we consulted yelp. 
We chose this chianti for these reasons: tons of parking, has a patio, half price wine Wednesday, and has pasta. So away we went....
We were there before 6:00 so found ourselves with a choice of seating on the patio. 
We selected a $75.00 bottle of wine (for 3 of us ) and at half price...you can do the math...it was exquisite.  
The bread is fresh and crusty. The salad was crisp and the dressing tart and tasty. 
I halved my pasta dish and added a starter salad, it was all just the right amount.  
We had a lovely server who was sweetly attentive.
 In the midst pf our dining experience one of my companions said "I'm having a really good experience, the right amount of sun and shade and the good wine and service. We have to come back."

I love san roque! We were having a hard time getting appointments at another local vet and they were always able to accommodate us. We ended up switching completely. Our dog is very scared of the vet and they are very gentle and have been able to figure out how to look in her ears and eyes without sedation (cheese wiz is a great distraction- who knew?!). They are also open on Sundays. Once when they couldn't get our dog in for an emergency they were able to get us in immediately at the montecito pet hospital - both offices did a great job at communicating. I didn't realize they were part of a network (sb, goleta, montecito) which is another plus!

I've been anticipating the opening of Nothing Bundt Cakes because I've seen it posted in my feed from my yelper friends showing off all the delicious looking cakes and positive reviews about it, so it totally had my curiosity!

This is such a cute little place. Once you walk in the door you are greeted by the friendly staff who are quick and kind enough to give you a run down of what they have to offer in the world of bundt cakes.

They offer 8" and 10" cakes, tiered cakes, cute bundtlets, bundtlet towers, and bundtinis that look like cupcakes but they are mini bundt cakes. So cute! 

I think this place is going to do just fine here in the 805. The quality and freshness of the bundt cake is amazing! They had samples of the lemon, and let me just tell you it was amazing. I love lemon and this cake was perfectly moist, slightly sweet with that zing of lemon flavor, and the best part of all was the cream cheese frosting! I could actually eat the frosting because it wasn't overly sweet like they tend to be. 

I purchased three bundtlet cakes to share with my co-workers. The hard part was choosing the flavors, but I decided on lemon, chocolate turtle, and white chocolate raspberry. My co-workers were very surprised just as I was by how delicious these were, and like me they also agreed the cake and frosting were just right, and again not overly sweet. 

Shout out to Hashani S. for recommending the white chocolate raspberry flavor! It was delicious.

I will say the hard part about the cake was cutting it up into small slices since the cake was very moist and the frosting was creamy. Aside from that no complaints!

I look forward to going back to try more of their flavors. Definitely check this place out!

I love Detour! It's an awesome local spot that's just around the corner from my parents' house, so we come here a lot. I'm a big fan of their wings since they aren't heavily breaded, which is perfect for the low-carb diet I follow. 

Prices are fair for what you're getting-- average American bar food. I do wish they had more draft beer options, but I'm always able to find something I like. Free trivia is on Wednesday nights. There are always daily specials going on.

I'd hardly heard of poke a few months ago... Now it's the hottest new thing. Lines were reasonable at this establishment, and service was friendly, although it was hard to hear over the glass barriers.

The essentials: rice or greens, protein, one of five sauces, and toppings. I have only had spicy sauce, which gives a good zing to the bowls. You can also mix your proteins; I love the salmon, but all of the proteins are high quality. One improvement would be to include a non-animal product in the protein section. Toppings include such things as Hawaiian sea salt (of course), cucumber, radish, tobiko, mango, and pineapple. Everyone also gets some micro greens and a tiny tropical flower--yum!

Poke Bowl lets you choose a small or a large bowl, the variation of which lies in the amount of protein added (3 or 5 scoops). Unfortunately, both are served in the same sized plastic bowl (whether you're eating in or taking out), so it gets a bit cramped with the large. Otherwise, Poke Bowl is worth a trip to indulge in this delectable dish.

I was extremely surprised when I walked in to find my usual brand name products for such low prices! I was beyond excited, as this starving college kid loves any chance she gets to save a penny here and there. The staff was extremely helpful and gave me tips on their epic "case nights" with $5 case purchases. 
Things are a little overwhelming to sort through, but if you have the time to browse the isles, you might just find a gold mine. Case in point, an IPad docking station for $50! 
In any case, give these folks a shot for your thrifty shopping needs!

16 check ins and a Duchess/Duke rivalry with my hubby behooves me to review one of my favorite bars in town. I really enjoy coming here to get a warm smile and big greeting from owner and talented bartender, Dylan! 

Since "Home Means Nevada" to me, it's great to be surrounded by all things Nevada in this casual, yet eclectic decor with wood benches, Victorian loungers, and saloon style bar. I also enjoy the chandeliers and pic of honest Abe. 

Snack on some popcorn or grab a menu from nearby local establishments if you come with an appetite. Get a refreshing drink of cucumber water during your visit or for your DD's. Pick a board game or two, or request a sporting event on one of their tv's, or simply enjoy conversation in a semi intimate setting. 

My favorite thing to do is challenge Dylan with my craving of the day, whether it's give me something with grapefruit or ginger or spank some basil or hit me up with something spicy! Dylan's creativity and imagination is endless and my tastebuds are never disappointed. 

I love that he offers a family friendly atmosphere 3-8pm, so if you're out and about with littles or teenagers, you can stop in for a quencher or a quick game. And in this summer heat, sometimes a quaint little break makes the day! 

I also love that Dylan gives back to the community through special events at 1864. It could be shining on awesome people in our city, like Debbie McCarthy and Leslie McCarroll, owners of Bliss Babe Magazine, who threw a blue and green party to help a friend in need. Or it could be a fundraiser helping little ones like Baby Grayson fight cancer. 

This bar is ever evolving to keep up with being the best of the best in Reno! Come check it out and keep coming to enjoy all the great changes! And tell Dylan I sent you! :)

So I'll be honest. We got takeout from here primarily because it was one of the few places that were open on Thanksgiving. We actually tried to order from 2 other restaurants before hitting Thanksgiving jackpot with Sher-e! Much like any Thanksgiving meal we were quite stuffed by the time we were done and I definitely needed to nap off all those good eats. 

We shared the mushroom chicken, chicken biriyani, mixed vegetables and some naan. It was all very securely packaged for takeout in a mix of white paper box (Plain basmati rice) and round plastic containers for the curries and biriyani. The naan was wrapped in paper and foil. 

I loved the seasonings and spices in each dish. We requested it mild spice and I felt they delivered just the right amount. It was still a little spicy but just a subtle little hint of it in each entree. The white rice was soft and fluffy and while the biriyani was good flavor wise, I thought the rice was just a tad overcooked. The naan itself was a little unevenly cooked as one piece was still a little doughy in the center but had black charred bits in the thinner parts of the bread. Seems like the oven it was cooked in was too hot perhaps? 

Portions were plentiful and it was enough to satisfy 2 adults and one toddler with leftovers to spare. If I were craving Indian food, whether on a holiday or not, I feel like Shere-e is a solid choice.

For a chain restaurant, they are great! They have excellent Happy Hour specials. (3-7pm and 10-?pm)
My husband and I went there, had 4 appetizers, and 4 drinks, and our bill was only $35. Plus, we downloaded the app and got an amazing Pazookie for Freeeeee! LOL The stuffed mushrooms are great, the potstickers, the tuna poke as well. He loved the root beer wings.
Friendly staff and service. Overall a very good experience! 
***I have now visited here 4-5 times and only at the bar.

This is not your standard Americanized Chinese restaurant. Definitely not a orange chicken and beef broccoli kind of place. This is more like the kind of authentic Chinese food I grew up eating!

I finally decided to try Chef Wang on a night that I was craving green onion pancakes and Taiwanese beef noodle soup. I live on the west side and Chef Wang's came up on Yelp when I searched "green onion pancakes" so after checking out the reviews my husband and I decided to give it a chance. We were not disappointed! 

I was immediately excited by the fact that they had Xiaolongbao! Soup dumplings are hard to come by in Tucson! I think on their menu they called it "small steamed bun - 10 pc."  We got an order of those, the green onion pancakes I'd been craving, the spicy beef noodle soup, and the salt and pepper ribs, all family style. We also got a pitcher of beer. 

Just re-capping everything we ordered is making my mouth water all over again! Both the green onion pancakes and the spicy beef noodle were *exactly* what I was craving. So flavorful! When my husband and I bit into the ribs, all we could say for a good minute was, "Wow!" The ribs were perfectly salted. My husband couldn't stop raving about them! 

My only "complaints" are that I wish they had given me a dipping sauce with my green onion pancakes, and that I wish there had been more bok choy in the spicy beef noodle. The latter is more of a personal problem though as I just love a lot of bok choy and typically need to order "extra" veggies anyways.

Service is standard for any good, non-American restaurant. It's similar to how some people say the hole-in-the-wall restaurants typically have the best food. In my experience the trade off is usually giving up an attentive server for the most amazing, authentic food. I'm 100% down for that trade-off and typically if I sit down and I realize service is that way, I have my strategy locked and loaded. I keep a mental list of everything I might need in the future and ask for it all at once. Napkins, sauces, extra drinks before we need them, and if there's something I think I'm forgetting a polite "I think that was it but can you please come check back in 10 minutes?" usually suffices! 

I think during our visit we were checked on a total of 4 ish times from start to finish, but I was too enamored by our delicious food to need anything but space anyways. Trust me when I say we will be back.

Ordered some for super bowl weekends. It's the best decision I've made in a while. The wings were crispy perfection! perfectly season and sauced. I love the gold wings, I've tried the Asian heat and teriyaki which was a little too sweet for me. The gold is by far the best. The naked was crispy perfection and nicely season! The rolls are drench in honey butter so your better off making this a cheat meal! The service is great they are always super friendly, everyone was wearing masks properly. The price and value you can't beat. Ghot Wingz is probably one of my go-to places.

My only complaint is it's pretty hard to see the location. I recommend checking out google map first so you know where to go.

My very first experience  here was a disheartening mess.  My request for a vegan dish was completely disregarded and my sandwich and salad both came out covered in cheese.  The waiter wad beyond annoyed at me because I didn't want the cheese I specifical l yw asked them to leave off and I had no intentions of ever returning.  I can look over many thsings, just not rudeness.
        A friend urged me to give them another try and I am glad I did.  Our bartender was a very lovely young lady who listened to my request for no cheese and assured me there would be none.  She provided attentive, friendly, cheerful and accommodating service.  The food was delicious, the beer fantastic and I was really thrilled with this place.  
        There is typically a great crowd here - friendly and social.  It does get a little packed so be prepared to stand for a hot second until a chair or table opens up.  All in all I am very happy I gave Farm & Fisherman a second chance.

The only Korean restaurant in the area that does All You Can Eat bbq? Heck yes!! I already love rice for their korean bbq but now there's another reason to love them even more. Unlimited meat!!

For around $25 you get to eat as much meat and banchans you want. The food is still fresh and good quality. I'm getting hungry just thinking about it.

Come Hungry. Feast on.

Over $7 for a small 16 oz slender greens  smoothie. (spinach, kale, cucumber, pineapple, mango, chia seeds, and coconut water blended with ice) I love kale and spinach smoothies, but the taste of this one was very bitter, not what I expected for the price and listed ingredients. if I do go back, I would not get a smoothie, but I would maybe try a Açaí bowl. The staff was nice and quick with making my order. Inside was clean and Convenient with parking in the back and on the side. I enjoyed the decor, but I wasn't impressed with the smoothie

Came here with a friend last Thursday night.  Just walked right in.  I ordered the brisket with a salad and fries.  The brisket was delicious and tasty. Maybe could have been a little warmer.  The salad was a nice side salad fresh and amazing homemade ranch dressing I loved.  The fries are shoestring, but not too thin.  Overall, pretty good.  Prices seemed a little steep, but you also get a lot of food.  Will be back!

Love Willie Mae's and will never visit Nola without stopping in. Been to both locations and this one has more space so its my preference. The other location can be cold to the point where you have to eat with your coat on. Waiting outside in a long line at the othet location isn't ideal to me. The service was ok but the bathroom needs some attention. It was very stereotypical public bathroom. The food is the same at both locations. I had the fried chicken, red beans and rice, sweet tea and bread pudding with rum sauce. Ate here twice during my visit. Had butter beans and cornbread with my chicken the second go round. I wish you could pick your pieces but white or dark meat were the only options. I didn't mind so much but it would be nice to have options. The chicken is seasoned and fried to perfection. The bread pudding is outstanding but it took long for some reason. It was worth it and I will certainly go back. Check groupon because I got a great deal. Head they're putting one in the airport and I'm looking forward to that. I can bring some chicken home to savor the flavor.

My husband and I came here tonight not really knowing what to expect from the mixed reviews on Yelp.  We would be really happy to have a new dinner place close to our house, but it seems like most of the reviews on here are either love it or hate it, and not very much in between.  My experience was exactly in between.  It was not incredible, and they committed no egregious actions like hair in the food (though I did find some and freaked out until I realized it was a cat hair from my shirt).

We arrived, and there was a girl cleaning the windows on the doors.  She did not move or open the door for us.  She just stared at us, deadpan, through the window, as we walked in.  Maybe I have been playing too much Walking Dead, but I was reminded of a zombie.  Then she spoke and greeted us and my fears of an un-dead uprising were put to rest.

We were seated on a very wet bench.  I told my husband, Gabe, that my seat was wet, and the girl in the next booth apologized and made it clear she was cleaning the seats (no, no need to dry them.  My butt did the job just fine, thanks!)

Our server came over and asked for our drink orders.  I had never been here and kind of wanted to try the best of what they had.  I asked for a recommendation.  I got a list of six different drinks.  If anything it made my decision even more difficult.  I get it, and I appreciate his gusto, but I was looking for more, like, one or two of his favorites.

I got the Spiked Strawberry Lemonade and Gabe got the Texas Sweet Tea.  Both drinks are dangerous, in a good way!  They were super delicious and you couldn't taste the liquor.  If I didn't know there was liquor, I would easily have put down two or three quickly and then regret it later.  I must befriend the bar tender here and learn how to make the spiked lemonade.  Yummy yummy.

Gabe was excited over the cheese bite appetizer, and we got those.  I will say, I am not a big fan of fried cheese, be it mozzarella sticks, cheese curds or whatever other cheese you want to bread and fry, but these were pretty tasty!  The cheese tasted fresh, they were clearly freshly fried, yummy marinara sauce to go with them... for once in my life I was a fan of fried cheese!  Hooray!

I ordered the Dijon Chicken with Mushrooms with broccoli cheese casserole and red beans and rice as my sides, and Gabe got the New Orleans Pasta.  Our food took a little while to come out, but we were in no rush and having a nice time so it didn't really bug us.

Things get fun here.  Mine, on one hand, was just fine.  The red beans and rice were spectacular, the casserole was good and the chicken was cooked well with a tasty dijon sauce on top.  Gabe's pasta, however, was amazingly overdone.  I thought he was exaggerating, and I took a bite.  Yup.  Pasta mush.  The flavor profile was there, the meats were yummy, but the pasta, the main part of the dish, was so over cooked it was inedible.

We alerted our server, who was very nice and took it away to replace it.  I understand this is a new place and has kinks, and I was sure the pasta was just forgotten about in the water or something.
