Good for Asian cuisine lovers in the Philly burbs.

Nice staff and a really cool spot. Food looked absolutely amazing but we had already eaten by the time we got there, so maybe next time.

Of course, you go to Yards for the beer, and unfortunately, they just aren't that good. I'd call Yards beer boring and unimaginative. Even their seasonal brews were nothing to write home about. Tart wasn't very tart, the IPAs weren't particularly hoppy, and I thought the "Best of Philly" Lager shouldn't be called the best of anything.

It's tough to recommend Yards when you're so close to breweries that are vastly superior--Love City, Roy Pitz, Evil Genius, and Crime & Punishment up in Brewerytown.

I will definitely go again and try the food. I doubt I'll have more than a beer, though. I don't like to overpay for average.

The soups are SO GOOD! I wasn't impressed with the lox spread previously, but I later tried the ham and pea soup and it was the best pea soup I've ever had. It wasn't too salty. It had a really creamy pea taste. It also had a good amount of garlic in it. It was really delicious. and affordable at $4 for a small homemade soup. You can't get anything for this price and quality from a fast-food place like Wawa. I will be back because I love soup and will have to try more of their soup.

Ah Surreys, my initial NOLA brunch love affair. While others have come and gone you have remained a steadfast institution of veggie friendly brunchy goodness, so much so that even your hatred of credit cards can't keep me away. The long and short of it:

1. Biscuits and Mushroom Gravy. My favorite thing on the menu. I like this so much that we often order it as a side knowing full well that it could constitute a small meal. It's the perfect combination of think, savory, salty, mushroomy deliciousness. Totally worth it even if you can't eat it all.

2. Cash Only. They don't take credit cards here. There's an ATM on site but it comes with a $3.00 transaction fee plus whatever your bank charges for not using their ATM. Best to just come prepared with cash.

3. Bread Bread Bread. All of their bread items (toast, biscuits, bagels, etc.) are fresh baked and amazing. This is the real thing that keeps me coming back.

4. BYOB. They don't serve alcohol, so bring your own! We usually sport a bottle of champagne to pour into their freshly squeezed juices!

5. Juice Juice Juice. They offer a variety of fresh squeezed juice. Take my advice, a fresh apple-cucumber mimosa will make any morning. They also offer the addition of ginger or kale.

6. Veggies. Lots of veggie friendly dishes. The veggie burger is decent and the ginger tofu scramble is to die for.

7. Size. The place is tiny, popular, and doesn't take reservations. Pretty much any weekend before noon will result it a decently long wait.

8. Salmon. I used to order their salmon scramble and bagel plate with lox until I discovered Coulis further into uptown. Surreys isn't bad but it still pales in comparison (Coulis just tastes so much fresher). It really all depends on how much you want salmon.

Surreys is good enough to warrant a long wait that will involve a trip to the ATM. One of my original favorites that's withstood the test of time for even my fickle pallet. 

Overall Grade: B+

I love HopCat even though I live way in Avon I always make a trip to Broad Ripple to eat here! the Crack Fries yes Crack Fries are the best they will load them with cheese Cracked Pepper jalapenos even Ranch on the side to dip them in and they are superb. last night I had the angry bird with a side of Crack Fries absolutely a must and topped it all off with a cherry cider. They also have over a hundred beers on tap they do have for ciders that I do love because I am not a beer drinker, so they have a beverage for every taste bud.the staff here is always so friendly and you can even check in on Yelp so that way you don't have to wait in line . There is a parking garage located right above so you don't have to find street parking and it's only five bucks for up to 3 hours so you can't go wrong so stop on by get some Crack Fries and then go right down the street to Insomnia Cookies and have dessert there must to that you have to do together!

This restaurant liked The Shins before seeing Garden State.
This restaurant smoked clove cigarettes.
This restaurant had a zine in middle school.
This restaurant is cooler than you.
This restaurant has delicious food and cocktails.
This restaurant deserves your business.

I can understand why there's a line for this place. We waited with the other barbecue lovers for over a half hour on a recent chilly Saturday night. It was worth it. You can mix it up however you want to here...I opted for a 4 rib dinner, which comes with one side, and a 4 oz. portion of pulled pork. I got green beans for a side ( haricot vert...nice touch!) and added a side of their smoked 3 bean salad. I like the set up...place your meat order with the first person you meet, they plate it (or more accurately "tray" it) and send you on to the person who plates your sides, then on to the cash register and any add ons...bourbon vanilla caramel shake, anyone? When it's busy, however, this process can take a few minutes, and the meat was cold by the time I got to the table. That's my only complaint, and I prefer barbecue a touch under temperature to reheated meat any day, so it's a small one. 

I really like these ribs. They're meaty and nicely smoked, and whatever rub they use is slight. They also let you sauce them yourself, which I really appreciate. The coffee sauce worked well with the ribs, as it did for the pulled pork, which was equally delicious. The only other sauce I liked was the sweet sauce; the hot one didn't taste great to me, and wasn't spicy either. The sides were very good and thoughtfully prepared. There's some good cooking going on here as well as some nicely smoked meats. I'll definitely be back.

Gosh I Love Stores like these! You can be Fashionable and not break the bank! A friend introduced me to this store at another location and i fell in love! The I found out, there was one right by my house! It's Awesome! The store is so organized and I can definitely find everything I'm looking for! I just wish I had found this place when I was pregnant. They have Maternity Clothes which is wonderful. Go Check it out!!!

My husband and I were quite impressed by Royal House, a restaurant located in the French Quarter very close to Bourbon Street; we liked it so much we visited it a few times while in the area.
The atmosphere is festive, loud and super friendly; we sat both in the downstairs raw bar and upstairs balcony and were given the same courteous and attentive service by staff.
I love oysters and here I was able to satisfy my craving without breaking the bank! The oysters were plump, juicy and fresh and most importantly served at the right temperature. My husband fell in love with their French Onion Soup and Redfish Beignets! So delish!!!
We also tried their Chicken and Andouille Gumbo and Creole Shrimp dishes, both quite adequate.
I also had a chance to try their signature cocktail, Royal Cup, made by the one and only, Cindy, who's recipe could not be reproduced! A delight!
If you ever find yourself in the area do not hesitate to give the Royal House a chance!

I noticed this place the first time I went all the way up to this area to check out Cafe Soho as it's only about a minute away from it.  I love tofu and Korean food, and after reading the good Yelp reviews, I knew it was a place I had to check out especially now with Miga in downtown Philly being closed.  

The decor is all wooden and what I assume is old traditional Korean style.  We were seated immediately and given menus.  In less than a minute we were brought a pitcher of water and the waiter was ready to take our order.  However, I wasn't that familiar with the menu, so we weren't ready yet.  I decided on the pa-jun (Korean pancake), that I seem to order at every Korean restaurant I go to because I like it so much, and an order of the vegetarian mushroom soft tofu stew.  The waiter asked us if we were sure we didn't want seafood and not the vegetarian pajun.  I will eat seafood, but I'm not too fond of the octopus and squid that usually end up in Korean food.  I told him I preferred the vegetable one.

About 6 Banchan (Korean side dishes) were brought out including:  Kimchi, beansprout salad, seaweed salad, and a few other things that I'm not sure exactly what they were.  They were okay, but I've had better at other places. We were also brought a raw egg, which I assumed was for our stew.   Our food came out within five minutes, and then the waiter was never to be seen again until we flagged him down for a check.  

The pajun was okay, but only had scallions in it.  At other restaurants when I order the vegetarian one, other veggies like kimchi, peppers, mushrooms, or carrots are usually included as well, so that was a bit disappointing.  The tofu stew was good and boiling hot in temperature and spice, but I didn't think it was superior to ones at other restaurants.  I did like the rice in the stone bowl, but it was really hard to get it off the sides and no one came around and poured the warm water/tea in our stone bowl at the end of the meal like others had written about.  We also were not instructed what to do with the egg (I wasn't sure if it was for the rice in the stone bowl or the stew), and the server dropped off the food so quickly and ran off that I couldn't even ask.  I wasn't getting any 3G on my phone, so I couldn't check back here on Yelp, so I guessed and put it in the stew.  It tasted good though.

The best part of the meal was the low price.  We only paid a little over $20 for the whole meal for the two of us and we left feeling full.  I would go back if I was in the area for the stew again, but I don't think I'm going to drive out of the way for it since the service was a little lackluster and I can get similar dishes at other places.

I felt like doing some food exploring today so I "dragged" a friend with me to Kelp for lunch. We had never been there before but had heard good things. And if you read my reviews you know that I love to try new places. 

We had no problems finding it. It is in a plaza on Bay to Bay. It is the same plaza that Feet First (running store), Pilot Bank, Massage Studio, Starbucks, Soleil Tanning, and Taco Fusion are all in. 

When we arrived we were able to park right up front. They have some spots reserved just for Kelp customers. We were also pretty happy to see the outdoor seating because it was a gorgeous day out. A couple actually had their puppy with them at their table outside :) Note that there is also indoor seating. It's a small place and I'm not sure how busy they get but between the indoor and outdoor seating, you should be good.

Their lunch options are great. For $12 you get 2 full rolls, a miso soup and a ginger salad. I went with that option. My friend got 2 rolls (see my pictures) and she really enjoyed them both. And their lunch, all the way until 4pm!

Service was very nice. Everyone was very friendly. They were attentive and the service was nice and fast.

Basically, I'll be back for more :)

All of us in the office were craving carbs, so we opted for the best sandwich shop in Reno, of course! The four of us all tried a different sandwich, and everyone was super satisfied. The sourdough here is crave-able, and they have tasty sauces that really complete the flavor profiles of all their high quality proteins. Admittedly, even the Green Acres (vegetarian sandwich) looked too good not to try, in spite of the carnivore in me. We were all working, but each of us really wanted a 10 Torr... I guess I'll have to come back on a weekend for that lavender lemonade my boss can't stop talking about.

I tried their proprietary dessert bar, the dream bar, and that thing, paired with a glass of milk, would alone be worth a trip here.

Keep of the awesome work, Urban Deli! Reno loves you!

The food was good this is a self serve buffet. It's nicely decorated, however they had limited hours when I went. The owner and his family are loved super sweet. He did spill water all over my jacket which normally isn't a big deal but it was winter so kind of disappointing. Overall, I can't wait to visit again when I am back in town.

Jeez, where do I start?! First, I love seeing an owner present at the front of their establishment. He was super friendly and understandably proud of what he has built. This is not an average bbq joint and I love that! It has a few fusion twists like grillade bowls and multiple styles of sandwiches that cross from Cajun to southwestern flair. I'm going back specifically to try a smoked Caesar salad!!  

The sauce bar in the front is on point! So many differing flavors. The house bbq is delicious but my favorite choices today were the 5 cane and sweet heat sauces. Grab a few small containers and try them all! 

The meat honestly doesn't "need" sauce. It stands apart on its own. The brisket and pulled pork were perfect. The smoked sausage has a classic Cajun green onion flavor and available hot or mild. 

The coleslaw is very unique. It has pickled hot peppers in the mix that give it a spice and flare I haven't seen before and very much enjoyed. You have got to get the maque choux Mac n cheese. It's the best possible fusion between two amazing dishes and next time I'll order two so I don't have to share with my daughter! 

I will be back, sooner rather than later!

Pretty tired of having hotel lunches, I made my way to this area of town. Again thankfully to yelp I was able to find this place with ease. All the reviews to this place seem to be spot on. Love the decor first of all... wish I could add a picture of my pooch to the wall. Great selection of beers on tap and semidecent menu, mainly comprised of sandwiches. I went with the cheese burger and it was Mmmmm good. I think I've send this about most of my reviews in Philly but this burger so so moist and juicy that I still drool just thinking about. Kind of small burger, but it what it loses in diameter it gains in thickness. A very fulfilling meal and the fries (idaho and sweet potatoes mixed) were great compliment to the burger as well. My server/waitress was very kind and she always made sure to check up on me. 

Great time and I recommend this place to anyone who comes here.

Grocery store, fruit stand, sandwhich shop and gift shop????? - YES please! All in this huge shopping store.  Place was clean, employees were friendly and if you like Viet food, there's a banh mi shop toward the side if the grocery store.  Prices were very reasonable with banh cuon (a tray was only $9.99). Banh mi ranges from $3 to $3.50.....buy 10 get one free.  Love that they had Viet dessert.....I was in heaven.....

These tortillas do not taste gummy like some  tortillas out there. they're very nice and thin I love to burn them on the gas burner. Some say if you live in Tucson you are a tortilla connoisseur well I know I am these tortillas you can roll a burrow and if they don't fall apart even though they are tender then the average tortilla they have a great text you they're not burnt torn dude up like some that you get from the grocery store only ingredients are flour water shortening salt. I'm sorry to say they won't last 4 weeks like the store-bought tortillas. These are fresh like yo Mama's Kitchen.
They don't need preservatives additives in everything to extend the shelf-life for weeks because they don't even last a couple of days they're that good

The best tomato pie in the world! We love getting tomato pie for our family parties. All varieties are mouthwatering. The veggie, straight tomato, tomatoes and cheese & cheese & pepperoni are so good!  The rolls we get are always a party favorite too! I was so happy when I found out Corropolese was coming to Limerick! The tomato pie is always a much anticipated treat at our office parties.  I haven't tried their cookies or anything else but I sure would like too!!

Coming in from a Bellvue roadtrip we stopped in here at around 3.00 pm on a Tuesday.  There were still a few stragglers from lunch - the vibe is dark and soothing, gentle Moby tracks were wafting and the lighting low.  Service prompt and attentive, panko fried avocado appy was delicious with hot mayo.  The Wasabi roll was beautifully presented and tasty but devoid of wasabi, no matter plenty to dip into on the other plates.  The Maguro and Saba were both delicious and generously cut.  A ginger Martini thingy was quite lovely.  We split all this for $55, it seemed a little pricey and it is far from home but definitely A-OK.  Private rooms and hibachi tables available.

We went looking for a new stove and visited the usual big places.  We couldn't find what we wanted and decided to try Mark's.  I'm so glad we did!  They had just what we wanted and gave us a great deal.  Our sales person was very knowledgeable, way more the the big places.  He took awesome care of us and it was delivered within a few days!  I love my new stove!  If you are in need of appliances, I highly recommend Mark's.
Consistently solid sushi and terrific service, especially during the pandemic. Love that you can ask for "nothing extra" to reduce takeout waste!

A few years after my first review, this is still one of my favorite drink spots.  And eating spots now for that matter.  I used to love the spicy chicken sandwich--it was the only thing on the menu I would ever order.  I still love it, but NOW they have fabulous burgers too!

They use the same local beef (from Triple L Ranch in Franklin I think?) that Burger Up does, and Melrose has an excellent selection of cheeseburgers now.  It's great for Sunday "brunch" too--if you've got a good hangover.  I recommend the sunshine burger (think that's what it's called, something similar if not that)--a fried egg on top of the burger patty with cheese.  YUM and I can only eat it once a year unless I'm training for a marathon.  Can't imagine the calorie intake, but it certainly made me feel better after a particular heavy binge the night before.

Thursday nights, Melrose is still the place to be.  2 for 1 drinks and a big crowd--ranging from 20-40-somethings.  Laid back and unassuming, this is a favorite bar for sure.

This was my first time trying South Philly pizza, and it was something special. We ordered a plain cheese pizza and sausage/mushroom pizza. Both were good, but I'll always remember the sausage. Loved that it was sliced sausage rather than crumbled or ground. It had so much good flavor. My friend patted her sausage with napkin, but I thought it was just fine--a little grease adds flavor :)

Cute little tiki place located in Fountain Square.

The food: good tacos, apps and burgers. Menu is small, but the quality is fantastic. The in-house sauces are delicious and HOT. This is a good thing. 

The cocktails: I'm a big fan of tiki drinks, and the drinks here hit the spot. From margaritas to mojitos, these drinks hit the spot. Beer choices however, are lacking. With only 6-7 choices, and maybe one local selection, it leaves the beer lovers out quite a bit.

The service: service is hit or miss, sometimes. Servers are friendly, helpful and nice, but if sitting on the back patio it might be awhile before you see a server. 

The atmosphere: Super.Cool. It's island flair gives a welcoming air, Andy the copper bar tops and open design lets light stream in the inside seating area. The back patio is a great place to hang on a cool evening.

The pricing is a little more than I'd like - guacamole and chips, and tacos  are a little pricier than expected.

First thing about this place that caught me off guard was a lack of menu.  
Just...coffee?  That's just assumed by all who enter?

However, I'm not complaining [but I did feel a bit like a moron]; maybe I'm too American (read: Starbucks).  I just ordered a latte, got my sugar, and [luckily] found a seat to do some work.

The latte was thick and creamy.  The espresso was good--not bitter at all.

The little cafe has a modern European feel and the people watching varied greatly.  In my opinion, the set-up is a tad awkward in ordering, picking up your drink, and adding sugar, etc.  But, again, maybe I'm just not used to this type of setting.  I noticed a lot of customers took their coffee to go, here, so that feeds into the weird vibe.

Its almost not a coffee shop.  Yet it is, in the most literal sense.
But the constant to-goers sort of takes away from any coziness at this location. Especiallly when winter air is slapping you in the face with every door opening and closing.

 I enjoyed the experience overall, however, and can see why others love it.  I almost really appreciate the simplicity of it all.  They brew good coffee, and that's it.
  
(And at this price point, it definitely is good enough coffee)

Worth a visit!  The entrance fee was fairly inexpensive and the extra garage tour is worth the money as well.  They said they typically change the showroom cars every 6 months, I think.  This time they were showcasing micro cars.  Loved how the showroom was set up.  No overwhelming and so many cars to look at.  The garage tour was also very informative.

If you love European cars, this is the place to go!

When the pizza is so good you forget to take a picture until you've ate most of the 12 inch !  I have been to a couple of the Jockamo's locations and love the food and service but the Irvington location is our fav!  Service, food, and atmosphere are above expectations.  

Does not matter your taste in pizza, they have it all.  From your average pepperoni pizza to the Slaughterhouse (ALL the meats!) you will find a favorite here!  

And for the healthy peeps, they have an amazing pine nut salad that is definitely a go to for me!  

Parking is usually hard here since it is on a busy street but the lot in the back and the stores next door are cool with using their parking.  

If you haven't tried this place, check them out!  Michael in the bar was excellent!

I had my bridal hair styled as an Uptini by Kaylee at Drybar. I came in with a vague idea and she transformed it into a fairytale hairstyle with great texture, which is a feat for my fine hair. I posted a photo to show how beautifully the style held up throughout my wedding day. Kaylee was so sweet and skillful, and her positive vibes really enhanced my wedding prep process. Thank you so much, Kaylee!

As far as the actual business, everything was clean and beautiful (I love the pops of yellow and fun product names). Check in was simple and there is a small waiting area with all of the latest magazines to browse. I enjoyed a mimosa during my styling session. I'd recommend Drybar if you need your hair to look amazing for an event or if you just want a pick me up. Who doesn't feel like a bombshell after an amazing blowout?

More people need to know about this place and expand their chocolate palates! 

I'm a sucker for chocolate and I usually stick with locally produced Endangered Species Chocolate brand while out and about but SoChatti has found a new place in my heart. 

Reasons to love this place:
- staff are incredible nice
- female chocolate chef 
- 72% cocao content across the board means not overly sweet but also not 88%-bitter-AF 
- two options of chocolates to purchase: to-go sized or larger reusable packs
- once covid is lifted, they'll be using ceramic tasting dishes for less waste (holla!)
- tastings tastings tastings! For couples, bachelorette parties, kids, wine lovers, oh my! 
- chocolate-producing machines. Be sure to ask about their chocolate making process! 

One recommendation: have some hand sanitizer at each table for tastings. I might have missed it but good to have on hand to be extra safe! 

Get your chocolate-loving booties in here. You won't regret it!

I can't believe I forgot to review this place. I came here for a bachelorette party, we were staying at an AirBnb nearby. As someone who doesn't eat meat, I was actually surprised at how accommodating the restaurant was. I had black bean burger tacos with a side of mac and cheese. I'm not really into the pimento mac and cheese, but if it's your thing, I'm sure you'd like it here. The tacos were great, and the server was lovely.

I am excited that there is a restaurant like Blue Duck Sandwich Company in North East Philly.  Living closer to downtown there so many awesome restaurant options but in the North East where I work it's mostly chains restaurants or less than exciting pizza/bar food type places.  Now getting my co-works to branch out of just a basic salad or sandwich can be challenging at times.  But despite their preference for boring food choices they seem to be ok with the small and unique menu offered at Blue Duck Sandwich Company.  And one of them actually frequents the place regularly.

Love the décor of the place has a very farm to table feel to it.  It's very bright inside; the only issue I have is that both times we went it's been extremely cold to the point where I debated eating with my coat on.  They were out of their signature sandwich and the produce truck hadn't come so no tomatoes for the bbblt on our second visit which was a little disappointing since two of us planned to try the blue duck sandwich.

The Blue Duck Fries honestly could be a meal in itself, there huge the 1st time the 4 of us split them the second time I went I actually just got it as a meal neither time were they all finished.  I've tried both the bruschetta wing and general tso, both were nice and crispy but the general tso were infinitely better.  Two of my co-works are picky about Chicken Salad and raved about the club, so if you're picky too this one might be worth a try.  I really enjoyed the portabella burger the roasted red pepper aoli really topped it off.  Both the fried chicken sandwich and quack & cheese looked yummy.  If you're not into cheese the cheese on the salt and pepper fires comes on the side.  It's a different sauces from the blue duck fires both are tasty I can decided which I like better probably leaning towards the one on the blue duck fires.

This place is everything you could ask for ask in 1. Love at 1st sight  the sugar cane beverage was everything.  Refreshing and perfectly sweetened. The pho was big enough to share which we did. Yummy yum.  Then let me tell you about the shrimp fried rice.  Heavenly delicious.  Ok ok. Everything really was delicious and service was outstanding.  We dined outside which was cute.  We saw duckies and snapping turtles. EVERYTHING WAS So wonderful I asked the guy if he open a location in WC. Definitely coming back.  My kinda place.  them out and don't forget to get a chirro after the meal.  Delicious hot and fresh

I'm so glad this place is in Columbia, IL. It offers a clean, modern restaurant that serves something other than American or Mexican food. We had a party of six and there were several other large parties enjoying holiday lunches. We were seated and served promptly. Even our picky eaters got their food as ordered. I've been here several times and always loved what I ordered. Today the Pad Thai was off. It tasted scorched and while my husband said he didn't taste it, I could not eat it. I ordered a basil chicken dish instead and it was fine. We will be back.

Reading the other yelpers' reviews on here was very perplexing.  And like so many others, I don't see any possible justification for the low scores, so had to check it out.

Admittedly, hubby and I had never been to a Brazilian steakhouse before.  Who are these other yelpers who have experienced so much that leave us lowly native Middle Tennesseans "in the dust" culinary wise I wonder?  We've been to many places and experienced great dinners from all sorts of realms - so while this was new for us, it's not like it's our first dinner out.

We visited on Saturday night at 7 PM with reservations between Christmas and New Year's.  The restaurant had a few other guests, but not too many at all, and just felt "cool."  We were seated at a table where we could look out over Belcourt Avenue through the (permanently closed) glass-paned garage doors, and it provided basically dinner and a show.  We're Cool Springs people... and couldn't go over all the cabs dropping off diners for Sunset, Cabana, and here.

Note - very recently, like the past month, I'm told a second Brazilian steakhouse opened on Second Avenue next to Melting Pot. Don't know if that means anything, but just thought I'd mention as a possible explanation for the low crowds.

Our very kind waiter explained the steakhouse what's-going-to-happen, and brought us our drinks and beginning sides.  The salad bar was very well appointed and presented well - all the items were in geometic, interesting bowls and perfectly-molded together-but-crushed ice, it was really lovely.  Nice greek salad, excellent smoked salmon, fruits, chicken salad, olives... I don't know what more you could ask for honestly.

We finished our salads and enjoyed some absolutely fabulous rolls (small warm cheesey yet yeasty, yum!) and then once our waiter magically appeared at exactly the right moment with fresh plates, we flipped our little cards over to green.  Within like 30 seconds, the first "meat steward" appeared with filet on a sword, and we took our little tongs to accept a slice, then steward #2 was RIGHT behind him with BBQ chicken wings he popped off his skewer.  Not 30 seconds later, another meat steward with Parmesean Pork, another beef something or another, pulling right in like it was commuter traffic and there's a guy with lamb and grilled pineapple - yum!

We immediately saw the value in pace of eating, so we flipped our cards to red to enjoy for a bit.  The filet was excellent, BBQ chicken excellent, lamb excellent... was it the best ribeye ever?  Not for my taste.  There wasn't any meat in the 12 courses we tried allowing for a repeat round of "visits" that I'd say we disliked, but we did have favorites.  Our waiter checked on us periodically, and mentioned more than once if there was any specific meat we wanted to visit just let him know.  A BBQ rib selection was a favorite as well, but honestly we were so full - the only repeat we asked for was the grilled pineapple for the "palate cleanser" appeal.

Our service throughout from both our designated waiter and all the numerous meat stewards was very good - we never felt like we were waiting for anything.  The experience overall was very good, because honestly it's something different.  We can go have a very nice $100 dinner lots of places, but only here can you have multiple meat stewards come by with kabobs on swords and try a little bit of everything - and at this point in life we are all about trying something different.

We did use a Groupon for $35 discount, but our tab which included 18% grat (their norm when customers use a coupon) for the other dinner and three cocktails was $90.  A little pricey, but not ridiculously so considering the uniqueness in my opinion.  We would very well go back, probably for a special occasion and using a Groupon/Living Social deal again since that seems to be easily done.

First time at 4th Street Bistro - and it won't be our last. 

Everything we ordered was above and beyond our expectations. 
The pre-dinner cocktails were so yummy - I tried an unusual Citrus Drop - similar to a lemon drop - but a little on the orange side made with St. George Citrus Vodka. He ordered a Boulavardier. It was a smokey delight! 

The bread arrived and it was warm, yeasty, doughy goodness with a sweet creamy butter. We could have asked for a bucket of that to go and been fine! But... 

We moved on to appetizers - we share everything - so one ordered the Brussels Sprouts with Calabrian Chilies ... OMG.. probably the best Brussels we've ever had. Perfectly cooked and the chilies gave it such great flavor. We added the Duck Rillettes with Mango Mostarda - I thnk i was delirious after one bite. 

We tried the Asparagus and Spring Onion Soup... Was that tarragon? Pernod? How did you make ASPARAGUS taste so amazing!? 

Onto Dinner - Moroccan Chicken Breast for me and Lamb Shank for him. Both were superb. 

We brought a bottle of wine from our cellar to share. So - no opinion on the wine list. 

The service was great. Tim and Max tag teamed to keep us satisfied with water, wine refills, the correct flatware as needed - it was truly a team effort. 

I look forward to bringing out of town guests and celebrating special occasions here. 

Thank you for a lovely dinner!

You should definitely visit Zollicoffee. Even if your not a coffee fan, you will find something to love about this place. Less than a mile from my son's school, I find myself here quite a bit. They have interesting seasonal syrup flavors - and Zolli makes all the specialty syrups himself. Lavender, blueberry, strawberry, mocha cayenne, chocolate basil, etc. They have comfy couches, as well as regular tables. Lots of board games and some books to read. Outdoor seating w a giant Jenga game on a table. WONDERFUL employees. Always delightful. My favorite food item is the yogurt with granola and fruit. My son's favorite is the homemade Chex mix. My daughter is a huge cane of the fruity pebbles rice crispie treats. Oh! The rice crispie treats!!!! TONS of awesome flavors. I try not to eat sweets too much, so I usually only try a little free tidbit near the cash register. HIGHLY recommend this place.

I loves da Schlaflys.

Great beer. In my too few days in STL, I had the following types of beer from Schlafly: Hefeweizen, Pilsner, Pale Ale. All of them were great, good quality craft beer. I really enjoyed the Tap Room too and it was fun to walk around and in to the restaurant to see the brew making machines / magicalness.

We didn't have any food at the Tap Room, just beer. But the atmosphere was cool.  Kind of like a mix of a Wisconsin bar with a lot of wood details with a urban-chic section of comfy & modern couches with a tad bit of German Brauhaus for your to make it your own stammtisch.  

Great place and I wish I lived in the STL area so I could drink more Schlafly beer.

Pollo Tropical is not your typical "fast food".  Slow simmered black beans served over fluffy rice.  Grilled, marinated chicken that is juicy and tender.  I love the Tropichop meals - meat over your choice of rice, beans, or salad - and they often offer bundled deals for a Tropichop and a drink for $5.  They also have a salsa and sauce bar so you can spice up your meal as you see fit.  The food is consistently good, fast, and at a good price.

One down side - I have never had a to go order come out correctly at this location.  When I ask for sauce on the side, I usually have to go in and prep it myself so I started just ordering inside.  Nice staff but they always seem a little lost and disorganized.

A free museum in Nashville gets 5 stars from me.  The stuff in the store is a little high so they can let you tour for free.  Plus they charge you if you want to take a picture in one of the cars.  I love the idea of this place as I watched the show growing up.  It only take 20 minutes of your time to walk around and it is beside the Willie Nelson museum.  Why wouldn't you stop in here .

My daughter didnt think this place was all that cool, but there was room for her to walk around.  She was at least a little bit entertained.  They have the cars inside the place as well as the General Lee on the outside.  They also have a museum in the back that is dedicated to Sun records.  The cases are a little busy but for free I understand using all the space one can.

I think Juan's gets a lot of unnecessary flack. It is what it is. I hate that saying but it is true in Juan's case. This is not the restaurant you go to for Mexican food. But then again, it never says "Mexican restaurant" it says "Creole Taquería"; whatever the heck that means. Their margaritas are delicious but small for the price. If you like your margaritas in a "big girl glass" and not a "sippie cup" go during happy hour, they're 2 for 1 (double for the price of one). If you care that the wait staff all has tattoo sleeves and not real sleeves, don't go to Juan's. 
I have to admit, I have a soft spot for Juan's. I've been coming here since I was a lowly tourist and it was a great place to grab a drink and some food when I first moved to the city and knew no one. I have numbers in my phone that say things like "Annie-Juan's". These were people I first met when eating at the bar by my lonesome and we had such a great time that we continued to hang out and exchange numbers. So cut Juan's some slack huh? Food wise: I love the pork and slaw tacos (usual), the Mardi Gras Indian tacos (veggie option), and the bacon azul quesadilla (when you want something that just might kill ya, but at least it's a happy death). Happy hour really is the best time to go, cheaper drinks and fewer crowds.

Okay. Overall I love their cheesecake and every once in a while I BEG my fiance' to come here basically because I want that brown wheat bread they give you and I want a piece of cheesecake.  So we went last weekend.  Luckily, being a party of 2 the wait on a Saturday night was only 30 minutes but be aware to potentially wait well over an hour for a table, especially if you're a bigger party.

Usually, I don't have any complaints. The food is just average and I always order off the skinnylicious menu because seriously all of their food is WAY too many calories (good luck finding items on the normal menu under 1000 cals) and if you want cheesecake with that, it's just too much for me.   But this last time our waitress was terrible.  She didn't come to check on us at ALL and she got my order wrong.  I ordered the skinnylicious chicken tacos and I got some kind of fish tacos with rice and beans.  The problem is, after we got our food, we couldn't find her or anyone that wasn't running around for that matter, so I ended up just eating it because I was starving.  She also didn't give us any refills on our drinks which was annoying, especially because I literally got water so I don't think I was costing them much.  I hope they're more attentive next time!

I've lived here for about 6 months now and I absolutely love it! The views here of the city are unmatched. Building is always kept clean and the leasing office staff are always friendly and love giving my dogs treats.

Lee How Fook is a pleasant spot to dine with friends.  It's a BYOB and we sat around after dinner, finishing our wine without feeling rushed.  Service is good (by casual Chinese restaurant standards), but food is not so much.

THE GOOD NEWS:
Salt-baked squid is great.  Good texture, salty, tasty and fragrant.  4+ stars

Sauteed snow pea shoots (green leafy vegetables) are good.  I love snow pea leaves and there's nothing wrong with these! 3.5 stars

White rice: acceptable.  Not great, not fluffy, but edible and included with meal.

THE BAD NEWS:
Pan fried wide rice noodles (ho fun) with beef: so-so, mixed.  Noodles themselves are a good texture, and fried nicely, but beef is hard to eat: overcooked, hard pieces lacking in flavour.  I was surprised by how bad the beef was, since even the mediocre Chinese restaurants I'm used to will tenderize and season their beef adequately.  Lesson learned: Avoid the beef. 2 stars for the dish.

Szechuan eggplant is disappointing.  First of all, the flavour of this dish is not Szechuan at all.  Nor is it spicy.  Instead, it comes with something like a sweet and sour sauce -- and not a good one.  The texture of the eggplant was fine, tender and soft, but a disaster flavour-wise.  I normally love Chinese eggplant, but the flavour on this was such a turn-off that I didn't want to eat much of this dish.  To be avoided. 1 star.

Pork with mushrooms, bamboo shoots is again not something I'd want again.  Pork is overcooked, and lacked flavour.  The vegetable stuff in the dish is fine, nothing amazing, but nothing gone horribly wrong with it.  Avoid pork. 1.5 stars.

SUMMARY:
Could go back for salt-baked squid, snow pea leaves, and ho fun noodles, but I'd want to avoid anything with beef or pork.  Might need to avoid anything that requires flavouring (with sauces, slurries, etc.)  The simpler dishes seem to work best here, e.g. SQUID + SALT = yummy, GREENS + GARLIC = good.

I'm putting an optimistic spin on things -- partly because I had such a great time with friends here -- but frankly, it's pretty bad when a Chinese restaurant can neither manage a dish with more than 2 main ingredients, nor pull together an acceptable sauce when so many dishes depend on it.

General rating ends up around 2 stars: I've definitely had better.

Great selection! I love the Starbucks area in this store. I also really like the layout and all the space of this location. The staff is always friendly and helpful. The reward program is great and I love the promotional offers they have!

I don't know why I've never been to this festival until this year. Maybe the very strange promotional art? I thought it was going to be very hippie, and it was in a way, but it brought out a lot of people...and not all of them were hippies. I do love the idea though: arts and crafts through upcycled material...how much cooler is that?

Getting there is somewhat of a pain because Highway 50 narrows down to one lane each way when you get close to the park. Add to that Oktoberfests galore, and you have a very nice recipe for "traffic jam". Everyone parks everywhere, but surprisingly enough, parking wasn't that big of a deal. It is really a family thing too. They have arts and crafts for the kids, indie bands playing, lots of picnic tables set up with the usual assortment of fair foods, an alpaca petting zoo, and of course, Girl Scouts selling cookies. 

But the booths themselves are the showcase, and the media is quite varied, even though I heard a booth owner complain, "It is so hard nowadays to be original." She was selling wire jewelry, so I guess I can see her point. And really, my favorite booths are really the unique ones like Beqi Clothing and Newberry Furniture. The Newberrys repurpose old wood for new stuff...their current thing consists of Adirondack chairs made from an old barn. And Beqi takes vintage clothing and changes it all around..she has quite the gift. The whole thing is pretty big, and it really does impress me that there are so many craftsters in the area.

How lucky were we that this festival was going on the weekend that we went to New Orleans? And that Richard Simmons happened to be there the same weekend so he showed up at the festival and jumped on stage?

This is a very small festival with maybe 10 art vendors and only 4-5 gumbo vendors... but it's free to get in so I can't complain. Loved the seafood gumbo that I got but there weren't a whole lot of options (which is very surprising for a gumbo FESTIVAL) hence why I'm only giving it 3 stars.. "festival" is kind of a big word to use for what was more a concert in the square with some gumbo.

After trying the cheesteaks and roast beef sandwiches at the market, make a stop here for the Trainwreck. We preferred it's meaty, spicy, greasy goodness to the iconic cheesesteak sandwich because it was packed with flavor.     The portion size was good enough for two of us to share for lunch. Try to down the sandwich quickly because the grease can make it soggy if it is sitting out a long time. We also got the beignets which are served on Sunday. I felt the doughnuts were a bit chewy because of the dough but my dining partner loved them. The sweet tea rounded everything off nicely and was a good way to wash down the lunch. Cajun is not a cuisine that instantly comes to mind when you are visiting Reading Terminal Market, but the wonderful flavors in the sandwiches served at this place is worth giving it a shot.

came here last night before the fireworks per classmate's suggestion.  hands down, the best jukebox i've ever heard/seen in a bar.  now, i'm no musical genius, nor do i consider myself to be at the cutting-edge of the industry's hippest and coolest and newest, so maybe that's not saying much.  regardless, i loved the tunes, and it seemed like everyone else was digging 'em too.

good variety of beers on top as well.  the food was surprisingly good--the fries are of the rustic variety, and much to my delight, some sweet potato fries were tossed into the mix.  cornbread was damn good, too.  great location, top-notch jukebox, good food, nice vibe.  can't go wrong, in my book.

I love Mexican food, so when a customer asked me to join him here for a work lunch I was super excited. Apparently this used to be a retail store only selling Mexican groceries and goods (the store is still in the back and is super cool) and recently added the restaurant portion. I ordered the mole chicken enchiladas and I'm pretty sure my order was mixed up somehow... there wasn't a hint of mole flavouring or colouring. The meal was okay, it was fresh and relatively tasty but I couldn't get past my disappointment of getting regular chicken enchiladas instead of mole (I am never the guy that would complain or correct, they are a small business trying to make it so I'll eat what I get). Served with side beans and rice, and tortilla chips and salsa to start... the best part here was the homemade hot sauces they bring out... quite the assortment of deliciousness if you are a hot sauce person too.

This is a spot I will give a second chance. When I do I'll report back on how my mole chicken enchiladas were!!

It takes me a bit to get the spelling right but after eating delicious food I will not forget where I ate! I noticed this place when venturing to Dings Tea the day prior. Having minimal time for dinner and having to run for an early evening webinar I wanted to give aldertos a try. 
I'm so glad I did.
I ordered a carnitas torta I thought it was a monstrous amount neatly packed in the wrapper.  There was an abundance of meat and even amount of tomato and lettuce. I thought this was perfect. It was so good I didn't leave a crumb behind.
I did drive through and after having one car in front of me quickly realized there were soon to be too more behind me. I thought that was a definite good sign. I would love to try other food options. I'm happy I found a delicious place with decently quick service!

Hands down my favorite theater in St. Louis. (I love Moolah but when I am not working I like to get away from the 8000 college students I work with).

Everyone has already talked about beer and wine being sold and that there is never a large crowd. I have never experienced movies selling out there either.

But I want to add a little nugget of wisdom about parking. If you drive to the theater there is a pay lot across Lindel from the Chase. If you bring your ticket stub out with you after the movie you don't have to pay for parking!

Located just north of Grant MacEwan on busy 109 Street is Purple Bubble, and you'll see their signature purple hue coming from the windows as you drive by. I stopped by after dinner one evening to check out the space and see what they had to offer.

While bubble tea isn't a go-to for me like it was in my younger days, I definitely appreciate a good milk tea every once in a while! At Purple Bubble there are a variety of drinks and a handful of snacks and desserts you can order as well. 

When it comes to bubble tea I'm a green tea or traditional milk tea kind of girl. The Original Milk Tea ($5.49) at Purple Bubble is smooth and isn't overly sweet. making it a winner in my books. The menu has an extensive list of milk teas, including some specialties like Hokkaido Caramel milk tea and Pudding milk tea. If tea isn't quite your thing, Purple Bubble also offers fresh fruit smoothies and fruit slush. 

One thing that separates Purple Bubble from all the other bubble tea spots in the city is their Blooming Art Tea ($6.99). A clear teapot suspended over a tealight holds a single flower bulb that "blooms" as it steeps. It really is quite lovely to see the flower open, and it makes me think I need to get myself a clear teapot! 

When it comes to the snacks, Purple Bubble has both sweet and savoury offerings. There's the usual fries and Chinese snacks like dimsum and dumplings, but on the more interesting side there's Taiwanese fried chicken, seafood ramen, Taiwanese style rice bowls and even Korean style spicy rice cakes. As this visit was after dinner we decided on an order of Egg Waffles ($4.99) - one of my favourite street foods in Hong Kong. Very few places in the city offer egg waffles, and those that I've tried have been quite disappointing. Luckily the puffy egg waffles at Purple Bubble are the best I've had in the city. Served fresh out of the waffle maker, the waffles are light, puffy, eggy, and lightly sweetened. 

For a dessert option Purple Bubble has Snow Ice ($6.99), which is their variation on a bowl of shaved ice. This dessert is available in four different flavours: Matcha, Vanilla, Strawberry, and Mango. We opted to go with the mango, and the shaved snow came topped with fresh mango chunks and a light drizzle of condensed milk. The snow was fluffy and creamy, and the mango topping sweet and fragrant. However this shaved snow did have a bit of an artificial flavouring to it, so it didn't quite hit the spot for me.

Purple Bubble is in a great location along busy 109 Street and just a quick walk away from the Grant Macewan campus. It would be a great spot for students to study or catch up with friends, and it's in a place where it is convenient to stop on the commute out of downtown. I would happily stop by for some tea and egg waffles if I were in the area and craving something sweet!

Melt in your mouth beignets! My word I was so in love. Super messy, but super good you don't even care you have powered sugar on your clothes or on the side of your mouth. 

Next visit I'm getting extra!

One of my all time faves, this is the first thrift store to hit in South Philly!  Racks and bins of clothing always stuffed to the gills.  Their selection of 80s prom dresses and wedding gowns is usually jaw dropping.  And, the prices are really quite decent in comparison to other Philadelphia area shops.  I have noticed a recent raise in prices.  However, as thrifting becomes an accepted and often profitable hobby, that seems to be the nationwide trend.

There are always a fair amount of hipster types at this establishment.  But, oddly enough, this thrift store hardly ever seems picked over.

Best thing:  An often large selection of boots in the fall/winter - from Frye cowboy boots, to 80s slouchies, and uber glam heeled "hooker boots" - I've found it all.  And, they stock a large amount of mens clothing and ties.  I find some of my best guy's stuff here.  Note: If you're a guy, always check the women's section for jeans.  Whenever I come across 70's bell bottoms and 80's skinny jeans in that section, they are usually for men.

Worst thing: There are no carts.  You have to keep making trips to the front to dump your finds in their reserved bins.  I find that incredibly annoying, as I love to get lost in the shopping experience.

Full disclosure: the owner is a friend of mine.

And he loves what he does. That dedication and passion for accessible cuisine really shines through here. 

I've probably had a third of the menu here so far - stand outs are the mac and cheese (it's not a side - share it), the banh mi sliders, the pulled pork nachos, and the homemade parmesan truffle chips. The bang bang chicken is also pretty good - be warned, however, because even though I can eat a spoonful of ghost pepper sauce and still remain coherent, the bang bang chicken made me sweat for a good 20 minutes. It's not so much a super sharp heat (6 out of 10 with ghost pepper at 9 in my opinion), but it's a sustained one. Good, but if you're not a lover of heat, you might wanna stay away.

Also, tons of beers. Ithaca beers. I'm always a bit disappointed at how many craft bars don't have Ithaca beers available, But the last few times I've been here, they had both Cascazilla and Flower Power IPA. Delicious.

Also, 5 dollars for a pour of whiskey? Seriously? Get a designated driver, and try 5 of them. 

It's also a beautiful space. My kind of ambience. They also play a lot of funk, R&B, classic rock, and other selections in the dining area. Not a lot of places stray from Buddha Bar or top 40, so this was welcome change for me. Put on some James Brown and you've made my night.

Also, check out their shows and movie nights and the like throughout the week. I saw a band there last Saturday that was actually quite good. Alt rock, local band, you know the deal. I'm pissed that I forgot their name, but hey - I was 6 deep and still drinking when I got there. 

Check the place out.

Of all the snowballs I've eaten in my life, I've probably had Pandora's the most.  There's so many flavors to choose from and the ice is so perfectly shaved but sometimes they can be a little skimpy on the syrup.  My mom is a Wedding Cake fan but I love the lemon-lime!

All of the yes. 

Definitely check out this beer if you're in the area. They are doing some really great stuff. From juicy IPA's to complex tiramisu stouts, they're awesome. 

I love the down to earth style, colors and vibe. The bartender was great, too. Awesome spot!

I thank all my Yelp friends and others for suggesting that I pop into Thumbelina's for my bridesmaid's dress alteration this past week since it was easily accessible from my house. I walked in on a Thursday, and said I needed my dress by Tuesday. She waved me into the changing room to make the alterations without any sort of sigh or "tut tut" you might get asking for a late favor.  The dress was a double layer of two opposing fabrics; one being a light fabric under a thick lace with sequins adorning it.  She pulled it tighter along the back seam and pinned it without putting any other alteration pins in it besides there. I took off the dress, and paid $32 in cash that I miraculously had on me that day. ((Cash or check only)).  I really don't know the price of alterations, but I felt like this was fine. 

I ended up actually picking up the dress early Wednesday morning since I pushed my flight back, and trusted that the alterations had been made correctly. 

Four days later I put on the dress right before my sister's wedding and loved how Thumbelina had transformed this beautiful yet frumpy-ish garment into a well-fitting dress that I could feel confident in wearing again. 

Notes:
-They do have weird hours and days off, so make sure to check!
-Wear the undergarments that you'll be wearing when you wear the altered piece again
-Bring cash or check
-Parking behind the building on the grass
-I would suggest trying on whatever you have altered there just to make sure, but they did a great job on my dress

This is a hands down 5 star place. Can't wait to go back. In fact we became wine club members and look forward to coming back for dinner and get our bottle of wine for free!!

Anyone who loves wine or enjoys it needs to go here. It's a wine person heaven. Im actually a beer guy but enjoyed every glass I had. And the different ways to enjoy it were sensational. You can order bottles from the store in front and bring it to the table. You can order a flight which is 4 tastings sampler. Order a carafe out of the barrel of their "seasonal special". Or just order a classic bottle service or glass. And even show up early and pay only 7$ for wine tasting. The area they hold the wine tasting is full of all kinds of great wine accessories for your wine enthusiasts. 

Now for the food, wow everything we were served was supremely delicious, fresh, and cooked to perfection. I highly suggest you ask for the free pretzel bread. Wow so good. The Asian Pork belly tostadas was out of this world appetizer. Made to perfection. I had the Dana's Parmesan Crusted Chicken and it was sensational. The freshness and taste was just exploding out of this meal. And you would think a place with this upscale atmosphere, amazing food and wine, would be well over priced, WRONG!! The prices here were not only fair but comparable to your general restaurant. But the food was hands down a million times better. The wine service amazing. And our waiter made us feel like we were his prestigious guest he provided us with such great service. 

So with all that said there is no reason to go anywhere else when for the comparable price you can eat amazing food, great wine, amazing service, and a beautiful atmosphere and view. 

We are 100% sold on Cooper's hawk and will be back soon and often!!

This place is pure love. By far one of the best options in Nola, away from tourist traps of French quarters yet very much accessible by Uber. 
This was highly recommended by a friend and it totally exceeded our expectations. The vibe is very hippie and its a self service kind of place so might get a bit confused initially figuring out how it works. The bar tender was pretty helpful though a bit cheeky, guess was trying to fit with the vibe of the place so we didn't mind that at all. We chose to sit outdoors in their backyard over some live music and under the warm toasty sun. I dig such cozy set ups, enough to win me over.
We ordered an olive tapenade sandwich and wines to start with. I can say very confidently that each and every ingredient is freshly sourced and carefully selected. You can taste the freshness in every bite, their portion size is also generous but then hey it's Nola. 
The afternoon was so enjoyable that we kept the wine coming and decided to go next for the cheese platter. For that you need to go to their wine shop in the front, pick your own cheese and pay at the counter. They charge u extra for the cheese plating. Do not regret coz they do an awesome job; you get cheese along with generous portion of bread slices, jelly, mustard sauce, sweet pecans, olives and pickled beans. 
Don't miss out on the cheese platter, it's worth every penny.
We loved our afternoon spent at this wonderful place. They are doing it right coz it pays to be different.

I discovered Drago's by reading the reviews on Yelp.  For the most part I have never been mislead by Yelpers but I have to say as far as the Charbroiled Oysters are concerned....I don't get it!  My buddy and I agreed, "they are just okay".  Admittedly, maybe we just are not oyster people but seriously we just didn't get what all the fuss is about.

Okay, now that I have gotten that off my chest, I absolutely loved my entree!!!  I ordered the Charbroiled Lobster with Spinach Risotto.  I'm not really a lobster person.  I find it to be a lot of work for a little bit of pay off.  However, this lobster gave me a huge return on my investment!  Every bite was delectable!  The spinach risotto wasn't exactly "real risotto".  It was more like rice with spinach and sausage.  Even though it wasn't what I was expecting, it still was delicious and I cleaned my bowl.  Lastly, the service here is incredible.  After this meal, I walked back to my room, climbed into bed and had a peaceful rest with dreams about buttery charbroiled crustaceans.  I will definitely be back!

Love the atmosphere! Awesome portions for super-low prices!  And its Creole at its best.
My favorite is the Chicken Po'Boy with Etouffee and Bread Pudding...
But side are unlimited so TRY THEM ALL!

Perfect place to hang out with friends! It can get busy in the evenings and the tables are first come, first served, so you kind of have to lurk around to find a place. But once seated, order the pretzel with beer cheese sauce- it was seriously my favorite part of the meal. The beer list is extensive and the sandwiches are served on pretzel bread, my fave. The food was not quite as delicious as I had expected...but the atmosphere is fun and casual, great service, love the porch and it's just a ton of fun.

Hip downtown sushi favorite on trendy Mass Ave. Always love this place. Great servers, great sushi, great cocktails! Especially worth the trip for 1/2 price sushi Sunday's, but well worth the trip even at full price! Grab the girls, besties or significant other and enjoy a great night out! 
This place still continues to rock! We love the sushi quality and variety and the drink specials! Always a great trip to Mass ave for sushi!

Yummers to the 'nth degree.

Pasta, why do I love thee so?  Why must you be prepared so deliciously here?  Why are you so heavy-laden with carbohydrates that I must avoid you most of the year? Why, is it that I let my guard down at Raddichio and consume you until I wipe my plate clean? Why??

Even crowded on Monday nights (a tell-tale sign that this place is not only good, it's popular), this cute corner BYOB is a neighborhood staple and along with La Locanda (a couple blocks over), it's a solid go-to choice for local italian BYO around Old City.  

Dinner progression goes like this: crusty bread, complimentary fresh bruschetta to start.  Wicked garlicky goodness of mussels followed by a favorite of mine, Penne Toto, that is liberally doused with mouth-watering prosciutto, shallots and a pink vodka cream sauce.  Get in my belly!  All their seafood is good here too, and the fish of the day is always fresh and well-prepared.  

Service is fast, sometimes rushed and a little impersonal.  Menu consists of good, standard Italian dishes except the Scallops Al Radicchio -  which are bland and the scallops are almost invisible (more white beans than anything) - skip it - and try their calamari instead.  Also, appears like frequent patrons (or family and friends of the owner?) get preferential seating and even reservations - even though the restaurant does not offer them.  I guess if you show up here in a Porsche or a Corvette Stingray, it guarantees you the first and best table in the joint.

I'm surprised at all the negative reviews, Stock Rittenhouse is definitely at the top of my go-to work lunch spots Iist.

Here's what it's not: a cheap authentic Vietnamese place with $5 banh mis or $6 pho. If that's what you're looking for you're gonna have to walk down to Chinatown or Washington Ave. I'd love to do that too, but it's too far to walk for lunch on a work day.

Here's what it is: a place you can take a coworker that's maybe never had Burmese noodles or a Thai crispy rice salad or Cambodian pork dip that you can be in and out within an hour and pay $12 for a decent amount of food that you can even pack up half of for a snack later or lunch the next day if you have any self control (I don't). The flavors are not too crazy or spicy or authentic but they're better than it's predecessor wokworks or a place like honeygrow. 

Food:

The options are more interesting than your typical Asian fast casual concept, there are herbs and toppings and things you've never heard of, but then there are simple things like a chicken pho (which they call a good deal soup for some reason), peanut noodles, and banh mis. Some of the other options are a curry soup (very good and going to be my go to in the winter), Curry noodles (really liked these), Burmese noodles (liked them at first but then got a bit tired of the flavor- lots of picked things), Thai crispy rice salad (good and actually spicy), Cambodian pork dip (this is an app and was very good, and would be big enough for a meal). The dishes aren't as customizable as wok works or honeygrow where you choose a sauce, topping, veggies and everything, here you just choose a protein ( tofu, seitan, grilled chicken, fried chicken, pork (+$1), and shrimp (+$3)). The fried chicken and grilled chicken are both really good.

The set up is pretty much the same as wok works was: order at the counter, choose a protein and type of food, they have some sort of rewards system you can link your card to, serve yourself complimentary water and grab your chopsticks/cutlery/napkins/ hot sauce, sit down at tables very close to others, they bring out your food, you bus your own table.

Hoping they add some hot noodle dishes for the winter, and looking forward to trying all their options!

We had a really good dinner here. We made reservations as it was a Friday night. Very cute space and love the booths. Our waitress was amazing very attentive without being intrusive. Good beer selection and yummy margheritas. We had the queso as an appetizer and it was really good, best chips I've had in a Mexican restaurant in a long time. The tacos we had were delicious, chicken al caborne. We also had a side of beans that were yummy. They had meat in them and had a smokey flavor. We loved nada and will be back.

Interesting little shop with a definite aesthetic...if it meshes with your own, you'll love it; if not, you might find a present.  Lots & lots of blingy jewelry, some vintage & some new. I'm coveting a 1930s Christmas tree pin which is well priced at $180. But there are lots of new pieces as low as $20:

It is definitely not a hard sell place; the sales woman was much more interested in chatting than convincing me to purchase. Not a bad thing...

Mr. B's was hands down one of the favorite meals of my trip.   

Great location on the corner of Royal and Iberville and directly across from the Hotel Monteleone. Seeing that it was new years weekend and we hadn't made a reservation, we were told that there would be a 60-70 minute wait. The bar was PACKED and we wouldn't have been able to sit down and enjoy a drink while we waited so we walked across the street and got a round at the Carousel Bar. We returned 45 minutes later and were told that they had already called for our table and that the restaurant was closing so they would "see what they could do." 

Ending up sitting at the bar which was actually a good thing because we didn't feel obligated to over order.  We were there specifically for the BBQ shrimp (their signature dish) and were were not let down! We were given bibs because the jumbo shrimp (with their heads still on) were served in a big bowl, sitting atop at least two inches of a peppery, butter sauce. It also came with french bread for dipping.  Trust me, it was GOOOOD stuff!  

 I am always a sucker for jumbo sea scallops so we had an order of those as well. They were served with a spicy,  watercress salad drizzled with white truffle oil and shaved parmesan reggiano.  Also delicious!!! 

The restaurant itself is beautiful and only added to my new found love of the city.

Along my walk through downtown Reno, I popped into the Renaissance Reno Downtown Hotel.  It's a Marriott Hotel and embodies that retro boho chic decor, much like the Basement.  Love the way it's decorated - a notch above the previous hotel/casino tenant in this building.  Fun bocchi ball courts.  Lots of kids enjoying a family day at the hotel.  Couple of nice restaurants.  Seating along the river.  A very modern looking lobby with comfy furniture.  Clean, fresh.  I noticed a family enjoying he area.  They were very comfortable and appeared to be feeling that it was just like home to them.  It was nice to see them having a good time.
Cool art plastered along the walls toward the lobby and throughout. My guess is that they are local artists.
I didn't try the restaurants.  Will update as I have an opportunity to try them out.
I also noticed that there were a lot of dogs here in the lobby so I guess the hotel is pet friendly.  Dogs were on leashes.  Pretty cool
I parked in the courthouse parking on a Sunday.  Free parking and lots of it

We were out and about and wanted something different to eat without the "restaurant vibe" considering we weren't dressed for all that. Passed by Little Greek and decided to hit a quick u-turn to try it out.

I'm huge on customer service and theirs was great from the jump. The girl working the front asked us if we had been in before, we let her know we hadn't, and she went through the menu. She let us know that they were out of 100% lamb but their Gyro meat (90% beef, 10% lamb) was good. I think she noticed under my mask that I was a little suspect of it being "good" and offered me to try a piece. It was delish and had she not told me, I would've thought it was 100% lamb; appreciate the honesty! 

I ordered the Greek Salad with Gyro meat and the BF ordered the Steak-Skewer dinner. Both of us were impressed with our meals. I loved the potato salad on the salad and their Greek dressing paired very well. My BF loved the rice on his salad and said the steak was "flavorful." The side of warm pita bread was good too and was shocked my boyfriend ate it too as that's usually not his thing. 

We ended up eating our food there and the manager periodically checked on us, which was a nice touch. The entire crew, front of the house and back, acknowledged us on our way out...another plus. I enjoyed the small business vibe and will definitely be back again.

Bottom Line:  Shops like this are incredibly valuable as they are run by people who are enthusiasts and genuinely love what they do  

Long live the small car shop!

I had been having some issues with my NA Miata and I learned about Ryan and this shop through some friends.  I got in touch with him and because he is just a car nut, he is just incredibly knowledgeable about the Miata in particular.

I finally brought the car in and what I thought was going to be a really big deal turned out to be something relatively simple but he was able to warn me about possible future issues that I hadn't really considered.

Thanks guys!

*****Zahav, Zahav, Zahav. Feels Like a Migos Song or Something*****

FOOD
Salatim: Don't sleep on the cabbage. The Beets are an older fave than even The Beats on Doug (killer tofu, anyone?), but the cabbage was my favorite.

Hummus and Bread: the SINGLE GREATEST DISH I have ever eaten in the United States! Thank you, Based Zahav. Someday, I will treat myself to an AYCE hummus sesh at the bar. For reference, went to Dizengoff for lunch, and this completely blew it away (which is no stab at Dizengoff). Bread is one my favorite foods and it doesn't get better than Zahav's laffa folks.

Mezze:
Duck Hearts: a classic favorite. Salty even by Zahav standards but the muscle is exquisite.
Sable: On a previous visit, I found this dish "inspirational." This rendition gave a more "uplifting" vibe. From the bread, to the egg, to the delicate fish, the dish gets increasingly lighter, providing a fresh, enlivening energy.
Kibbe: another old favorite
Haloumi: Classic dish but this is the best rendition I have had (dat date sauce doh). Gotta get multiple orders when sharing with a big group.
Cauliflower: A Zahav staple. Highly recommended for first timers. 
Crispy Grave Leaves: these were great, but not my favorite among the mezze
Cobia Crudo: If you could make a mini pizza out of fish, this would be it. Nice spicy sauce complements the raw fish well. Recommended for the adventurous

Al Ha'esh
Crimini Mushrooms: Very good but not the best I've ever had. 
Branzino: Also exquisite but portion could have been a little larger (~4 small bites).
Lamb Merguez: mmm mmm good.
Beef and Lamb Kofte: see lamb merguez
Rice: Would have liked to see a slightly bigger portion, not because I had room for it, but just because its rice. I'm just really looking for reasons to criticize, at this point...Please bring the Ribeye back, Zahav!!! 

Dessert: true sleeper of the meal. Wasn't expecting this as a strength but Zahav is still #zahav. Wasn't a huge fan of the complexity and sourness of the sourbet but it was a hit at the table. Ice cream sandwich was small (cut into 3 pieces) but delicious. Chocolate mousse had the most decadent cream. Kataifi had a great variety of texture and I felt one of the largest portions.

SERVICE: It's like they secretly slip a magnet in your food that repels you from the staff when you walk around the restaurant. If you are sitting on the open end of a table, good luck trying to make it to the restroom and back before your napkin is neatly folded. Same goes for seeing the bottom of the water glass, quite impressive given the massive quantities of water necessary with a neverending rather salty feast at the table. Service would seem over the top if they couldn't pull it off, but boy do they pull it off. 

PLAYLIST ANALYSIS: Up to this point we're at six stars. Zahav flexed an upbeat variety, with The Dream to dropping sidetracks from College Dropout (School Spirit) and the Black Album (Lucifer). Even paired Nas and Jay songs with only one song in btwn!! If anyone can pull that off, it's Zahav. But the one moment where things went too far...to my utter shock, I heard Drake (fortunately not while I was enjoying that hummus). I wasn't expecting to hear Meeks weak response to Back to Back, but dropping a sing songy Drake track? TOO SOON, Zahav, TOO SOON.

WEBSITE: Single greatest website music ever. Really want to bump this at my wedding. Until then...link: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nBuBAOxtLpI

FINAL VERDICT: I can't imagine why anyone besides Jeezy ("standing at my podium, trying to watch my sodium") and maybe Meek would not fall in love with Zahav. Get rid of the Drake and I'll consider petitioning Yelp to add a sixth star #zahav

I love this place! Went for weekend brunch with a friend, and I was expecting a crazy wait. We waited around 30 minutes, which seems reasonable at 11 on a Sunday. Cute decor, cool vibe, and the food was delicious. I got the fried egg sandwich on a brioche and it was amazing (and came with breakfast potatoes!). Can't wait to go back.
Small, clean place attached to the hotel. Service was fast and my pizza was perfect. I love thin crust and Provel cheese- it is so gooey and delicious!

Bravo, bravo! Vision Lofts was a wonderful place for my coworkers and I to get sh*t done. We had the space to ourselves for our annual planning summit and while there were only about 10 of us, you could definitely host an epic party of just about any kind, in this lovely space. My brain went wild thinking of fun things to do here. 

It was big and open, had tons of natural light, the bathrooms were clean and fabulous, I loved the plant wall towards the back, they had coffee available all throughout the day and heck, there was even a fireplace! We spent the majority of our time in the center of the building watching presentations, but they even had couches and cozy corners scattered around. When we needed go get up to stretch our legs, we could! Additionally, the staff was really helpful when need be, and they had tons of televisions around. 

Overall, they went above and beyond to make our group feel welcome. I'd highly recommend.

Service is awesome!  Even though I didn't find exactly what I wanted, the salesperson was very helpful and friendly!  I was on my lunch break, so I was on a time crunch.  As soon as I walked in, he asked if I was looking for something in particular.  I told him what I needed & that I didn't have much time, then off he went to get me a few dresses that fit the style I was looking for.  

There was a lot to choose from, but I didn't fall in love with any particular dress. (Lately I've been a picky shopper-not getting anything unless I absolutely love it or need it)  

I have to admit though, there are a lot of unique stuff here.  If you are looking for vintage dresses or jewelry, stop on by!  It's worth the look even if you're just browsing.  =)

I crave burritos on a regular basis and it seems that Chipotle is the best Nashville has yet to offer up to burrito lovers. It's sad to be honest. Chipotle will never have burritos that will compare to my personal favorite of nopales and tofu rancheros from my local taquaria in San Francisco. But its what happens when you move away from the source. If there are some veg friendly places I am overlooking, please drop some knowledge on this transplant.

This is your standard Chipotle. If you like Chipotle in general, you will like this one. I work across the street and this is the best vegan option for my long days on campus. I tend to burrito here frequently (burrito is a verb here). 

If you don't like Chipotle, you won't like this one either.

I find that Chipotle is a fix, but is not quite fully satisfying. It's like when you really want to have a satisfying beer and there is only light beer. Yeah, you will drink it, but it's no IPA. It serves it's purpose well.

My husband and I were in a mood for sandwiches tonight. We came to this location because it's closest to our house. I ordered tuna club- delicious and tasted very fresh.
Husband got hunters club- he loved it.
All employees wore masks, food looked, smelled and tasted delicious. We will definitely be back. We enjoyed it so much we did not take pictures fast enough before it was all gone. Thank you!

How can my favorite store rank 2 out of 5 on the Christy Scale! Well, let me explain...

The store's presentation is appalling. Scarce shelve, disorganized, junky, open product still on shelves, bread on shelves next to cleaning products, dirty floors...a damn mess.

I was in total awe of this Dollar Store location. I'd hate to be a Maplewood resident having to rely on this location for my $1 days. I am a Dollar Store FANATIC, there's very little not to love about the jewels they offer for a single buck. However, here's where I draw the line. 

2 stars for the pleasant customer service and the merchandise that was somewhat easily accessible.  Management needs to be ashamed. I'm taking my dollars elsewhere. 

~Christy

Bringing you back to 1965 diner style eats. Burgers, fries, shakes and hot dogs. 

Personally I love me a good old fashioned burger and it looked like they had a burger that looked like a big Mac if that's your thing! 

I went plain jane today. A naked frank. An angus beef hot dog sliced open and grilled, on a plain bun. Hey, don't judge, it takes me back to childhood alright?? I know I asked for a naked hotdog, but they toasted the bun and it made it much drier than if they had not. 

Onion petals. Think of.onion rings but just a different shape. They come with a dipping sauce i can't quite describe other than its called the "clancy sauce."  It was white and almost looked like tartar sauce but it definitely wasn't. It was chilled and thick, a bit tangy. Was good for dipping the onion petals, but I would be curious if their famous cheese sauce wasn't even better. 
Crinkle cut fries, single burgers with the option to double up the party for an extra $3 and chili cheese fries. I'll be back to try everything.

Beautiful walkway, loved walking here, sometimes just sitting outside the hotel watching the view and people running past me. Very peaceful, and serene. Must be the best part of downtown Tampa...for me at least.

I am in love with this place! My friends and I came here for restaurant week, and it was definitely worth it. The waiting area was cozy while we waited for our last friend to park. He was about 20 minutes late, but they didn't mind.

We got a bottle of red wine along with dinner. For the appetizer, I ordered a mozzarella with Italian meat. I was expecting something like prosciutto, but it was disappointing... I'd liken it to plain ham from the deli. My friends were happy with their butternut squash soup and beet salad, though. We all had the filet mignon for our entree and everyone was wowed. All conversation stopped because we were too busy eating! It was definitely one of the best steaks I've ever had.

For dessert, I ordered chocolate bread pudding and tasted my friend's blood orange sherbet. Both were phenomenal as well.
